This game is extremely cool with VR. There is a lot going on with the game. I was looking for a flight simulator that was realistic, and had a good amount of planes to test fly, while also being able to use VR tech to enjoy the realism. Xplane 11 has a lot to offer. It is about 91 Gigs to download. So about 40ish gigs less than MFS. You don't need to make an account to play. Graphics for the inside of the plane 8/10. Graphics for the outside 6/10 with my entry level computer. If you have god tier comp, probably 8/10. It still looks really good, especially from high above. They did an excellent job with all the controls in the plane. You can hold the x button on the MQ3 Controller to zoom look at all the switches and buttons in the plane, as well as the view outside windows. I set my graphics and everything to max. The only thing I left at a normal setting was the Anti Aliasing. If you set it to Max or anything above what your comp can handle, there will be lagtime and stuttering as you look around. Not enjoyable to play that way. If you have a 5ghz Network on your router, connect your headset to that instead of the 2.4ghz standard one. It will make streaming to your headset much smoother. The game is a lot of fun. Lots of different craft to fly. Small planes, 747 commercial planes, military jets, helicopters, gliders, sea planes, ect. They even allow you to fly the planes from the older version of this game, which includes a nasa rocket. Haven't flown that one yet. The game allows you take lessons as well so you can get hands on realistic experience on how flying really is. You can do full flight paths and have communications with the flight control stations. They have almost every airport in the world on here to take off from. The initial cities and surrounding land mass is pretty realistic for these areas. But if you are trying to fly over, lets say, your house. In your home state. It isn't THAT realistic. Trust me, I tried. I believe the game is using some sort of map generator beyond the airports and cities. You will see random highways that don't exist, or the road ramping off into nothing sometimes. A lot of random generation beyond the airports and cities. I'm excited to see where this technology goes in the future with how realistic it is already. If they incorporated google earth maps with this game, it'd be a sight to behold. I recommend if you get this game, to find a few planes that you're comfortable flying. Get them up to a nice altitude, and then start using your controller to flip switches and dials and figure out what they do. It's very enjoyable. If you don't have a joystick, GET ONE. You can use the VR controllers to fly the planes, but it's annoying having to hold the triggers down the entire time and to lose your grip on stuff randomly. A Joystick will make it feel that much more realistic and make your gameplay more fun. I purchased one for 25 bucks. On the 747, you can even open the cockpit door to the passenger area and see rows of seats. You can't walk back there but it's pretty cool to see it, and feel like you could. You can parachute out of the planes as well which is pretty fun. I couldn't believe they even had an airport for Okinawa Japan for me to fly around and check out the area i used to live in. So cool. I definitely recommend getting this game if you're interested in flying. I looked around a lot before I got this one and it was a great purchase in my opinion. I already know a lot more about planes now and have the confidence that I could actually land a plane in an emergency situation already. With a MetaQuest3 headset, running this game. You will get about 3 hours of gameplay before your headset needs to be charged. Try it out!

I only got this because it was cheap and I was relatively professional.

At first opening, I looked at the planes. NINE. No problem, I'll just go online and download some - nope, the only working ones are payware. I looked for a freeware Concorde - nope - $50. Alright, for fun I'll get the freeware Tupolev "Concordeski". Downloaded, moved to proper folder, X plane will not show it as a choice.
I put in 15 hours, that's enough. I won't get  a refund, I'm sure, but I am definitely deleting this sim and never opening again.

[h1]My last review:[/h1]
As of the time of this review, I currently hold a License for Private ASEL, and have a check ride schedule for my instrument rating.
X-plane 11 is great for simulating instrument flight and procedures. However I would recommend a beefy CPU. I have an i7-4790 that struggles to compute the sim fast enough to match the frame rate my GTX 1080 provides.
Easy support for 3 monitors, to be able to look left or right.
The new microsoft flight will have to be pretty good to top this.

[h1]Now:[/h1]
I'm now type rated in the Airbus A320, and start flying for an airline next week. This sim I have used to stay current at my flight school. Compared to microsoft flight sim, it seems to run a bit better and provide more consistent results. MSFS however is better for cockpit procedures.

"If you can walk away from a landing, it’s a good landing. If you use the airplane the next day, it’s an outstanding landing."

Chuck Yeager definitely never knew me.

I know next to nothing about flying, but have always been curious. So I figured a sim would be a good start. From what I read, the X-Plane series is more accurate than the Microsoft Flight Simulator series, and that is what I prefer. Since this one was $10 at the time, and I read 12 needs a much better system to run...to be safe I went with 11. My biggest worry was if there would be tutorials to teach me the basics....which thankfully there are.

In my hour of playing, I have learned:

1. How to take off and remain steady in a small propeller plane.
2. How to take off in an old crop duster with a back wheel...by driving all over the grass and almost running into everything.
3. How to land......three runways to the left of where I should have stopped.
4. How to take off in a 737 with the whole panel beeping at me.
5. That I should never fly a 747 in my life. And...ironically....that a 747 can in fact do barrel rolls and fly inverted, even when the pilot doesn't mean to.

For anyone that is not a pilot or has never flown before, I give you this warning: the tasks in the game are difficult and easy to do at the same time. The flight school gives a good walkthrough how to handle landing, flying, and taking off.....but it is still going to be difficult to master. But it is worth it. Just put a little time into it each day or week, and it will be a rewarding experience.

I can't say the same for my passengers on the 747. They hung in there well as we spun and flipped for a good 10 minutes before running upside down along the ground. I just hope they got a refund for their ticket....

...and that we had enough barf bags during that 15 min ordeal of a flight.

I recently had the privilege of experiencing the awe-inspiring world of flight through X-Plane 11, and I can confidently say that it has set an unparalleled standard in realistic flight simulation. This outstanding simulation game is nothing short of a masterpiece, and I am excited to share my exhilarating journey through the skies with you.

From the moment you take your seat in the virtual cockpit, you'll be struck by the jaw-dropping attention to detail. The aircraft models are nothing short of remarkable, with their meticulously recreated instrument panels, functioning controls, and authentic physics. Whether you're piloting a small Cessna or a mighty Boeing 747, you'll feel as though you're truly in command of a real aircraft.

But what truly sets X-Plane 11 apart is its world-building prowess. The developers have harnessed the power of cutting-edge technology to create an awe-inspiring, realistic world that extends as far as the eye can see. The level of detail in the landscape is staggering, with faithfully modeled cities, rolling landscapes, and realistic weather conditions that can challenge even the most seasoned virtual pilots. Flying through a storm at sunset is an experience you won't soon forget.

X-Plane 11 goes to great lengths to ensure the accuracy of its global terrain. This means that you can take off and land at virtually any airport on the planet, and they'll all be represented with striking fidelity. If you've ever dreamt of flying over your hometown, or exploring the exotic landscapes of far-off destinations, X-Plane 11 will make those dreams come true.

The realism doesn't stop at the graphics and physics; the audio in X-Plane 11 is equally impressive. The roar of engines, the whistling wind, and the radio chatter of air traffic control all contribute to the immersive experience. It's a true symphony of sound that enhances the simulation's authenticity.

One of the game's standout features is the comprehensive selection of aircraft, which ranges from light, single-engine planes to heavy commercial jets. Whether you're a novice pilot or a seasoned aviator, you'll find a suitable challenge in the wide variety of aircraft available.

Additionally, the flight modeling in X-Plane 11 is nothing short of groundbreaking. The simulator's use of blade-element theory ensures that every flight feels unique, with factors like weight, balance, and environmental conditions accurately affecting the aircraft's performance. This attention to detail creates an incredibly satisfying sense of realism.

The community behind X-Plane 11 is passionate and engaged, and they have developed a vast library of add-ons and mods that further enhance the experience. You can customize your simulator with new aircraft, improved graphics, and even more accurate navigation data, ensuring that X-Plane 11 can evolve with your interests and skill level.

In conclusion, X-Plane 11 is a monumental achievement in the world of flight simulation. It doesn't merely allow you to play at flying; it enables you to experience the joys and challenges of aviation in an entirely authentic way. Whether you're a budding pilot, a dedicated enthusiast, or just someone looking for an extraordinary and immersive gaming experience, X-Plane 11 will take you to new heights. It's not just a game; it's a breathtaking adventure through the skies. Strap in, and prepare for takeoff - your journey with X-Plane 11 awaits.Highly Recommend!

Notice - this title was superseded by X-Plane 12, and I recommend the successor over this.

In the expansive sky of flight simulation games, X-Plane 11 stood out as a hallmark of realism, complexity, and technological prowess. Developed and published by Laminar Research, this simulator was more than a game; it was a comprehensive digital aviation experience. From hobbyists to professional pilots, X-Plane 11 offered something for everyone who has ever wanted to defy gravity. Here's a detailed look at what made X-Plane 11 a premier choice for aviation enthusiasts.

Visually, X-Plane 11 was a marvel. Upon launching, players were greeted with exquisitely detailed aircraft models set against dynamically stunning backdrops. The global scenery, which included meticulously crafted landscapes, roads, and city structures, was a testament to the game's commitment to realism. The simulator's lighting, reflections, and shadows pushed the graphical fidelity to impressive heights, although enjoying these at the highest settings required a powerful PC setup.

At its core, X-Plane 11 excelled due to its authentic flight dynamics. It employed a unique aerodynamic model known as blade element theory, which simulated the airflow over aircraft components in real-time. This attention to detail created an environment where aircraft responded to various conditions with an accuracy that mirrored real life. Whether players were controlling a light aircraft or a heavy commercial jet, the responsiveness and feel were nothing short of authentic.

The base game provided a substantial fleet of aircraft, spanning from simple single-engine planes to complex jets. Each craft was designed with incredible attention to detail, offering players a wide range of flight experiences. The modding community further enriched this diversity, with countless third-party add-ons available, though the most intricately detailed ones often were not free.

The dynamic weather system was another highlight of X-Plane 11. Players had the option to manipulate weather conditions, choosing from presets or customizing their own atmospheric setups. The weather's impact on flight, combined with visually striking storm effects, cloud formations, and accurate wind patterns, added multiple layers of challenge and immersion.

One critical consideration for potential users was X-Plane 11’s intensive system requirements. Running this simulator with all features and high graphical settings necessitated a high-end PC. Players needed to ensure their systems were adequately equipped - at least an Intel Core i7 6770 or AMD equivalent and a fairly beefy GPU with 4GB VRAM.

X-Plane 11 was an all-encompassing flight simulation platform. Its sophisticated flight model, top-tier graphics, and realistic features set it apart in the genre. While the learning curve was steep for beginners, and the system requirements were demanding, the rewards for aviation enthusiasts were unmatched. For those who were in pursuit of a pilot's licence or those who simply adored the complexities (and rewards!) of flight, X-Plane 11 was an unrivaled journey through the skies.

After nearly 80 hours in X-Plane 11, I can happily say that it's not worth it in 2023, and theres more to it than the existence of MFS2020, however I will be mentioning it in this review

You may be wondering how many hours I've actually FLOWN in X-Plane 11, and I can happily say it's only around 20 hours. The rest? The painful setup of addons, primarily the scenery where you have to manually set up layers because Laminar wasn't smart enough to code it correctly on their end. Many of the payware sceneries are also expensive, and good luck making sure all 20 libraries needed for one scenery are installed and layered correctly. Don't even get me started with Ortho4XP, and other ways to install scenery tiles. 

Speaking of add-ons, the out-of-the-box experience is so underwhelming and small that it's literally required to install third party add-ons such as the Zibo 737-800X (which is actually amazing - great job Zibo!), and 20 plug-ins (conservative estimate). When the first tips you get when asking for advice from seasoned X-Plane users involves installing a metric ton of add-ons, you know something went wrong at Laminar Research. On top of this, the majority of quality aircraft (even in the middle-of-the-market in complexity) are egregiously expensive. For example, the Boeing 737-300 from IXEG & X-Aviation, which cant (from my experience) even do a hold at a waypoint and is just converted from the ancient X-Plane 10, is $70. $70!!! While this isn't necessarily Laminar's fault, it is something to note if you wish to use X-Plane 11. 

Don't even get me started with the aforementioned plug-ins. Want live weather that isn't just local METARs taped together? Here, spend $40-$70 on a weather engine (that Laminar could have added as default during X-Plane 11's development cycle!)

Once all of these add-ons are installed, you'll have to pray that the coding equivalent of (now wet with all of the installations you just made) duct-tape that seemingly holds X-Plane 11 together (after 11 iterations worth of code (?)) works, and that your hard drive isn't more stuffed than you after a dinner at Grandma's. Sometimes it does. Sometimes it doesn't. Such is the motto of the grand scheme of life, I guess.

However, there are a few pros:
1. There is a massive selection of add-ons and third party aircraft to choose from
2. The aircraft feel great. Personally, not enough to create the cult following that Laminar's flight model gets, but they do feel great. 
3. UI is very easy to navigate, and controls are easy to set up.
4. Good performance
5. Pretty good graphics, however Laminar might have wanted to re-check how shadows worked before launching back in 2016 - only your aircraft has shadows!

Now, for my real X-Planers out there, you've probably noticed that I have nearly 1100 hours in Microsoft Flight Simulator, and are now working to doxx me, kidnap me, and sacrifice me to The Great Austin Meyer. Yes, I'm not lying when I say that a couple dozen of those were used to set up and whatnot, but it didn't make me feel like I was speedrunning a migraine, and it made me feel like I was using a piece of software that wasn't created during the Crustacean Era. 

X-Plane 12, you say? What's that? Oh yeah... that exists... I guess. Anyway! Main point being, X-Plane 11 is no longer the industry standard. Even though its $30 more (and it's own issues), MFS2020 is a much less frustrating experience, with much more to offer out-of-the-box. However, if you've already poured a decent fraction of the US Defense budget and your lifetime into getting X-Plane perfectly calibrated for your experience, all power to you. 

See y'all in the skies, Captains!

2021 REVIEW UPDATE
------------------------------------------------

X-plane 11 has charm, some great planes and even combat but with the release of Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020, it's extremely difficult to recommend X-plane as a serious simulator---that is until the graphics and ATC catch up.
_____________________________________________________________________

Previous review updates

This review is based off of my steam purchase of X-plane 11 with a Steam sale.  Most of the details I have included are for new users to X-plane.   

REVIEW UPDATED FOR X-PLANE VER 11.30


SOME HIGHLIGHTS/POSITIVES ABOUT X-PLANE 11


User Interface (UI): 

Pleasing to the eyes.  The UI in X-plane 11 has been given a complete and welcome overhaul from past versions of the sim. Old and new users will find the settings easier to navigate and understand. Whether configuring a joystick, flight yoke or tweaking the sim’s graphics, the simple sliders, added search function and visuals make configuring X-plane 11 to your liking fun and intelligent. 

Lighting: 

Impressive, bright and vibrant. The lighting in X-plane 11 is simply amazing and in my opinion, more realistic than ever.  Lighting is vastly brighter (and more realistic IMO) than previous versions of X-Plane ever were.  There is a noticeable haze which is somewhat adjustable under weather visual settings and for me it enhances this sim.

Sound:

Generally good quality. Aside from the ATC audio, general environment and aircraft sounds are quite realistic and pleasing.  Audio for default X-plane 11 aircraft is generally acceptable.  Aircraft audio will depend on the original quality of aircraft you download or pay for.  (Payware aircraft tend to be more realistic both visually and sound-wise)

Clouds: 

Clouds appear to be softer and whiter in X-plane 11 but my FPS did take at least a 10 point frame rate drop when flying in heavier fog/cloud layers unless you use a FlyWithLua shadow/cloud plugin which can help to improve frame-rates.


Graphics/Autogen: 

Default textures for terrain, buildings, road-networks, airports etc. look fantastic in X-plane 11.    Days (and nights) are more realistic  than ever in X-plane 11.
 HDR lighting makes street lights, runways, and aircraft lighting look real.   With a decent graphics card (the more memory the better)  visual settings and lights will look great in your sim.  New partlicle system implemented in 11.30 helps improve clouds and exhaust effects.

Combat mode and Scenerios:
 
X-plane 11 includes a combat mode which allows your aircraft to engage in combat with other AI air traffic.  Pretty cool!  Various scenerios such as glider tow, mid-air refueling, carrier take-off/landing, and space shuttle re-entry and landing are included.

Addons, Plugins and Tweaking

If you like tweaking,  modding and using addons/plugins you will love X-plane 11 because adding custom content is a breeze in X-plane 11 and will enhance your sim.   (The FlyWithLua plugin is a good example)

 

SOME NOTE-WORTHY CONS ABOUT X-PLANE 11

 
User Interface (UI): 

If your are coming from X-plane 10 or even 9 you may miss the additional options for rendering that were available in those versions of X-plane.  X-plane 11 has simplified the User Interface which is great but I do wish there was an Advanced Option built-in for tweaking indiviual settings such as traffic levels, roads, boats, etc. 

Sounds: 

ATC in X-plane 11 has been apparently updated in ver 11.30 to be more realistic than in previous versions of X-plane but I wouldn’t know because I haven’t tried it yet.  I find the synthesized voices (also upgraded) that are used completely unbearable to listen to.  

Steering/ Controls: 

It might be just me, but I find the steering/rudder controls of the default Cessna 172 and helicopter erratic and somewhat difficult to control on take-off especially when using the Saitek flight yoke. The Cessna 172 continues to want to roll right even when trim is set.  New users,  especially users coming from FSX may have some difficulty at first getting things just right. 

Clouds:

While generally clouds and fog in X-plane 11 are good we know they could be improved visually in terms of their shape, definition and overall appearance.  Thunderheads and storm clouds should appear like tall menacing thunderheads (cumulus cloud) rather than layers of stratus.  Contrails appear to have been improved in ver 11.30. 

*Note about X-plane's default airports (for new users):

Some default airports in X-plane 11 will not include buildings but updated airports which do include buildings, hangers and terminals are always being added to X-plane via updates.   

CONCLUSION 

Try the X-plane 11 Demo first.  See how it runs on your computer system.  
If you enjoy flight simulators such as FSX or PrePar3d, I highly recommend X-plane 11 especially if you can get it on a steam sale.

X-Plane 11 presents a breathtaking world of aviation, with stunningly realistic visuals that capture the essence of flight. However, beneath the surface of its beauty lies a user experience that often falls short of expectations. Navigating menus and settings can be needlessly convoluted, leaving me frustrated and spending more time wrestling with options than actually flying. The challenge of setting up profiles and controls adds an unnecessary layer of complexity, making what should be an immersive experience feel like a technical obstacle course. While the skies may be gorgeous, X-Plane 11's user interface and profile setup are anything but smooth sailing.

On 10 April 2010, a Tupolev Tu-154 aircraft operating Polish Air Force Flight 101 crashed near the Russian city of Smolensk, killing all 96 people on board. Among the victims were the president of Poland, Lech Kaczyński, and his wife, Maria, the former president of Poland in exile, Ryszard Kaczorowski, the chief of the Polish General Staff and other senior Polish military officers, the president of the National Bank of Poland, Polish Government officials, 18 members of the Polish Parliament, senior members of the Polish clergy, and relatives of victims of the Katyn massacre. The group was arriving from Warsaw to attend an event commemorating the 70th anniversary of the massacre, which took place not far from Smolensk.

X-Plane 11 is an absolute gem in the world of flight simulation. As a passionate aviation enthusiast, I have spent countless hours exploring the virtual skies, and X-Plane 11 has blown me away with its unmatched realism and attention to detail.

The flight physics in this simulator are mind-blowing. Every control input, environmental factor, and aerodynamic effect is accurately simulated, providing a truly authentic flying experience. Whether it's battling crosswinds during a challenging approach or feeling the effects of turbulence, X-Plane 11 delivers a level of realism that is unparalleled.

The level of detail in X-Plane 11 is nothing short of astonishing. The meticulously crafted aircraft models are a sight to behold, with stunning exterior and interior visuals. Every button, switch, and gauge is faithfully reproduced, allowing you to fully immerse yourself in the cockpit environment. The world itself is equally impressive, featuring a vast and beautifully rendered global terrain with breathtaking landscapes that add to the overall immersion. The dynamic lighting effects and realistic weather systems further enhance the visual experience, making each flight a visual feast.

One of the standout features of X-Plane 11 is the extensive selection of aircraft. From commercial airliners to small propeller planes and even helicopters, the simulator offers a wide range of options to suit any aviation enthusiast's taste. Each aircraft is unique, with its own flight characteristics and systems, adding depth and variety to your virtual flying adventures.

The X-Plane 11 community is thriving and passionate. With an active user base and dedicated developers, the simulator benefits from a wealth of high-quality add-ons available through the online marketplace. Whether you're looking to enhance your aircraft collection, add detailed scenery, or incorporate additional features through plugins, the vibrant modding scene has you covered. The possibilities for customization and expanding the simulator's capabilities are truly endless.

The user interface of X-Plane 11 is user-friendly and intuitive, making it accessible for both newcomers and experienced simmers. The comprehensive tutorials and documentation provided ensure that you can quickly get up to speed and start enjoying the simulator right away. The developers' commitment to regular updates and improvements further solidifies X-Plane 11 as a top-tier flight simulator on Steam.

In summary, X-Plane 11 is a masterpiece that sets the bar high for flight simulation games. Its unmatched realism, attention to detail, and extensive selection of aircraft make it a must-have for any aviation enthusiast. Whether you're an experienced pilot or someone who has always dreamed of flying, X-Plane 11 will provide you with an awe-inspiring, immersive, and true-to-life flight experience that will leave you wanting more. Strap yourself in, take to the skies, and prepare for an unforgettable journey with X-Plane 11 on Steam.

Play MSFS if you are a VFR pilot. I am an IRL pilot and the physics for GA aircraft are considerably better than X plane's. Not to mention, you don't need to spend thousands upon thousands just to get decent scenery.

Look, I get it, making areas look realistic is hard. FSX looks rough and even vanilla MSFS gets many cities wrong. But to not even try is next-level stuff. I tried flying out of KSMO and was genuinely at a loss for words at how the game rendered LA - LITERAL SEASIDE FARMLAND. Like ??? I can't even come up with a way to describe how disappointed I was. No buildings, no houses - even FSX at the very least tries to emulate LA and it gets the job done. When you purchase a game and the fanbase's next tip is to literally buy scenery, or install a convoluted (but FREE!!!) scenery mod that delves into the game's files and really makes you think the creators should've done it, something is very wrong.

'Play MFSF if you're in it for the scenery' - I'm sorry but no. What a lame attempt at defending the devs. I shouldn't have to sacrifice scenery, something QUITE LITERALLY imperative to flying, for the sake of 'oh, the Cessna flies just slightly better than Micropoop's model.' I mean, the planes here look great and the interiors are fine and all, but am I supposed to just close my eyes and pretend LA or SF or whatever city I'm flying over is simply there? Say what you will about Microsoft and their greed, but at the very least, you can fly over your home base and actually recognize it, without ever needing to purchase or even download freeware airports. 

Even at half-off, I feel like I was shafted.

Of course, the obvious comparison is between X-Plane and MS Flight Simulator.  To me, the comparison is simple.  The graphics quality of MSFS and accuracy of the terrain are unquestionably superior.  And, MSFS is much more "playable" as a game.  But, X-Plane is just much closer to real flight, in terms of the flight model and aircraft handling.

If you want an accurate simulation, X-Plane is the clear choice.  MSFS "can" be tuned to approach the realism in X-Plane, but even then is just a little bit off.  Not sure how to describe it - it's just maybe too game-like ... too forgiving?

But, this isn't an MSFS review.  It's just hard to talk about X-Plane without mentioning MSFS.

X-Plane is pretty much infinitely configurable, since you can make your own aircraft or terrain or get customized content from the community.  If that appeals to you, the community is very active and the sky's the limit.  As for me, I mostly fly stock aircraft over stock terrain.  I have found the handling pretty much spot-on for the aircraft I have flown.  It is not a replacement for actual flight time, but it definitely makes me a better pilot with skills and habits that translate to the cockpit.

Could you teach yourself to fly a real airplane by using X-Plane only?  No ... not with a desktop setup.  The software itself will not teach you what you need to know.  But, if you are learning to fly or are already a pilot, the practice you can gain is invaluable.  In some ways, it is better than actual cockpit experience, in that you can experiment a bit, pay more attention to instruments, etc.  In short, since you don't need to worry about endangering yourself or others, you can really hone specific skills in a way that is more difficult in real-world conditions.

There are really only a few disappointments, to me.

First, the terrain is technically accurate, but not terribly detailed.  That is, airports, navaids, etc. are where they should be, with runways, taxiways, towers, etc. all matching real life.  Likewise, major terrain features are as close to accurate as necessary to really matter.  The only deficit, though, is that the terrain is sort of roughed in, making it hard to navigate by specific landmarks.  For example, you can usually find and follow something like an interstate freeway, but don't expect anything smaller to be accurate or even present.  Similarly, rivers, streams, lakes, and shorelines are usually on the map, but with pretty low fidelity.

In short, it is difficult to use it for VFR navigation in an area you might be familiar with.  For example, I used to fly in Colorado Springs and used a school bus garage as a landmark for navigating the traffic pattern.  In X-Plane, there is an area that looks vaguely light-industrial, but no details that give any clue as to where that garage might be.

Second, radio communication is ... OK ... ish.  One thing I wish I could get from a simulator is good and accurate practice on the radio.  Communicating with ATC and other services, accurately recording and applying the information received, and managing frequency changes  - all while flying the airplane, potentially under difficult conditions - that takes some practice.  I would say that ATC communication in X-Plane is more of an annoyance than it is valuable practice.  As a feature in the software, it is slightly better than nothing.

Hand-in-hand with this, AI traffic is not realistic either.  There are other aircraft flying about.  You may occasionally see them, you will hear them on the radio, and you can see them on your map view.  But, they don't really fly in any way that makes sense.  They just sort of show up, fly for a little while, then disappear.  Not a big deal, but it would be valuable to, for example, encounter other aircraft in the traffic pattern and/or using the runway(s) that you are wanting to use.  I have flown several times into SeaTac airport (in X-Plane), and have never encountered another airplane.  (That just NEVER occurs in real life.  In reality, you not only have to contend with busy traffic, you need to pay attention to things like wake turbulence.)

Overall, I would say that X-Plane:
- Is a good way to get a pretty accurate simulation. Probably the best available to most consumers.
- Is not a game and probably won't appeal, as such, to someone looking for that.
- Is accurate where it matters, but lacks some refinement that might make it more visually appealing.
- Will make you a better pilot, in particular, in using your instruments effectively.

This simulator is much, much better than the Microsoft Flight Simulator I used in the '80's.  I had asked my dad's friend if you could learn how to fly by using a simulator back then and he frowned on it, if I recollect rightly.  I feel you can learn how to fly using this one, however. As an aviation enthusiast, I have to say that X-Plane 11 is hands down the best flight simulator out there. The attention to detail in every aspect of the game is simply amazing. From the realistic flight physics to the stunning graphics, X-Plane 11 truly immerses you in the world of aviation. The vast range of aircraft and airports available is impressive, and the ability to customize and create your own planes and scenery adds even more depth to the game. The user interface is intuitive and easy to navigate, making it accessible for both beginners and experienced simmers alike. The community support is also fantastic, with a wealth of resources and add-ons available to enhance your experience. Overall, X-Plane 11 is a must-have for any aviation enthusiast or anyone looking for an incredibly realistic flight simulator. Highly recommended!

A great flight sim for novices (like myself). Comes with a handy flight school mode to teach you the basics (so you don't crashe) and a plethora of different aircraft to fly (my personal faves being the general aviation stuff). Those dlc prices may deter you but if you are a true blue aussie (me) and are only looking to fly around in the oceanic/asian region than you will find that only some of the paid dlc might be nice-to-haves (though not necessary at all, I only have the base maps for all regions which are free and am getting along just fine).

p.s. if you have no clue on using plane gps systems than fear not, install the Avitab plugin to get a virtual tablet with a more familiar map system to guide you on your flights: https://github.com/fpw/avitab it's what I use and it gets the job done nicely.

p.p.s. while this game is way less resource intensive than xp12 or msfs2020, make sure you have a decent cpu, this game is heavily reliant upon it. For example, I get 45-75fps using a ryzen 5 2600 and a gtx 1650 super, whenin the graphics options I can crank up every gpu intensive visual effect but I have to set the reflection detail to low to make some more headroom for the cpu. 

Basically, don't be afraid to crank up those texture qaulity, visual effects and AA settings to the max if you have a gpu on par with mine or higher, but be weary of number of world objects and reflection detail settings on a cpu on par with mine.

X-Plane 11 is a truly outstanding flight simulation game that provides an incredibly realistic flying experience. As a virtual pilot, I am thoroughly impressed with the attention to detail that has been put into every aspect of the game, from the aircraft models and cockpits to the weather and terrain.

The graphics in X-Plane 11 are stunning, and the scenery is incredibly lifelike, making it easy to lose yourself in the world of aviation. The planes are meticulously modeled, and the physics engine ensures that the flight experience is as realistic as possible. It's also great to have such a wide range of aircraft to choose from, allowing me to fly everything from a small single-engine propeller plane to a jumbo jet.

One of the standout features of X-Plane 11 is the level of customization available to players. The game's powerful SDK allows players to create and share their own aircraft, airports, and other features, which adds an incredible amount of depth and variety to the game.

Another fantastic aspect of X-Plane 11 is the community that surrounds it. There are countless resources available online, from tutorials to add-ons and mods, and the community is incredibly welcoming and helpful.

Overall, I would highly recommend X-Plane 11 to anyone who is interested in aviation, whether you're a seasoned pilot or just starting out. It's a fantastic game that offers an unparalleled level of realism and customization, and it's a joy to play every time I sit down at the controls.

WOW WOW WOW WOW WOW. AMAZING. Bought the base game and flew a small 2 seater prop, F4 Phantom (my dream finally came true!!!!) , SR71 Blackbird, and Boeing 747-400. WOW....WOW WOW WOW WOW.
SOOOOOOO REALISTIC. (I am not a pilot but have been in passenger jets often). Still learning all the buttons and how to actually use ILS and glide slope, etc but so far I would say this is IDEAL FOR NOVICE TO INTERMEDIATE FLIGHT SIM ENTHUSIASTS  AND MAYBE PILOTS TOO BECAUSE IT FEELS SO RIGHT). Graphics in cockpit are quite beautiful, scenery is OK. I have watched hundreds of hours of historical and documentary shows about flying from WW1 to present day and also about passenger aircraft and I will eventually try to test the physics and limitations of the aircraft to see how accurate it really is but so far everything seems normal. I forced my F4 into a stall but couldn't recover. I will have to research, re test pilot the maneuvre and see what happens. But overall flying physics seem very accurate. If they could ever turn this into a combat simulator for exampe F4 Phantom vs MIG 21 (imagine being able to get enemy call outs from Red Crown in the Gulf of Tonkin (with all due respect to Vietnam War pilots....I hope I got that right)  and having your RIO tell you he's broken out the bandits from the ground clutter and letting off a couple of missiles and watching the plumes track to target.....getting goose bumps just thinking about it) or P51 Mustang vs FW-190 it would be incredible.  Oh ans I almost forgot......you can make gorgeous screen shots with it which make beautiful desktop backgrounds. Already have a fav ..... F4 Phantom of course.

Performance is commendable, and the graphics are similarly admirable.FSX proved to be a source of vexation for me In the busiest of airports. Flight dynamics far surpass those of both FSX and Prepar3d. Add-on software come with a steep price tag: You will be charged $30 just to walk around/inspect your aircraft, which to me adds into realism. ATC, in comparison to FSX, is incredibly difficult to operate smoothly, as if a rocket-science. Essential to note, that keyboard flying is not supported. It took me nearly an hour to calibrate my LOGITECH G Extreme 3D Pro Joystick. Pros aside, what I loathe the most is the inability to assign a key lets say to reverse thrust initiation. The sole options are "yes" or "no." FSX, as well as FS2000, had superior keyboard dynamics.Nevertheless, I highly recommend it, especially for low-spec PCs.

When I first got XP11, my review was terrible.

Since then, a few things have changed:
For one, XP12 came out, which somehow made XP11 look better. 11 did end up getting some very helpful updates throughout its life though, including much better airport scenery (even if they're a lot overzealous on the static models). The G1000s got very smoothed out and almost operate like the real deal. 

Of course, several things are still (and will remain) broken.  Icing effects are pretty wild and the rules for icing are very aggressive.  I've literally come home from a great day of flying at my home airfield only to load X-Plane at the same airport using current weather and have my C172 so iced up it will barely taxi. Taildraggers are still just straight up broken.

You're also going to just not use any of the ATC or AI aircraft.  AI planes suck framerate as if you're loading multiple full scale models into the sim, because that's what you're doing. Stock ATC isn't even worth the effort, while the best of the third party ATC plugins is marginal at best and just loves vectoring you into downwind landings even when ASOS is reporting the opposite runway active. Bonus points if it routes you into a mountain while vectoring you through a nonexistent instrument approach. So get used to flying alone and only using the radios for navigation and weather. It's a more peaceful existence anyway.

Oh, and the game just LOVES to load copious amounts of randomly generated points of interest for you.  Be prepared to encounter sailing boats in the Arctic Ocean and 3000 different Nimitz class aircraft carriers along your route. If you get bored of shooting limitless carrier approaches on your transoceanic adventures, you can always set down on one of the 500,000 offshore oil platforms that can be found anywhere there is water. I mean, really, I appreciate adding things to do, but let's keep things somewhat accurate.

And of course, there are too few stock aircraft and they vary wildly in quality, as many of the models were developed for previous versions and have been updated only to varying degrees over the iterations of this sim.  Oh, and you want the "nav data out of date" warning to go away on your navigation systems? That's a third party subscription service.

But, all that said, X-Plane 11 still has pretty decent visuals, good flight models and has been a great tool for flight training. It's riddled with flaws, but it's still the version to have, at least as long as 12 keeps bogging down framerates.

So no one gets confused and think my comments are one sided, I have both XPlane 11 and the latest flight sim from Microsoft. Unlike many who are relative newcomers to the flightsim world, I've been playing Microsoft flight since 1988 with it was a crappy 6 color game with only the Cessna or learjet 45 to choose from. I still have every "original" copy of every version of Microsoft flight sim I've bought since 88. To say that I'm a flightsim vet is the understatement of the decades. With that said, Microsoft should be ashamed to let anyone come in the market and outshine them in any way with flight simulator games and that is exactly what X Plane did. 

I don't know what happened with Microsoft Flightsim team, but there was a large gap between flight sim releases, and there was an even longer time when the "new" release didn't really bring anything new to the game. The developers of X Plane timing was exceptional and they dominated the market during that time. I've enjoyed playing the game and running sorties everywhere. The airplane details are excellent, the graphics on a whole is excellent, the availability of the game is exceptional being on Windows, Mac and Linux. Not many games can make that claim, but X Plane developers are on top of their game. I tip my hat in great respect to that achievement... All three major platforms!... WOW! Microsoft has only been available on Windows :-( 

Downside. There are two downside to X-Plane, and the only reason those downside now exist is because of FS2020. On the release of FS2020 we saw for the first time photo-realistic clouds, and real-world terrain generation. Those two groundbreaking achievements made me see X-Plane through a different lens. Don't get me wrong, I still play X-Plane once a while, but I'm awestruck with the terrain and weather system if FS2020. Also, the ATC communication feels a little more real than in previous generations. 

Seriously, it wasn't until release of FS2020 (and several subsequent bug fixes and updates) that Microsoft Flight sim got my attention again. As soon as X-Plane update to match or exceed FS2020 terrain and weather, myself and many other will like be onboard again more often.

I once wrote a review on FSX:SE. I recommended it because of its relatively cheap pricetag, and the "modding" opportunities...

Then i bought X-Plane 11...
I have been so close to buying this game multiple times, but decided not to because of the price.
Got 34% off on Steam Winter Sale 2017 and oooh boy. If this game is not amazing, i dont know what is!

By far THE BEST flight sim on the market (without addons). Compared to FSX it wins almost everywhere. The only place this game lacks is the amount of aircrafts (and atc funcionality, but who uses that..), but then again, look at the detail! Almost every function in every aircraft included is simulated. The FSX Default planes dont even have an FMC/FMS.
With X-Plane you get a ton off free addons avalible and easy to install from www.forums.x-plane.org/
You get amazing default scenery.
You get a flight sim without the need for addons! (Which is unheard of in the flight sim community)
It has a bit of learning curve, but watch some tutorials on Youtube, and you will be good to go in no time.

If you think the game is a little expensive, i completely understand. Wait untill the next big sale. I got mine for 42 euros, which was an absolute steal!

I 110% recommend this game for every aviation enthusiast, "veteran" flight simmers ans those who are just getting started!

2023 UPDATE:
Even after the release of Microsoft Flight Simulator, this is still my choice of sim. While it doesn't quite look as good as MSFS, the flying is at least on par with it. If you, like myself, have bought a good handful of addons for X-Plane I would find it unreasonable to change to MSFS anytime soon. On my system MSFS doesn't run nearly as good as X-Plane. And from what I've heard, X-Plane physics are more realistic, but I'm no pilot so wouldn't know. Still a recommend!

I picked up X-Plane 11 after playing Microsoft Flight Simulator 40th Anniversary on Xbox GamePass for a few days and wanting to have the ability to play a flight sim at my desk when the kids were hogging the living room TV, or on-the-go with my Steam Deck. That last part is very important because while I may have an Xbox, I'm a Linux gamer and have been for years, so want to invest in games that can run natively on Linux. So far, I am very impressed. The performance on the Steam Deck is great, everything set to medium save for reflections, shadows, and world objects results in a solid 60FPS on that hardware.

So far as the user interface goes, it's very basic, like Laminar Research is saying "We care more for the simulation than the user interface." Then I hopped into the Cessna 172 Skyhawk with the "X1000" (Garmin G1000) avionics system and holy crap you can set up your entire flight plan within the cockpit without needing some fancy UI that doesn't present you with all of the options that system is actually capable of! I'm looking at you MSFS with your focus on additional UI elements rather than the tools the plane comes with. Laminar Research got it very right in this regard and what's more, just like with a real plane's avionics, they publish manuals so you can legit learn the way the various pilot handbooks available online will teach you to use the equipment. Now that's a sim!

I only have short amount of time in X-Plane 11 so far, but given that I can play it on my Steam Deck in hand-held mode (custom control schemes for the win!) or in Desktop mode with an extra monitor if I'm at my desk (thank you docking station!) it's quickly going to be my go-to time sink when I'm not in the mood for an RPG but want to "play a game".

I very much recommend this game for anyone wanting a credible flight sim that works in Linux and plays well on the Steam Deck, and is looking for the kind of immersion that doesn't require the fanciest of UIs to suck you in. X-Plane is unforgiving, but flying and messing with avionics feels like they should, and in a simulator, that's what matters.

This is a great option if you have a decent VR system with ample power to run most settings maxed out. I'm running this on an Alienware Aurora R9 Core(TM) i7-9700 CPU @ 3.00GHz on an SSD drive with Win 10 Pro 64 bit and an NVIDIA RTX 2070. I'm on an HP Reverb G2 WMR headset which offers a really nice and stable VR experience!

The only issue for me is the small selection of aircraft's offered by default but that was an easy fix with all the free addons available on the Internet. I've since added multiple helicopters and planes to further expand my aircraft options greatly enhancing my experience.

Before buying X-Plane 11, I downloaded the demo for both X-Plane 11 and 12 directly from their website but version 12 ran a bit sluggish on my system and I simply wasn't happy with the overall performance. I opted to buy X-plane 11 because it offered the perfect balance between scenery, expansion and performance. The 3D building models are well done even though it's not very accurate in terms of actual buildings that exist at your set locations. It's more arcade like when it comes to that but the flying is really good! It's very responsive and fun to fly, especially if you calibrate your hotas before flying.

I know many mention and compare MSFS 2020, AEROFLY FS 2 & 4 and X-PLANE often and since I own all three I have a better idea of what each has to offer. They all have their strong suit but for me, flying in X-Plane 11 is really enjoyable! It sits perfectly between MSFS 2020 and AEROFLY FS 2 & 4 where you get a bit of everything a flight game has to offer. X-Plane 11 is really responsive on my system and I truly feel a sense of speed which I don't really get from the other two. 

I'm not a sim fanatic or anything like that, I'm simply a gamer whom enjoys escapism via casual gaming. With that said, upgrading my video card may greatly improve my experience with other titles so it's not so much that the other flight sims are not good, it's just that this one runs the best on my system for entertainment purposes.

I think this is an excellent flight simulator, however this game is getting very old now that X-Plane 12 is out. Like, just buy that game instead and you'll pretty much get the same experience with newer and improved graphics  (Though, there might be a lot more bugs in that game right now since it just released a few days ago). Or, buy Microsoft flight simulator 2020 instead, if your PC can run it. One thing that I dislike about this game is the lack of good air traffic control (ATC) in the game. Like, even in FSX there was ATC and that game is ancient. Most of the time you will just be relying on your FMC to do everything for you in autopilot, and programming the FMC is very time consuming. But, besides those complaints, I don't really have anything else to say. X-Plane 11 is great, but I personally wouldn't buy it in 2022 unless my PC couldnt run other flight sims. The default planes also kinda suck but the Zibo mod 737 is free to download, to just download that instead of using the default 737.

Don’t really recommend unless you are ok with really low fps.  I run a 3080 and with 4 addons (1 plane, ground handling, lula etc.) my fps is 5-20 (on max setting).  5fps is when I land at night.  20fps is when Im in cockpit zoomed into instrument panel.   Flight dynamics are great!  Stock planes are really bad (unfinished, lots features not working and def. No where near to real planes). You have to buy plane add-ons to learn the real thing ( around $100 per plane but they are awesome).     Graphics are not great at all, you will def not recognize where you are if you fly visually so immersion is meh.   But when you buy an add-on plane for around $100 from a 3rd party developer (don’t cheap out big difference)  awesome flight because everything works how it should.     Watch real pilot reviews online they compare x-plane to msfs and review different planes and how they work compared to the ones they fly in real life.      Also stay away from x-plane.org (check “trustpilot” reviews, sometimes x-plane.org claims they work with and help develop x-plane but they did not they just took the name and added .org.   They will not issue refunds or help and are very very rude site owners, but your add ons from different store.  They also tried to steal my personal info.    

I don’t recommend game but all that being said I started with a Cessna and now fly Airbus with full out flight plans and know the systems and it is fun, The only reason I don’t recommend is it’s gotten to a point where there is no immersion for me because of bad fps, add-ons eat more fps, x-plane.org ruined x-plane for me and I’m making a switch to MSFS after watching many pilot reviews about the Fenix and FBW A32NX (free add on). 

MSFS you can try for $1 on x-box live store for 30days.

Also many add ons for x-plane are free if u look hard enough 

Any questions or if I can help add me and send me a msg. 

I have over 200h on x-plane on another account and again I run a 3080 Nvidia.  Always check real pilot reviews on a video service, each experience is different.

Thanks to Steam I am unable to give mixed ratings, so they let me no chance other than to vote this down.
In reality, I'd give it a 4 out of 10.

Positive:
**********
- (seems to be) quite realistic (at least according to the ratings of people who like it)
- once you (theoretically) master it, it might actually give you a good overall feeling for flying in reality

But... the major drawbacks:
*******************************
- VERY difficult learning curve! After 2 hrs of trying, I haven't even managed ONE landing yet (not even an ugly one)
- tutorials (the "Flight School") are horribly unintuitive: Any instructions pop in suddenly as modal text popups, brutally pausing the game flow, thus bringing you out of concentration (trying to read, then steer, then read again and so on). Why the h.... couldn't they create some less intrusive AUDIO instructions, making this a bit more immersive??
- ran into a couple of obvious bugs (audio not initializing properly, spontaneous game crashes, erratic handling of keyboard input), which caused tons of unnecessary plane crashes
- changing game settings is completely confusing for me, as someone who doesn't have any knowledge about flight terminology (the latter not being explained at all). E.g., I haven't found out yet whether I can steer with keyboard keys instead of my mouse (hoping that this at last would give me a slightly more stable steering control)
- UI and overall handling of the game appear quite outdated (old-style UI elements, lots of technical junk, tedious loading times for comparably mid-level graphics)

My conclusion:
*****************
I tried to play this game as a "flight newbie", hoping to get some first feeling (assuming that this is what flight simulator GAMES should be offering). But it turns out that this is not the case. It rather seems some real-world simulator has been quickly transformed into a game (to make money from it). For advanced-level players, this might be exactly what they need. Just be aware that it is not suited for beginners like me.
It's okay - not as good as MFS2020 though and 12 is out now (which is also good but inferior to MSF2020 in just about every way other than optimization for macs if that matters to you).

with mouse it is in the beginning pretty hard but alot of practice will help! it is kind of confusing how to select your routes still havent figured out how everything works but thats probally because of me. I do RECOMMEND the game! it is a lot of fun and not boring and learning new things about planes.

I bought X-Plane specifically because of its advertised VR support. I don't usually get motion sickness, in VR or IRL, but this game's VR support is so terrible I couldn't keep the headset on. Laminar reused the same camera animations from the desktop simulation, moving your viewpoint very quickly, tripping my brain up with unfelt but expected accelerations. But to make things much much worse, they also locked my viewpoint during these scenes! I've never felt vertigo like when I turned my head in this game and my view didn't change. I hope you like looking at your plane, because you literally can't look away!

I was able to tolerate this during the first tutorial flight, but when I loaded up the second, they spawned me in a taxiing Cesna with my view locked. The viewport was rocking back and forth with the Cesna, making it particularly bad. I should thank Laminar for this experience though, now I know what people have been complaining about when they talk about simulation sickness, so I'll be more empathetic to them.

Thanks Laminar Research!

Xplane > FSX > Microsoft Flight Game

XP11 is not a game. This is a serious flight simulator built, maintained, used and loved by aviators for aviators across the planet. A Labour of Love, if you will. Evidenced for example by the attention to detail of the flight model. Check out any of Austin's media content and you will immediately understand the ethos of XP11, and why, by any measure this simulator is an A-list success. Yes, since the release of MSFS2020 the playing field got more serious, but Laminar Research have never taken their eye off the ball and continue to drive forward to successfully compete with the big bucks hitter, Microsoft. The latest edition XP12 has just been released, for example. Yes, spend loads of time experiencing the beauty of the MSFS canvas and pique your interest for aviation, together with the hordes of platform gamers out there. But at some point, I can guarantee, when you want to get serious about aviation simulation. That is the time to invest in this superlative product, which you will always come back to.

I've been flying XP11 for years now and I still enjoy it as much, if not more than I did prior to MSFS 2020 releasing.  I love them both, I'm an ambassador for Flight SIM and no matter which SIM you choose, I'm all for it.  XP11 shines for IFR / Commercial flight operations.  I fly quite a bit of VFR as well, but 1600 hours IFR and counting.  I highly recommend XP11 and I'm holding out on XP12 until more support is available for 3rd party plugins and some of the bugs are ironed out.  I don't think of myself as a fanboy, and I do love the visuals in MSFS.  But theirs an appeal XP11 has over MSFS I can't explain very well.  This is my flavor of Flight SIM and I intend to continue enjoying it for years.

The tutorial is broken and that's a problem when it comes to a realistic sim game about flying a vehicle I have no business flying. Imagine going to flight school and your instructor doesn't show up but you're still expected to fly. Tutorial #1 you are thrown into the cockpit while in the air. No instructions are given but it doesn't take much to figure out how to control the plane and follow the flight guide. It's not the best tutorial but not a deal breaker...yet. Tutorial #2 is vomit inducing because its the only tutorial that makes your vr headset inverted. When you turn you head right the vr view goes left. I wasn't even in the air yet and wanted to puke. Tutorial# 3 once again throws you into the cockpit but you're grounded. No instructions and no text. If you've never flown a plane before good luck trying to figure out how to get it started. Only half the instruments that highlight green to indicate they're interactive actually work. Tutorial #4 you're in the air once again trying to learn how to land but the plane is frozen in time. There's a large green arrow on where to land but you're not moving. Once again no instructions and no text to guide you. Tutorial #5 is a mystery to me because I requested a refund before bothering. I know XPlane 12 is out but I'll spend that $ on MFS. If this game functioned I may have been interested in the sequel but I say good day XPlane. I say good day sir!

Firstly I would like to apologise for my bad England. 
Don't get me wrong, this game is OK, but there are some aspects that need improvement, considering its original price which around 60 dollars (RM169) (but now its cheaper RM51 since X-plane 12 about to be released). I also understand that this is more like a "simulation" than a "game", thus this is why I give it a thumbs down:

1- ATC
the atc sounds like robot, and its slow tempo. Its a shame that FSX, a flight sim thats released 10+ YEARS AGO, has better atc than this.

2- Ground Services and Jetway
for this price (RM169), I expected some working ground services and jetways. Guess what? there are only a few "living airports" that have ground service. Jetway are almost none, well I know you could buy dlc or even get freeware on the internet, but for this price i think they should add it into the game, no? And this is where FSX comes in, again. FSX is wayyy cheaper than this, and it has all of it.

3- DLCs and NavData

Just as I cross the 800 hours mark in X-Plane 11, the end of an era is approaching. Laminar dropped the price in half, and everyone is getting ready for the 12th version of the X-Plane series.

This review is not to list pros and cons, to praise on the good parts or to complain for the shortcomings. I want to leave this here as a testament in time, as a thank you to the software, the developers behind it, the pilots who flew and the amazing community with the myriad of freeware/payware add-ons from simple utilities to complex aircraft. All of you have contributed your bit to make my experience (and everyone's experience) a thing to remember. 

And for you future reader of this review, when you wonder around the page of X-Plane 11 in STEAM remember that a new and shinny cousin of this is already out and probably worth your time and money more but if you decide to purchase this sim personally neither I will judge you, nor I will try to stop you. You will not get the crispiest graphics, you will not get the most optimized performance, you will probably find default assets bland and uninspired but feel pride in having this sim installed in your hard drive, because once it was the best home flight simulator of all time, the king to reign them all.

[b]Farewell X-Plane 11 and thank you for all the hours of joy.[/b]

Starting off, X-Plane is not eye candy by any means. If you are looking for a flight sim that is built for VFR with landmarks, remarkable visuals, and a solid default weather system then I would suggest MSFS, not XP. But, if you are looking for good flight physics and want to escape the arcade feeling that MSFS can give you in some certain ways, then XP is right for you. The community is what makes XP worth it. The amount of freeware plugins, beautiful scenery such as ZeroDollarPayware makes the game worth it alone. When you buy this game, expect to spend more on plugins, aircraft and such. The aircraft that are available for XP might not be comparable to FSLabs, but some GA planes available such as the CL650 are out of this world detailed. It just boils down to what you are looking for. Overall, I love the game. As said previously, even though by all means it's not eye-candy, it still gives you the avgeek experience.

I was on this page reading reviews and it struck me that I haven't written one yet.  X-Plane 12 is on the horizon and I thought I should leave my thoughts on the sim here before it becomes out of date. 

For some background, I am a private pilot and I have around 150 hours of flight time.   Almost all my hours have been in the Cessna 172.  I've also flown the Cessna 182.  I think this experience has given me a good amount of understanding on how a plane should handle in the air. 

Flight simulation was actually what got me into aviation and inspired me to fly in real life.  I played flight simulators all throughout my childhood but I really got into it in 2015.   I was in high school and I would save up money for hardware.  I found three old Ipads and set them up to make a virtual cockpit.  Soon, I had a full home cockpit.  I was putting hundreds of hours on FSX with planes like the PMDG 737.  I loved the thought of being an airline pilot and it became my life's goal. 

In 2016 X-Plane 11 released in public beta.  I had never tried any X-Plane title and I decided to pick it up.  At first I really didn't love it.  I thought the flight model was spongy and it didn't feel as stiff as FSX.  The graphics were also a downgrade and the game did not run well on my PC.  (This was only really a beta problem, the game runs fine now).  I ended up going back to FSX for the time being. 

In 2017 I began flight training.  I was doing it on top of high school and at first I was only going every two weeks.  As I learned how to fly in real life, X-Plane became an excellent tool for learning.  In FSX, the default Cessna was not nearly as good as the X-Plane one.  This is really what pushed me to switch to X-Plane.  Before every real flight, I would completely replicate what we were going to go over in X-Plane.  I would follow checklist procedures and had my kneeboard on to write fake taxi instructions.  As I flew in real life, I began to realize how organic the flight model in X-Plane 11 felt.  The sponginess I felt was because there was no air resistance on the yoke or rudder pedals.  (I've come to learn this is an issue in every flight simulator).  Other than this, the flight model is superb and surpasses most other simulators on the market. 
 including Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020.  X-Plane 11 was with me every step of the way until my checkride in 2020. 

Nowadays, I only ever use X-Plane for VR procedure flights in big airliners.  The VR support in this game is the best of the best in the flight sim world.  Flight simulation has become more of a casual thing rather than a serious hobby.  The huge home cockpit I built is mostly dismantled as I never really have the drive to use it all anymore.  College has really changed my goals in life and I am no longer pursuing aviation as a career.  I still stay deeply connected to the aviation world and have made many friends through flying. 

Here's the bottom line, as much as people say X-Plane is only for the serious flight simmer, it isn't.  You can have tons of fun with this game.  Sure it's not too flashy without some addons but there is a ton of free content provided by the community that can make this game beautiful.  Even with being nearly 6 years old, it is much better than it's competition.  MSFS 2020 has been a major disappointment to me and I barely ever use it but that's a story for another day.  I know this has been a bit of a rambling review, but here's to the future of X-Plane as a series.  Soon this steam page will be an afterthought, but I just wanted to leave my two cents for everyone.

Let's just say this isn't an arcade game, this is a simulator and must be treated as such. If you are looking just to fly, look somewhere else.
Combined with Vatsim (or any other online platform - Ivao, etc.) you reach an environment as real as it gets to the real thing and from time to time you might find that real pilots will join you to maintain their good practice.
Don't try to compare it with other simulators, everyone of them has its highs and lows, and if someone tells you that this one or that one is best, they are biased. For me, if you want the best flight model and simulation, buy this one; if you are looking for the best visuals (aircraft and sceneries) buy MSFS.
Caution: addictive. Later on you might try to be an Air Traffic Controler..... And a word of advice: choose your addons carefully - read online reviews, Youtube -  (there are free very nice ones online) or you might end up paying a lot.

Honestly, I truly wanted to like X-Plane. The flight physics and cockpit detail are top-notch and and I love bargain deals for people who want to fly on IVAO without having to pay so much just to go with P3D. Laminar Research has come a long way and I can only wish the best for those guys, and I hope the guys from LR do not take this review personally as the negativity is not directed towards them.

The negativity is directed towards the add-on developers and the majority of the community members. Unfortunately, in order to make X-Plane viable for commercial flights, you'll need to install a lot of add-on's, and the one drawback of X-Plane is that it's not a stable platform that can support a lot of add-on's without crashing, and if an add-on plugin or aircraft fails? Well, good luck trying to get support on those, 'cause from my personal experience, I've only dealt with toxicity after toxicity from the X-Plane community. Those guys have a long-proud tradition of calling anyone they disagree with trolls, and then banning people from the Discord servers. Your mileage may vary of course, but from my standpoint, this is a major turnoff.

If that wasn't bad enough, unfortunately, aircraft choices are limited. Your only REAL choices in terms of aircraft are either the Zibo 737NG, ToLiss A320/A340 family or FlightFactor 767's. The 777 V2 and 787 are being developed by FlightFactor; however, considering the toxic community base, my advice to you is not to hold your breath as the community will refuse to help those who struggle with the aircraft addons even if they are caused by legitimate reasons.

So what alternatives are out there? Well, unfortunately, not much. P3D is overpriced and is extremely unstable in terms of the platform, and it's starting to lose support from its developers. MSFS2020 has poor aircraft physics (Like seriously, WHOSE IDEA WAS IT TO MAKE CHEESECAKES FLY IN MSFS2020?! DO THEY EVEN GET REALISM RIGHT?!) and it'll take months if not years before the available aircraft fleet in MSFS2020 will mature.

People once told me that "these are great times to be flying on flight sims." Well, at least in my case anyway, it turned out to be a load of BS. Don't give into that scam. I did, and wasted too much money in the process to the point where this year, that's already a disaster on its own, has been ruined further.

Yes, X-Plane 12 is coming out soon; however, if I were you, I'd have serious second thoughts about going into it considering the toxic community base. Ask yourself, is it really worth all the stress and toxicity just to be able to fly in a flight sim platform that has the best flight physics?

Very disappointing.
I've used sims before and have my own stick and peddles, so this isn't my first rodeo. I got this installed and called my young daughter over to show her the joy of flying. After calibrating the controls we loaded our first flight and saw... a view of the front seat from 1 cm away. That we couldn't change.

Okay, its cool, lets reload the flight.

"You can't! There is no option to restart in any of the visible menus!"

Okay, fine, we'll restart the program. Now, new flight, load and...

"You're controls are unresponsive! Also, throttle is set to drive you off the runway and crash!"

Okay, so when the plane is on fire, then the option to reset shows up. Great. Now, I already calibrated the controls, so I'll do it again.

"You can't calibrate the controls! Because reasons!"

... Okay FINE, reset the program AGAIN. Now, load program, calibrate joystick, load a mission... 

"Throttle response is normal! You're not looking at the ass of the seat from 1 cm away! Aren't you proud of our amazing software??!"

Fine, can we please take off now?

"No, because the controls are unresponsive to pitch! Here comes that wall again!"

My daughter giggling in the background as I grind my teeth. 

Yeah. Having software that does All The Things ever with Amazing Graphics is cool and all, but if your flight sim turns into a go-cart simulator because the controls are ass backwards and you spend half your 'flights' with your head wedged between the seat cushions, maybe fix that first? This feels like an Alpha build, nevermind anything more polished. 

Other reviews generally proport good things, so I imagine I'll probably get the software to do the job it's built to EVENTUALLY,  but just understand that if you buy this you're on the hook to do much more configuration than is necessary for your average flight sim : /

For me the game is just ok. If you want to get familiar with flying and the controls and learn what all the buttons in a cockpit do and mean, then I think this is a good program for that, I would not call it a game. The scenery is not good, So much paid dlc makes me think its a money mill. SF CA had like maybe 9 buildings, Santa Fe, none. Once you get the hang of it the planes control systems can do most of the work for you, so, whats left, look out the window at poor scenery. I spend hours sometimes looking at google earth, and If you want to site see I suggest you go look at google for free. This is about flying imo and not much else. If you want to spend hundreds of dollars on controls and feel like driving is not enough work for you then here ya go. I would rather look out the window instead of being behind the stick of a plane. This imo is not for fun, especially if your gonna mouse fly, imo it is very hard and not at all realistic using a mouse, so to make it feel more like work and not luck you can buy real controls, then you can be like a working pilot who makes no money and has no goals but to understand what buttons to use to make the plane do all the work. 

If I was going to learn to fly I would spend a ton of time on this and get as familiar as I could the the cockpit functions and what flying a plane is like. I do not plan on learning so this was a waste of money for me. Good learning tool. Buy it on sale if you have never played any flight games, pay full price if you want to learn about planes. If you dont mind spending money on games, I would gear up and get a nice set up and buy both this and MS. American truck is a ton more fun imo. Out-of-the-box, has very well-detailed planes visually. Good effects and physics as well.

If you're new to sims, this may or may not be a casual experience for you. 
The world scenery isn't that too well-detailed, so this isn't much for VFR flying.
The ATC leaves a lot to be desired, understandably. Other sims do a decent job of implementing ATC.
Not all airports will be detailed, or updated... hence this is where freeware/payware addons come in.

Where it really shines (as with other flightsims) is how you want to modify your flightsim, whether freeware and/or payware aircraft/scenery/utility addons.

I recommend this for getting into the basics of flying.
I don't recommend this for VFR flying unless you have a lot of time and PC storage (downloading and storing Orthophotos, basically satellite images of the world).
I highly recommend it for procedures and basic IFR flying. If you have the money, you can buy much more detailed aircraft (the default aircraft systems are detailed but up to certain points) with really in-depth systems modelling.
Thank god for autopilot.

This is really good, just have problems with lag.



Physics: 5/5, the physics are study level, there is a physics model so you can see thermals, drag, etc. Even approved by the FAA for a simulation model.

Scenery: 3.5/5, if you get some good scenery packs and sky enhancements it's DEFINETLY 5/5

lag: 3/5 For Low-End devices it's very laggy, however on a gaming laptop/computer it doesn't lag on max graphics settings. Expect FPS drops!!!

Plane selection: 4/5, the planes are super nice and there is quite a selection, but you get Boeing only,gotta buy Airbus yourself.

Airport selection:5/5, There are all airports that you can think of,except for smaller regional ones,but you can download them. Sadly, most of them are copy and paste buildings and none of the default ones have working jetways.

Controls: 4/5, the game uses mouse controls and you gotta select buttons yourself, but of course it supports USB joysticks.
Price: 5/5 , it's worth the price, never gets boring. 



Problem for laptops or PC's that aren't made for games: If you have bad memory and Graphic cards etc. , you will have to wait a minimum of 5 MINUTES to load in a plane, as said, the framerate is bad if you put the graphics to like medium. I recommend to take a look at the requirements before downloading. 

Other: The game takes A LOT OF TIME TO DOWNLOAD, it took me 8 hours. You should let it download at night if you want to play it the next day. 



Rating: 4.5 / 5

Overall: I love the game so much! It is great physics wise, realistic plane models, awesome different settings and visuals, it's simply the buildings that are very lazy. However, with free plugins like Enhanced Cloudscapes, Gandalf Skycolors, HD trees, Ortho4Xp, X-Europe, X-America, etc. you can get awesome graphics that make it look somewhat better than MFS2020. 

Thanks so much for this great simulator.

X-Plane is a great simulator. As of right now, I have had it for just over a year and I can't think of one time where I uninstalled it. It is just overall great. The default graphics are not good though, and if you want your game to look decent it will require some mods. Although the default graphics are not good, the physics and system depth is great especially if you're like me not willing to pay the money for P3D. I will say you need some better planes than just using the default ones, but there are some good free ones like the Zibo 737-800 and a good payware one which I have is the ToLiss A319 or A321, and if you're into Boeing then I would suggest the Flight Factor 757 or 767, but not the 777. After you pick out some good payware planes, you're good. I would suggest doing some research before buying your planes as I would not want you to just go with the cheapest, because in the flight sim world it is rare for the cheaper plane to be the better one. The most expensive are usually the best ones.

My final conclusion is that if you are into IFR flying and flying airliners, X-Plane 11 is the simulator for you. If you value graphics and VFR General Aviation flying, Microsoft Flight Sim 2020 is the simulator for you. It all comes down to personal choice and my personal choice, of course, is XP11.

Great simulator, but needs a lot of plugins since it lacks in some areas, but most of them can be found for free.
However, if you are looking to buy this simulator, you should consider waiting for Xplane 12 which is soon to be released.

Free plugins I wish I knew about earlier:
- Zibo mod (better B738) + AviTab & Terrain Radar
- Better Pushback
- Autogate (movable jetbridges for custom airports)
- Simple Gound Service (automated baggage loading and catering trucks)
- Head Shake (The camera feels more dynamic and reacts to forces like hard landings etc)
