First off, I absolutely hate the complicated and scattered Steam GUI in general and wish I'd bought directly from the manufacturer.  I can't access my online screenshots.  Nor is there any option to store pics/videos locally (i.e. on my own computer).  Managing "DLC" all I get is more commercials instead of game settings and possible upgrades which are missing. They are available on the net but not through Steam apparently.  

Will they be supported and fixed automatically if I add free Ortho scenery from a 3rd party?  
Will the file ordering be automatically fixed by Steam?  
Because for the consumer that is the only major draw for becoming embedded into this network which controls all game play.   Where are the extra content links and setup menus for my games?  Why aren't all options presented in a logical fashion?  Why can't I even copy this review  text?  Why can't I access my desktop at any point using alt+esc?  This is a bug and not a feature. Steam.

I played the game for about 15 min, but Steam shows 76 min play time.

I already have a lot invested in 32-bit Microsoft FSX with extensive photo-real scenery, many aftermarket addons, REX, and EZ-Dok camera. It still is a lot of fun.  Memory balancing and optimization is a major problem though and the quality of various addons differs greatly.  While I still love that game I wanted so much more for my higher-end system and went with X-Plane. 

Playing X-Plane for the first time after downloading for two full days, one flaw is obvious: You can't access Settings Menu(graphics/aircraft/weather/etc) without quitting and re-starting the entire game.  WTF?  At $60+tax for an older game the price is a bit steep to begin with, but from online videos it has the potential to look absolutely incredible especially with Ortho photo-real scenery.  Steam doesn't show that option in the GUI.  All of the possible upgrades are localized and become very expensive quickly when it all adds up. That is to be expected from an a-la-carte business structure.  The starter aircraft selection is very limited.  Buy what you want or need for any given area.  Enjoy.  Purchase more as time goes by.  I get it.

Increasing my graphic settings to Max resulted in an environment only slightly better than default FSX scenery from way back in 2004.  Buildings are missing and roads looks like broken black spaghetti.  There was some rendering problem right off the bat and the dashboard for the OEM 172 turned into 'great green globs of greasy grimy gopher guts' (i.e. bumping up the graphics turned the dash controls into lumpy lime-green squares).  That is not a good indicator when the default game is used 'out of the box'. And it should never happen with a proven game.  I expected much more.
 
I'm not a lawyer, but a quick read of the EULA indicated at a glance the OEM says the distributor is responsible and they are under English law and limitations are a grand blah blah blah typical legalese stuff.  
So what happens when basic problems like this happen?  Download "fixes" from some 3rd party forums?  

I don't mean to knock the game entirely.  The X-Plane OEM default environment is consistent and very acceptable for any basic flight sim who at least want  basic coverage for the entire world.  But it should have been a whole lot more to start off with for the lofty purchase price.  
It did not run at full capacity without modifications...and it should have.

The game only runs at 30-40 fps on my computer. 
I have a Rysen7, GTX 2080 Super, 48GB RAM, Gigabyte MB, liquid cooling, etc. 

Q:  Where are the advanced settings options so I can fully tweek the game?  
A:  They are missing. Both in-game and on Steam.
Get it before you make the mistake of buying MFS 2020.

I finally bought XP11 after being disappointed by MSFS and I'm glad I did.  Don't get me wrong, it has it's flaws like all other flight simulators and everyone has their favorite, mine is now XP11.  There's several reasons but I will list the main one.
-Flight physics are far superior and more realistic than any other flight sim out there.  Even taxing is more realistic.  This is the main reason I bought it, and not for just airplanes but also helicopters.  I've always wanted to fly realistic feeling helicopters and there are some very good ones for XP11.  It's a thrilling challenge.  All aircraft in XP11 have their own unique feel and personality, something other flight simulators have sometimes struggled with.  For me better physics makes flying so much more fun and interesting.

Yes the graphics of the X-Plane 11 world are not impressive to say the least but there's some really great add-ons you can buy (there's also a free worldwide mesh) to make everything from the autogen buildings, to the trees to the airports and everything else outside your cockpit window look a lot better.  The default aircraft look ok visually but there are some very beautifully done 3rd party aircraft that look spectacular inside and out.

Overall, it's a great simulator, especially if you're willing to put some money into it.  Unfortunately that is the case with all flight simulators though.

FEEDBACK:

X-Plane 11 is (still) the best plattform for flightsimulation
that ships with limited default content.

PRO:
+ realism
+ realistic & probably the best flightmodel
+ nice graphics & nice clouds
+ great interface & gameplay
+ lots of free community add-on content with easy copy & paste installation,
   some of it in payware quality, like the "Zibo Mod"
+ it never gets boring
+ helpful and competent Community
+ flued performance thanks to *NEW* Vulkan rendering!!

CONTRA:

- unfinished native planes ("Columbia 400"...)
- no coop multiplayer (like  shared cockpit)
- poor dedault (offline) ATC
- Native FMC is unsatisfying (important pages missing...).
- King Air C90B, bad handling
  Autopilot-Panel can't be brought up as a separate window.
- G1000 offers NDB (morse-code) monitoring but no possibility to tune in the frequency.

- no shortcut to set local QnH
- no shortcut to readback last transmissiono (ATC)

- small in-game map excerpts
- no in-game word map
- no ingame web-browser

- not propper jetways
- no seasons

Suggestions:

- implement Ortho4XP
- finish Columbia 400, bring the Baron with a G1000
- release Cessna in 3 versions: Bendix AP, new & G1000
- improve handling of good native planes like King Air C90
- add shortcuts (readback last transmission, set local QnH...)
- add Option to end current flight
- add Indication of mainpages on right display of G1000
- add Option to tune in NDB in G1000
- map-up button (on G1000 in "map track up") should move map up, not north!
- always keep aspect ratio when rezisizing G1000

After primarily flight simming on FSX for over 10 years, I picked up X-Plane 11 to see what all the hype was about and to try out the Toliss Airbus A320. It took a few hours of getting used to but now, X-Plane 11 is my main flight sim. I'm impressed with the default scenery especially for areas here in the Philippines. Airports that just had plain runways in FSX have taxiways and generally accurate positions for buildings in X-Plane 11. I also like how the navigation database is updated in this sim compared to FSX. I can prepare for my instrument rating thanks to how XP11 has current RNAV waypoints and the like. Overall, I highly recommend this sim for more serious flight simulator enthusiasts.

In depth review from real heli pilots and from a requirements perspective.
COMPARISON:Probably some of the best heli dynamics in a sim! I have IRL experience and 2 siblings that fly heli's for a living also gave their feedback. It could save thousands in basic training with proper, linear, full sim controls. The only thing found lacking was auto rotations as they felt more like a plane, but that could be down to the model I was using (MD 500e...my dad used to be a 500d pilot so seeing if they got the model accurate for it is the next test when i see him and will update accordingly. It feels like I remember but he will know for sure). 
Unlike DCS, the controls don't have that few milliseconds of delay, which makes flying linear full sim controls in X-Plane a lot more real. 
Some amazing paid heli add on, scenery/mesh, as well as a mission generator are available. Honestly a great Sim experience that focus' on flying skill rather than blasting enemies out of the sky with heat seeking missiles....although there's an add on for that too, if you fancy a fiery ball of PPL and CPL pilots off the runway or out of your airspace !!!
GRAPHICS REQUIREMENTS: If you're doing VR you will need a beast of a machine to make it look any good. just so you have some reference- 1 Suprim x 3090 with overclocks isn't enough. 2 GPU's would be required to make *everything* maxed out. CPU side of graphics is fine maxed out with OC'd 5950x, plenty headroom.
I run an Index at 80Hz and Resolution at 400%. 25-37 fps depending. Maxed Texture and Effects. Zero Antialaising or Antiscopic fliters.
Can't wait for the next Edition: X-Plane 12

Can't wait for XP12, but even as-is, XP11 is FAR AND AWAY better than FS2020. If you enjoying flying in VR (or even having the option to fly in VR), then choosing between X-plane and FS is very simple--XP11 is your option.

A year after FS2020's launch, it still doesn't have basic VR functionality for all default aircraft and where is does work-ish, it turns the experience into more of 3D rendering of a mouse-clicking game and still requires you to interact with immersion-killing menu overlays. XP11 handles all of this on the actual controller hands and when activated, they go wherever the controllers go, which is rarely right in front of your face out the windscreen.

XP11's VR also let's you teleport, which is a feature worth discussing all on its own. I can literally walk outside some of my aircraft (with click-toggle tags) and preflight the aircraft in VR before moving back inside. It's also very easy to set up preset teleport locations relative to an aircraft, so on those long haul flights, it's very easy to slip back to the cabin and look out any window you want. In the included 747, you can actually even walk around the lower level. Unreal. So much fun. Nothing remotely close to this in FS2020, where console seems to be the focus and why not ($$$).

Performance is no contest. XP11 couldn't be further ahead in this area. Vulkan make it much smoother in and out of VR. FS2020 crashes routinely and if you're in VR, you better have borrowed a machine from NASA even to have a shot at completing a flight. I'm running an i9-9900K, EVGA RTX 3090 FTW3 Ultra, 32GB of speedy ram, 1TB m.2 SSD and many other goodies and they aren't close to enough to wrestle through a flight in FS2020 on the absolute lowest graphics settings without severe stuttering, tearing and, well, since the graphics are bottomed-out, terrible images.

When it comes to extras, such as live traffic, XP11 has a couple solid lightweight free plugins that accomplish exactly what FS2020 is touting and I think the XP11 plugins actually work better (they provide some customization of this feature as well).

Neither has universal shared cockpit, although some specific XP11 aircraft do support that on their own, and multiplayer is achievable in both, but this is the one place that really makes FS2020 worth trying. It's built-in and that streamlines the process, which XP11 has yet to do.

As for the graphics on the ground, yes, the Bing mapping does take some of the grunt work out of getting detail on the ground in FS2020, although it's still possible to get pretty close to the same thing for those willing to learn how to do it and be patient enough to follow through the process in XP11. It's worth noting FS2020 is enormous in size and without a solid internet connection, the experience is really diminished. XP11 wins here too.

The third-party mods are starting to come around, slowly, for FS2020, although there are just bugs up and down and all over the place, where X-plane's healthy hangar of mods is much more stable and the higher-priced payware is pretty rock solid.

I still have FS2020 installed, but I'll be making my flights in XP11 and hopefully soon, XP12.

If you're a long time MSFS user like me, it'll take you a few days to unlearn how things are done there and learn XP's way of doing things.  Luckily, it's fairly intuitive and didn't take too long for  me.  The one and only gripe I have about XP vs. MSFS is that there is no built in airport search by nation or state.  You'll have to get ICAS codes from outside the game.  It's not a HUGE problem, but I really liked MSFS's way of being able to explore the world, country by country.  Other than that, it's a big improvement in just about every way over MSFS before the 2020 version.  You probably won't go back to MSFS after XP11... which is NOT something I'd say about XP10.

XP11 is a sim with tons of potential, but it doesn't quite hit the mark.

I'm a casual flight simmer, have been for years. My first was Microsoft Flight Simulator 3.0, and I had every FS up to FSX. I loved the feeling of immersion you got with FSX, especially, what with all the AI traffic and a halfway decent out-of-the-box ATC. You didn't need to mod it to get a great sim experience.

XP11 is the exact opposite of that. If you are using it for anything other than flying in and out of uncontrolled airports, you're going to feel like you're missing something. Without extensive modding (most of which are paid mods), you will be lacking in any meaningful air traffic, and hampered by a lacking ATC with what little traffic there is. 

Sure, the flight models are pretty great (except for the helicopter model, which is just broken), and graphically it's better-than-decent. But the complete lack of any other life in the air just completely breaks the illusion.

Additionally, the DLC is all outrageously expensive. If one were to buy all the pay airports and aircraft, you'd be spending hundreds of dollars piecing together the complete package.

If any devs/producers are reading this: I'll not be buying any more Laminar Research products until you focus a little on a better world-building experience with air traffic and an acceptable ATC, otherwise you're only releasing half a simulator. I'll just stick with FS for now.

Update: I gave the sim a few months, tried (and ditched) some free add-ons, and did more playing with the Vulkan rendering engine. It somehow has gotten worse... texture management is broken, ATC is still broken, the visual rendering is still silly (massive power lines, extremely unrealistic trees, broken road and water systems). The flight model of the simpler aircraft is pretty decent, but not great. Still absolutely cannot recommend it...I really hope XP12 offers something better so that MSFS has some real competition.

X-Plane 11 is a classic flight simulator that does an incredible job of simulating aircraft with impressive systems and procedures (especially from some of the third party efforts). As a scenery simulation, X-Plane 11 has fallen far behind its competitors without some significant (and sometimes expensive) third party support which brings it closer to the latest and greatest.

If you like deep systems simulation, challenging flight dynamics, and an modifiable sim platform, X-Plane 11 is for you. If you hate tweaking things and want it to just work, you may want to look at other options.

It has unparalleled physics and good graphics. Undoubtedly, X-Plane 11 is the best flight sim for VR; it can run on a GTX 1060 6gb or a GTX 1650 Super. The competition,  DCS World and MFS2020, fail to get a playable VR experience from those graphics cards. Beyond this, XP11 also features the most accurate planes of the three games, allowing for the most accurate flight sim experience. Furthermore, while the graphics may seem to pale in consideration to the alternatives, there are tools, such as Ortho4XP, that allow XP11 to get just as amazing visuals as MSF2020. However, do be warned that this does take tremendous amounts of storage! My only complaint with this game would be the less-than-ideal in-game tutorials. In order to truly use this flight sim, you must find guidance from third-party sources. Overall, this game is extremely worthwhile and an incredible buy.

X-Plane is X-Plane.  If you're interested in aviation and GA, X-Plane is the best simulator.  If you're interested in what I'd call the "Model Airplane" experience, you'd probably be better served by the new MS simulator.  If you're into the EAA/Experimental/Homebuilt portion of aviation, X-Plane.  If you're more interested in the AOPA/Boeing/Airbus experience (which, 99% of us will never actually reach), MS Flight Sim.

I've built two planes, flown a few more.  X-Plane makes a fantastic, inexpensive software platform to create models of experimental aircraft and then simulate them in a way that does relate to real world experiences.  It is not the best "photo realistic" simulation platform.  If you care more about the exact placement and color of a knob in the 3d rendered cockpit, X-Plane is good, but might leave you feeling disappointed.  If you want to know the behavior of a plane with a specific loading and w/b configuration and how that is impacted with changes in c/l and airfoil design, X-Plane.

X-Plane is inexpensive enough that if you really are interested in aviation, you should buy it, just to see what's there.

For sure, one of the best flight simulators on the market. The simulator is arguably one of the best regarding flight physics, flight model, community plugins/add-ons (freeware, as well as payware) and in some degree graphics. Also, a fantastic simulator for those who want to learn to fly an airliner for the first time, like I did, where we have great planes like the freeware Zibo 737-800X, which is "payware quality" and can easily be compared to other 737-800 payware add-ons on other flight simulators.

Overall an incredible simulator, with massive benefits for newcomers to flight simulation/aviation in general as well as experienced pilots or simmers. Would absolutely recommend this flight simulator to anyone who has even a slight interest in aviation, and to anyone who want to learn realistically and professionally using a simulator.

Great flight simulator. I'm a Private Pilot and I've loved having this around for the lousy weather days and days I just can't get out to the airport. If you're on the fence between this and Microsoft Flight Simulator. I think if you choose X-Plane you'll have a much better experience. MSFS does have the live terrain updates from the cloud and the AI building rendering and more points of interest that have been modeled by people to make it more real looking. So, if you have hardware that can handle MSFS you _can_ get a better looking flight simulator. If you're looking for flying, X-Plane wins on almost every account. You have access to more planes, you have better tools if you want to create your own planes, the mod community for X-Plane is wonderful. The engine is optimized well. There are far fewer bugs. The avionics are actually implemented in X-Plane and the features work. Lots of avionics features in MSFS either aren't there, or just don't work. I don't have to run that awful updater every time I want to do some virtual flying with X-Plane, and I get to have fun.

As an FSX veteran, I regret not purchasing this game earlier and putting it off for so long. It's legitimately the most realistic and comprehensive flight simulator for 60$. It mostly comes down to the incredible graphics, beautiful default scenery, very realistic flight controls and physics (as I'm told, I played the demo a while ago and thought it felt too sensitive and weird compared to FSX, but it turns out FSX is less realistic on that point), and amazing default plane selection. 

Simply put, the cost of getting a realistic 737 model for FSX (like PMDG) is the same as the cost of this sim, which has the added benefit of having an excellent realistic base 737 and a free "zibo mod" for added realism and all the other stuff I cited.

Not to mention the improved UI compared to FSX, 64-bit architecture utilizing all cores unlike FSX, and much more...

P.S : And you don't have to wait ages for it to update unlike another sim...

This simulator is one the best, if not the best flight simulator out there.

This simulator is brilliant for many reasons, one reason is the ability to fly to any airport you want on this planet with default airports being up to an acceptable level of detail which is more than enough to fly into. Another reason this simulator is so great is because of the fact of how much you can mod it to work pretty much like real life. There is a whole forum for X-Plane 11 where you can download custom sceneries for airports to fly into that are more accurate on building and taxiways than the default airports which are still very accurate. You can also buy study level aircraft from the X-Plane forum store, Threshold store and X-Aviation. And installing all these addons is extremely easy. You can also modify the way the simulator looks with all skycolours from night to dusk to midday to dawn and the cloud texture to. You can also create satellite imagery for the ground, using Ortho4XP, to make it look identical to real life on the ground.

Overall, I recommend this sim 110% over the likes of MSFS and Prepar3D which are still sims with flaws and being very expensive to not even get on the same level as X-Plane 11

Great Sim.  played for about 18 hours according to the game, 25 hours according to  steam.  I have spent a lot of time setting things up, I only have a simple setup, 2 screens and a joystick but there are so many  keyboard shortcuts and options in game that I wanted to set up.  The setup is also more complicated because I am starting to use this game & flying B 737 - and the cockpit detail & controls is much more realistic than FS98 which I was flying previously.
I am really interested and amazed at the support the program has for build your own simm.
For me its been 25 hours of challenging fun so far.

This game can be finicky at times with it having crashed twice the first day I got it, and I played it for around 6 hours the first day; maybe just bad luck. Overall the game is quite good with few hiccups. When first getting the game I was planning on visiting landmarks however, I was quite shocked by was the fact that some landmarks were missing from X Plane 11's scenery, for example the CN Tower in Toronto is missing. Another issue is that major cities only have a few skyscrapers. I guess all isn't that bad on the scenery side after all major landmarks like the Statue of Liberty and Eiffel Tower are present. Besides scenery the game works well and I would refer to it as a high-end simulator. Me being new to flight sims I would recommend this game to you but, would definitely suggest checking out the new Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020 that is being released on August 18, 2020, it's Standard package is only 7 CAD more than the cost of this game - X Plane 11.

Edit: I haven't experienced anymore crashes. Although now with MSFS 2020 out I sometimes struggle to come back to it. I would hesitate to recommend picking it up, especially because X-Plane 12 is going to be released soon.

I like this flight simulator very much. I think it has a few issues that could pretty easily be fixed, but overall, I'm quite pleased with it and I would recommend purchasing if you are looking for a quality flight model.

PROS:
Flight model as accurate or more so than other sims as far as can be told
Default content (planes, scenery) is quite decent, no complaints from me, though you may find otherwise depending on your desires
Tons of 3rd party content is available for free or pay from high quality sources
Active Discord server available, for the most part, fast responses when help or advise is needed.

CONS:
Default ATC is NEEDS to be drug tested. On numerous occasions, I've been guided in low visibility to fly directly into mountains. 
After crashing due to bad ATC instruction, the ATC actually BANS you from their airspace, which I find hilarious. Advice given by the community is to not use the default ATC. Just double check your maps on your own.
Default ATC LOVES to repeat themselves, each time requiring a read-back of the last transmission. VERY UNFORTUNATELY the only way to do this is to click the mouse on a button in a small window that has nothing to do with the plane control interface, and completely breaks the immersion. Also, this causes you to have to either get good with your opposite hand at clicking the mouse or just turn it off. THERE IS NO WAY TO RESPOND TO ATC VIA HOTKEY!
Not much default content, only a few planes available with the default installation.
Flight manuals available for the planes are sparse and contain incomplete startup procedures. You will have to try to find independent aircraft flight manuals, or you will probably have some problems during the flight. One that immediately comes to mind is the King Air C90 fuel system. It requires tanks transfers to the nacelle, but the operators manual does not tell you how to do this and it seems to work a little funny.

Don't let the longer list of CONS be an indicator of the quality of the simulator. Most of the cons are simply tweaks that need to be made to default ATC instructions and the ability to communicate with them via hotkey, so that you can respond without using the mouse. See DCS A10 simulator for a good working example of this.

Overall: I do recommend this as a great simulator and I will use it when not flying combat missions in Georgia.

Um simulador muito bonito visualmente, e é bem gostoso de mexer. Possui vários níveis de simulação, desde um mais arcade para quem só quer curtir, até simulação total. ENGLISH:
A very beautiful simulator, visually speaking, and quite fun to mess with. Has various simulation levels, like a more arcade mode, with unbelieavable physics to full simulation system. And, a lot cheaper than the Expensive Combat Simulator(DCS World). It comes with around 30 aircraft, all simulated with full panels. Airliners, private charter planes, trainer planes and some combat aircraft. Also has a combat system.
Approved by both Lito Sousa(Planes and Music[Brazillian Youtuber with 20 years of experience working with airliners]) and Aero por Tras da Aviação.
Also, Lito helped develop the PMDG 747 for Microsoft Flight Simulator!
Recommended for those who want to relax flying a plane in arcade mode or simulate full aircraft physics.

I know that I have very little hours at the time of this review, but feel that I have enough time to make a good review of this product. This is without a doubt the flight simulator to buy if you want the most realistic flight dynamics and models currently out in my opinion. MSFS feels to arcade-like and that was the reason for buying X-Plane 11. The graphics are nothing to write home about, but they will do. If you want the best graphics some money is going to be dropped on this simulator, but I suggest MSFS if you like VFR flying. The default aircraft are better than MSFS and the FREE 737 Zibo mod that you can download for X-Plane feels like it should be payware. The Payware aircraft that you can get from Toliss, FlightFactor, InIBuild and so many more beat anything that MSFS has hands down.

TLDR: If you want the best flight simulator and can give up the bing maps scenery that MSFS 2020 has, this game is for sure worth a buy!

Absolutely amazing simulator and cannot compare the flight model between this and the new MSFS 2020. This is the best flight *SIMULATOR* on the market currently with so much aircraft to choose from and some amazing developers and airplanes. The night lighting really sticks out and you can get a bunch of freeware to make this game look amazing. (Ex. Enhanced cloudscapes, Zibo 737, 737-700 and 900U, mSparks 747, etc.) There is so much to do in this game and it really pumps me up for X-Plane 12. Just had my first crash out of about 61 hours of flight time in this game, so unless you're running on a really low end computer, then you should be fine in terms of crashing. 

Optimization: The optimization in this game is ok. I'm running on a R7-3700x and an RTX 3070 with 16GB of RAM (Note there are background tasks that you do have to keep in mind of when playing). This game takes a good chunk out of my RAM usage. However, I do get good frames when using ReShade RTX and max graphics. Although, if you're running on a low end PC, I highly recommend saving up and getting a new, more powerful PC before buying if you're planning on it. Or, if you want to try, this game offers a free demo that you can use via their website. Just search on Google: "XP11 demo version", and you can still add mods but you will only get to play for like 30 minutes at a time. 

Overall: I'd give this game an 8/10, it is an amazing simulator which I hopefully plan on using for flight training and has an amazing community with lots of developers and integration of multiplayer (Ex. VATSIM or Pilotedge). It may not have the best optimization in the world however it really sticks out in the flight sim community so if you're debating on a SIMULATOR to buy between XP11 and FS2020, choose XP11.

Hands down, this is the better flight sim.  Don't get me wrong, MSFS is good.  In fact, it has the better graphics, but X-Plane 11 dwarfs MSFS in every other category.  When it comes to graphics, you can also get it pretty close in quality to MSFS by using mods.  X-Plane (with Vulkan enabled) performs SO much better.  It also takes less time to load and frame rates stay consistent.

However, this game is really for people who are into flight sim.  If you're a casual player and trying to decide which one, then get MSFS.  It is better out of the box.  If you are hardcore flight sim addict and/or love modding games, then this is your choice.

For mods, I suggest: Ortho4XP, Enhanced Skyscapes, Active Sky Weather and A Better Camera.  For planes, I highly suggest the Toliss A340 (payware) and the Zibo Mod 737-800 (free).

Xplane 11, one of the most up to date and one of the best flight simulators we have on the market today.

I strongly recommend this product both for the completeness of the flight model and for the community that you have around it.
As most of the flight simulators currently on the market, with this product you are not purchasing a game but a way to simulate aircraft flight in the most complete way. You will therefore have to study real aircraft manuals just to turn on the engine and to perform your first take off and touch and go which will make the learning curve quite steep for a casual user.

It is therefore recommended to all people who have a passion for flight and are looking for a way to have a complete simulated experience.
Being a simulator means that all the actions are in real time, with real flight durations and real reactions. In order to get the best it is therefore recommended to have at least a joypad or a flight stick and foresee some long playing sessions.

G'day All,

I switched to X-Plane a few weeks ago from being a die hard MS flight simmer since the last 20 years! All was going well with FS2020, till Update 5, after which there were CTD's every time on loading....which led me to be grounded.

So! I decided to try out X-Plane and get back to the skies :)

After spending a good amount of time getting to "know the X-Plane product", I am now enjoying many "CTD free" flights with an experience in a realistic aircraft, having a detailed Cold & dark start + the checklists + FMC etc, etc.

Yes! Nobody can dispute the difference in the graphics ...ground imaging, clouds and aircraft external appearance with FS2020, as X-Plane really has to catch up in those areas. The ATC is also way behind FS2020.

But on the other hand....the aircraft (cockpit functionality) is better in X-Plane and the feel is more realistic.....not considering the graphics as mentioned earlier. 

If X-Plane could improve on the Land Graphics, Clouds and external aircraft looks (like FS2020), this would be the Simulator to have for the Serious Flight Simmers who like to treat it as a Flight Simulator and "NOT" a game to play.

I'm still new to X-Plane and I'm sure there's a lot to learn, but for a person like me who loves serious flight simulation, I would strongly recommend this product. Yes! FS2020 was great....till it stopped working after the 27th JUL update, and nobody seems to know how to fix it. For people who want to spend time flying rather than time on trying to fix the numerous CTD's......X-Plane is it :)

As Leonardo Da Vinci said...."For once you have tasted flight you will walk the earth with your eyes turned skywards, for there you have been and there you will long to return".

Looking forward to improvements in X-plane to make it the ultimate Flight Simulator :)

This review pertains to VR only (since that's the only way I use flight sims these days).  Since the Vulkan update in XP, the VR performance experience is simply the best you can get in a civilian sim.  You do, however, need to be willing to spend time modding--especially with Ortho textures--to get this sim up to its best.   I've taken enough flying lessons IRL to land a plane with instructor hands off; so I have a decent sense of what it feels like.  Currently, in A/B tests with MSFS, using a combination of physical Yoke (Honeycomb), pedals, Knobster, and virtual control of thrust, switches, and buttons, XP feels much closer to what I experienced in the cockpit than MSFS.  MSFS does excel at providing more photorealistic visuals out the window, but IMO is less convincing than XP when it comes to actual flight feel and control.  Basically, XP is much more of a flight simulator (what if feels like to fly a plane), while MSFS is more of a flying simulator (what it feels like to fly *in* a plane).  XP also provides me with much better performance in VR, giving me a minimum of 15 fps better performance than MSFS's default VR settings (and which only spreads wider at higher settings).  I still like MSFS when I'm up for a more casual experience at low altitudes where its trademark photogrammetry matters most; but for duplicating real-life flying, flight planning, and at altitude I find XP much preferable--feeling more professional and well tuned in this regard, especially in terms of navigation, take-offs, and landings.  Both continue to evolve so any flight simulator enthusiast should treat themselves to both, but XP is the one I currently use the most.

X-Plane was disappointing. The textures are knockoffs. It does not come with force feedback, one has to pay an additional 14$ to obtain it. To have to pay extra for something so fundamental, seams like extortion.

All that being said, it is currently the only FS that allows one two fly any aircraft anywhere in the world in VR. Where it lacks on hotas it makes up for with the touch controller compatibility. The touch controllers can be mapped. because of that i have decided to give it a thumbs up.

X-Plane is a great sim, great for some extra training and practice. I personally use this to train for cheaper than I can buy flight time. Feels pretty close to the control feedback of the real deal. Instruments are pretty good too. Other than the Graphics, X-Plane 11 is still better than Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020. MS Flight Sim crashes frequently even on top notch systems, has limited planes, has mushy control feedback, and is not nearly as realistic overall. 

For a good example: In X-Plane, when you drop in 10 degrees of flaps the nose balloons just like it does in real life -- MS Flight Sim does not replicate this. 

If you are looking for realism, training, extra practice--Stick with X-Plane 11.

This reviews is dedicated towards those who wish to buy the game for training purposes (student pilots). 

[b]Pros[/b]
1) As stated in the store page of the game, it is a flight simulator aimed to simulate how aircrafts are operated and flown in real life.  Cooperated with VATSIM, it's really good for those who wish to strengthen their communications with ATC and other pilots.
2) Amount of add-ons that can be added into the base game. (Tons of free add-ons around)

[b]Cons[/b]
1) Lack of aircraft variety- limited variety of aircraft in the base game. (Add-ons can fix it)
2) Graphics is pale in comparison to MFS 2020 (but who needs good graphics when you can sacrifice it for better performance)
fun

Probably was my favourite sim.  Two halves of this story - the first is a general review of XP11, and the second part is why I simply cannot recommend it now.

XP11 is way way better than XP10 - flight models are excellent and the base scenery is very good indeed.  Plenty of expansion opportunities, official or third party.  Add some serious scenery from the likes of ORBX and you have a terrific looking simulator that is now working well.  Note - rudder pedals strongly advised for both XP10 and 11 - unlike FSX where there is a built in compensator for no rudder pedal hardware, XP11 really needs rudder pedals to control aircraft on take-off - particularly piston engined aircraft.

The games Air Traffic Control used to be dreadful - I'm pleased to say that XP11 has improved that aspect of the game.  It's still not perfect, but is much improved.  The only really serious fault with the game that needs adjusting is the behaviour of other AI aircraft in game.  This is probably the only area where FSX still wins - aircraft in XP11 fly off in one direction, and then suddenly appear out of the blue on finals in front of you!!  

The game demands a half decent graphics card to run smoothly, so watch out for the graphic specs.  And hereby lies the real thorn with this sim.  My PC is not a high end machine, but it has been working fine until the powers that be created the Vulcan open GL update.  Since then, my load times have trebled, and sometimes the sim just freezes on loadup.  The Vulcan update has, in my opinion totally ruined the flight sim experience for normal folk like me who do not want to reinvest hard earned cash - and lots of it - on a new PC just to make a flight sim work.
I used to get a lot out of this sim - once loaded it may have run a little slow, but it was still more than acceptable.  Since Vulcan, it's the devil's own job to get it to load.  Have tried alll sorts - making sure up to date drivers are present etc etc, and I've been trying for a long time to get things sorted, but to no avail.  There are some really helpful folk out there that have been making lots of really good suggestions to make my sim load up more consistently - sadly none have worked.

Overall - I'd therefore have to very reluctantly not recommend unless you have a high end PC that can handle the graphic output and can handle the Vulcan upgrade.
Having recently purchased MSFS202, I stand by this review - MSFS on the same PC loads reasonably quickly and works.  Purists will say that the flight models in XP11 are better, and they are probably right.  But half the time, I can't get it to load - when I do it's taken two or three freezes, and then an insanely long load up time that eventually works means that after around 40 minutes of frustration, I might just get a flight going.

In short - a really good flight sim ruined for low-end PC users.

After spending few years on FSX and Prepar3d v3 & V4 my friend pushed me into the world of X-Plane, and here is how it went.

At first it was different than simulators mentioned above and no sceneries I installed worked but then he told me that I need to download libraries required for each scenery. At first this was a bit painfull but as this was my first fresh install of X-Plane I took some time and once everything was done I started having fun exploring addons, sceneries and I am amazed by it. From that time I only fly X-Plane and I am enjoying every bit of it. Great thing about X-Plane is if you ever need to do fresh install simply copy Custom Scenery folder somewhere and when reinstall is done place it back and all your sceneries are there and working.

Plane developers here are great and we see great planes like HotStart TBM900, iniBuild A300, Beluga and A310, Toliss A319, A321, FlightFactor A350 and so on which will take hours and hours from your time flying them around the world. If you ever get bored looking at auto gen scenery there is Ortho4XP where you can create your own meshes in better details and more up to date versions of terrain around the regions you fly.

In 2021 I just can't recommend this sim to anybody whether they be casual simmer or hardcore enthusiast.  I bought it as an upgrade to Microsoft Flight Simulator X and have barely played it.  It's a slight graphical upgrade to FSX with some interesting modern aircraft and an advanced physics model.  But all of the fun factor of FSX is gone here and the real world locations are flat and bland in comparison with few points of interest for sight seeing.  It is inferior in every way to the latest Microsoft Flight Simulator including its implementation of VR and I'm uninstalling after just ten hours of flying over all the years I've owned it.  I recently re-purchased FSX in its Steam iteration for the fun and challenging missions and would still recommend that over X-Plane.

Sorry to say but it is time to put this baby to bed. It can not and will not ever compare to MSFS . It used to be a great game before and even at MSFS launch, but now - no comparison. Stop wasting money on a dead horse (Inc Xplane12) and move to the future of flight simulation. The longer you wait, the more you going to hate yourself for not making the change sooner.  You can ignore any bad reviews on MSFS - I have only the greatest admiration for where this sim is at the moment - miles ahead of any other (Xplane/P3dv5). Medium to high end PC is required to truly experience the marvel that this sim has to offer.

Play this while you're waiting for FS2020 to download, then get a refund from Microsoft because X-Plane is WAY better.

I was all ready to post a decent review, but NO, I just had to go discover the official X-Plane forums, and all the hundred of gigabytes of addons, scenery, mods, and aircraft they're hosting, all (mostly) free and made by the community.

Speaking of community, for whatever reason, the X-Plane/Flight Sim community was spared the pain of being assimilated into the Steam Workshop/Mod community, and it shows. I haven't had this much fun hunting down cool mods and addons since before Steam built the railroad.

Last but certainly not least, is the ease of use. I ACCIDENTALLY setup a 3 monitor view while tinkering around with the settings. I was fully expecting it to be an ordeal like with every other software I've ever tried, but however they did it, 
Laminar Research did it right. Configuring my HOTAS was a breeze, I did it on the fly during the intro flight.

My only nit to pick is the ATC has no keyboard hotkeys, and you must respond by clicking in a dialog window. Since my mouse hand is the same as my joystick hand, I have to take my hand off the stick to respond to ATC. But that doesn't matter anyway when there's a mod called LiveTraffic that populates your sim with actual flights from actual flight tracking networks)

Make sure you use the Vulkan render library in the settings

X-Plane has been the clutch of my passion for aviation. To be able to fly planes in the comfort at home with almost the level of precision as in reality is amazing. X-Plane 11 is a "real" simulator unlike FS2020 who tries to suit for gamers. It includes a large amount of tools to help simulate so many different aspects such as the Instrument Operating System giving you so many options. The control inputs I found are more direct and precise. The third party catalog is huge with an incredible amount of developers continuing to add-on despite the newer FS2020. I often fly full flights simulating every aspect of a real flight roleplaying as an airline pilot.
However FS2020 looks incredible and has lots of third party potential, I do still recommend X-Plane if you're more into realism.

Very difficult to recommend this game when the new MSFS exists and it cost the same - and visually the two are not even comparable. As for those talking about flight models, I'm just playing with a controller and will sometimes break out the flight yoke, but i'm not a pilot and personally don't notice the difference that much. MSFS seems overly stable, yet during last weeks hurricane I turned on live weather, flew out of NO and the plane was bouncing around almost uncontrollably, like I'd guess a real plane would. But X-Plane has been around for a while and it shows when it comes to visuals, and the performance isn't even all that great, so even on a lowered powered system you're likely not going to get a much of a benefit with X-Plane. Overall X-Plane was the best flight sim for a while and it has a ton of add-ons you can buy for it (and a ton of free ones too), but if you're just casually playing, it's not even close to competing with MSFS. I hope they're working on something new that will blow us away, but until then, it's hard to recommend this game.

MSFS 2020 is a game, It is a game designed to make you part with your cash for stuff you do not need and features that you do, but that X-Plane has had baked in from the start. Look at all the complaints from PC pilots  when they added the XBox version. You cannot fly a plane with an XBox controller. If you like pretty pictures (and I think MSFS 2020 is super pretty)  fly MSFS 2020. If you are a pilot or you want to be a pilot, fly X-Plane. I am a pilot. I play both. For visual appeal, MSFS 2020 wins hands down. For a real flying experience, it has to be X-Plane. Now, when MSFS 2020 offers Sky4crew shared cockpit, I will think seriously about what I've said here. Until then, it's a crappy answer, but buy X-Plane. Microsoft have just demonstrated how much they do not care about you by destroying loyal fans' experiences by adding XBox and breaking it for everybody else, but X-Plane have always had (IMHO) a clear vision and they have stuck to it. I salute Laminar.

Although I've sadly never flown a real plane, physics in X-Plane 11 are the closest to what I've heard from videos and other documents. Taildraggers are especially realistic - It's the only sim in which you need to constantly correct with the rudder to keep the plane straight. P-Factor is much more apparent in X-Plane than in my previous sim, FSX. Planes in FSX feel too stable and are almost impossible to stall. Stalling in X-Plane (in GA aircraft) Will make the left wing drop and will put you in a spin. Overall I highly recommend it if you're looking for a realistic sim. If you're looking for a more "gamer" feel - get MSFS 2020
fun

Simply the most satisfying flight simulation. My first Flight simulator was Microsoft FS3. Each iteration of the 'game' required me to buy a new PC and it was always the only software that pushed the hardware to its limits. At the time FS2020 was launched, the process started again. I bought a new machine and run the sim. The first expedition was a VFR flight in a Cessna along the river Nile from Aegypt to Lake Victoria. What a great experience! Then I did some more smaller journeys and ended up in the Airbus A321 neo. Again, the plane is great, but somehow it didn't feel right. I tried the freeware FlybyWire, which is a great improvement, but still, it didn't feel right. After a few weeks I invested in XPlane. The standard scenery was (compared to FS2020) bad, but the flight experience is on another level. First, you struggle managing the airplane. You have to learn about the airplane, radio communication, flight procedures and the like. After a while you get the basics and a seemingly easy task flying a plane from A to B becomes a very fulfilling activity. I am currently at the point that the ATC gibberish starts to make sense to me and I try to follow all procedures to my best ability. I am currently piloting an A321 and am building a cockpit with real buttons to play with. Finally a project that requires me to solder and make use of my beloved Arduino :) To improve the scenery I used plugins to get sateIlite images of Europe on my harddisk (no streaming!). I bought the Toliss A321 and am really happy with this marvel. I have about 200 hours of playtime on Xplane and about the same time on FS2020 (Although most time was downloading upgrades). FS2020 is just stunning and a great fun to fly around and learn about our planet. However, Xplane is more rewarding to me, because I feel that I gradually learn to master virtual aviation and each step on this journey opens another aspect that catches my interest.

X plane 11 is the best Flight simulator I have played by far. I would frequently use Flight simulator 2004 a century of flight and later FSX but hadn't played a flight simulator in some years. I first tried Aerofly FS2 because it was in a steam sale a while back and feel this is an ok Sim with a nice selection of planes but has limitations on where you can fly, lack of weather and despite them using some nice scenery visuals the world within feels a bit dull. I Wanted to try MSFS 2020 because lets be honest it looks nice but for me I couldn't even get it downloaded.

I'm glad I bought X plane though as this is the best flight simulator I have played by far. The visuals wont beat the competition I'm sure but they're still really good from default "out of the box" so to speak and there are some free downloads available to improve the scenery, unfortunately (but to be expected) with an FPS hit.  The sounds and the feeling of flying (well best you can get from a PC sim anyway) are just amazing in X plane. The included default planes are enough for me and what's important is they're nicely detailed.  I also purchased and installed a separate real time weather add on that I felt was worth it to add immersion.

As a game, scenery and flight dynamics is ok. But there are great problems. First and foremost the simulator cannot be reviewed as a real flight simulator due to the fact that it lacks proper ATC and the one that is present is at least unreliable. You cannot get out of the airport VFR. You can only fly out IFR. Even if you cancel your IFR plan during the flight when you reach your destination airport you cannot communicate with the tower to request landing. Another negative is that though you can change the weather conditions, if you fly IFR the controler will guide you to the runway that you have a tail wind. Impossible in real world. They need too much work in order to qualify as a flight simulator. For the time being is a very eye candy game with some good elements of a flight simulator. Bottom line, it is too expensive for what it offers.

I'm a noob when it comes to flying and flight sims. Having tried both MSFS2020 and X-Plane 11, I think both are great 'games' but they have a different audience:

Get X-Plane if you want:
- better feeling aircraft
- smoother simulation and better FPS 
- to get nerdy with aircraft operation
- mod the game to your taste
- a lot of *purchasable* quality content

Get MSFS 2020 if you want:
- delicious and realistic scenery out of the box
- assisted flying
- modern glass cockpits that operate similar to a car GPS
- letting the plane autopilot do the work while you enjoy the scenery

I think no choice is wrong, but I would warn you that the novelty of nice graphics wears off after some time, while the learning on how to fly and navigate all sorts of planes properly seems to be an endless rabbit hole.

Edit: I've decided I'm sticking with X-Plane

X-Plane 11 is a wonderful mix of real-world and virtual flying. 
For the average airline simmer, this sim is going to rub off on your positive side; it's 737 is great for beginners and is ready for flight right out of the box. For the average VFR and Cessna hopper, I have good news and some bad news. Good news is this sim looks incredible and it's slew of small aircraft are highly detailed, bad news is it lacks a lot of airport and various VFR scenery. 

In terms of enjoyment, X-Plane 11 is a bit hard to learn. You are given cheap vanilla tools to fly with mouse+keyboard, and the sensitivity scale is not fun to play with. Essentially, if you're looking to pick up this game, look forward to around 10 or so hours figuring out how the controls work, their sensitivity, and various other factors that are going to help your flying experience run smoothly. Compared to Microsoft Flight Simulator X, X-Plane 11 takes a lot more time to get set up for flying.

Additionally, the only real way to get 100% enjoyment out of the sim is either through the use of plugins, (which are incredibly easy to install, just drag and drop and you're good to go) or use of joystick/yoke. Mouse and Keyboard functionality are extremely limited, and when you're first starting out it feels like the devs intentionally made your life very hard. Luckily, there is a plugin to fix this, find it here: [url=https://forums.x-plane.org/index.php?/files/file/51810-bettermouseyoke/] Better Mouse Yoke for X-Plane 11 [/url]

[b] At the end of the day, if you're coming from FSX or PMDG, you will be asking yourself the all-too-familiar question: Is this sim worth my hard earned $60? [/b]

[i] Yes! No... well, MAYBE. [/i]

If you plan to run the sim on a high-end or high specs computer, GO FOR IT. This sim is incredible at it's max settings, and if you have a powerful system, you can fly your heart out seamlessly.

However, for the majority of young and aspiring pilots.. your mid-low specs laptop may not be completely compaitble with this simulator. If you're running on very low specs, forget it. The truth of the matter is you're going to have to either stick to VFR and small airports in the middle of nowhere, or stay on FSX. 
If you're on a mid-range computer, changing the internal graphics settings may be enough for you. However, if it is not, there are plugins out there that obscure rendering distance, and improve performance dramatically. Still though, expect to be running 20-30 fps at best in cities.

In conclusion, I love X-Plane 11. Even though I run on a mid-range laptop that I got in 2015, the sim still amazes me. It's an absolute must for people looking to enhance their airline knowledge, or even get into high-lever simming.

I bought it because it supports VR and it was on sale.

There are shortcomings, but it is quite good.

Shortcomings: if you start the game in VR mode, you'll be thrown into a tutorial. However, the tutorial is not made for VR. It is keyboard centric, plus messages it presents to you do not show up in your HMD and you have to interact with them on your desktop. Oh, and also rudder controls aren't bound to anything on your motion controllers.
It also takes quite a bit of disk space - you'll need about 60 gigabyte of space to install it without any addons. And you ideally would want to install this onto a ssd.

Now.... If you ignore the tutorial, bind yaw/rudder control to something (left stick works). amd also install free X-europe addon and then set world object count to at least "Medium"(in graphic settings)... then everything suddenly becomes great. The scenery is believable enough, especially when you try to fly as low as possible without crashing, and the simulation aspect is done very thoroughly. At least some In-game aircraft comes with manual and there's additional manual for autopilot, GPS system etc. 

Speaking of VR, flying right above rooftops in VR is fairly excitring, plus you'll be able to press almost every knob use actual handles, as pretty much everything is interactive.

So, I recommend this one if you have some interest in flight sims and if you have a VR helmet. There are some shortcomings and minor glitches, but otherwise the game is great.

Amazing physics, quite customizable. Out-of-the-box graphics aren't the best but you can make it look amazing without paying a single cent, by searching for free content in the x-plane forums. forums.x-plane.org. That being said, lighting and clouds are 2 issues that I've stated multiple times, but those are being worked on. In the meantime, Reshade and some enhancement pack like Vivid Sky + Vivid Clouds (free) can make it look amazing. You do need some good computer to run it over 40 fps though. 8.5/10 honestly.
actually this sim is great but i won't recommend this to u coz idk will u like it or no
Definitely a great flight simulator. Physics model is great, graphics are great.

Great for IFR flying although visuals are sub par for 2021 unless you spend lots of money or time installing and figuring out Ortho tiles, OSM files, order of entries in the scenery_packs.ini file. You can find airport enhancement mods for free but then some of the required graphics libraries are no longer available so as a result the airport wont display properly or the ground surface is warped and then you have to learn how to use Bflat to smooth out the mesh. 

I downloaded the brilliant  King Air C90B Jonge Pionier mod. Can't even get the plane off the ground without it catching on fire, haha. On Xplane.org a few actual pilots made posts directed to the modder  but then couldnt be bothered when I and others asked questions regarding how to apply throttle, prop RPM etc to prevent damage the engines.  Mod author made an hour long video yet didn't make a single tutorial regarding basic operation of the aircraft.  

I asked several questions regarding issues I was having with Xplane in their discord and I get no response after several times. The question I asked on xplane.org forum is still awaiting review by a moderator after 3 days. 

Its all absurd beyond belief. Far too many skills and time are required to get this sim up and running smoothly and looking good.  

Now if you want to jump into the sim as is and fly the C172 or the Baron 58, there are geat video tutorials by users that will get you up to speed. I learned a lot from Xplane regarding VOR stations, NDB, CDI, HSI , basic navigation, etc.  

Its great for that although the moment you attempt to install mods and improve the look of this sim you will jump down a bottomless pit of confusion with very little help from the community. 

If you just want good IFR out of the box choose Xplane  although if you want good visuals and a great VFR experience choose MSFS 2020 or get both and use each for what they are good at. 

I spend more time installing and sorting out visual  mods in Xplane than I do flying which is ridiculous. Perhaps at sometime in the future Xplane will get revamped and installing visual mods wont be so painful and frustrating.  Or better yet Xplane will look good out of the box. At this point I might just get a refund and buy MSFS if I could although I have put 50hrs into this game to come to this realization.  

Xplane has its good points for sure although its a headache unless you have a good connect to experienced Xplane users/modders.

Spend literally hundreds of dollars or hundreds of hours getting Xplane to look great or just buy MSFS 2020 for the same base price although it has some issues as well.

I have read some of the posts on here where the brewer inadvertently stops working. The first one I purchased quit after 2 days. The replacement stopped working after 2.5 weeks and acted the same way--just wold not make coffee. If this happens to you, the problem might be (I discovered this by accident and I blame Keurig for not putting some note or instructions in the paperwork) the piercing needle is plugged with debris or coffee grounds. The unit detects excessive back pressure and stops. All one needs to do is get a paper clip and open up for one piece of wire to insert on either side of the needle to remove and debris. After doing that, the unit worked fine. If you call Keurig, they will send you a device to clean that port as well. If your unit tries to make a cup then stops short of filling the cup, try this first.

Before playing this game, I played Microsoft Flight Simulator X, and I am pretty new to this game. Playing the game feels pretty good, but I recommend using a joystick since playing the game with a mouse does not feel right. I have to click at the center of the game to control the plane with a mouse, and when I change views, I have to click the center again to regain control. 
When I played the game, I thought I would have to remember the X-Plane's key bindings; then, I learned that the game has a feature where the key bindings can change to FSX key bindings did not know until I played around with the settings. The scenery and the aircraft models look fantastic but take some of my CPU and RAM since it's a big game. I would recommend playing the game, even if you do not have a joystick, but it would take a lot of your hard drive space, CPU, and RAM power.

This is the best "Flight Sim" on the market, bar none. The best "Terrain Sim", with very good flight simulation is MS Flight 2020, but this has more detailed planes, that you can find free/paid mods for off of the steam marketplace (you have to install them manually in most cases). If you want "batteries included" experience with mainstream controls and tutorials, go for MS Flight. If you want to find your house and land a helicopter on the lawn, go for MS Flight. If you want air combat, go for DCS, Rise of Flight, or IL-2. If you want incredibly detailed planes, with some fudged but decent terrain and airports (you can pay for the big ones in high fidelity) go for X-Plane 11. If you want VR that won't ignite your GPU, go for X-Plane 11. If you want motion controller support in VR, go for X-Plane 11. If you want your legacy (say.. X-55) HOTAS to work out-of-the-box, go for X-Plane 11. 

All that said, I love X-Plane 11, and I love MS Flight 2020/X, and I love DCS. But for **PURE FLIGHT SIM** I will choose X-Plane 11 every time.

As a flight simmer coming over from FSX, its is a great simulator overall. Not only are graphics and preformance better (Running in Vulcan) but it is a 64 bit, meaning it does not have the limited 4 gig of ram that caused constant OOM errors on fsx. Xplane also has a couple of great free aircraft that make the sim awesome: The zibo 737, and the sparky 747 which are just overhauls of the default aircraft. In conclusion Xplane-11 if much better than fsx, and I was skeptical of switching from fsx to x-plane, but when I did, it was worth it. 

Now, while Xplane is a way better sim, that comes at a cost. Normally on fsx, you could get a full pack of good airplanes for around $60 dollars, but just for the base model of the 757-200 from flight factor is $72! That is a lot of money! Almost everything for xplane is going to cost money, and a lot of it. This is because it is a 64 bit game, the graphics are better, and the performance is much better too. If you are looking for a good sim, and have the money, time, and patience to do so, xplane is the way to go.

X-cellent Simulator. By far the best sim available when it comes to airliners. Right off the bat your greeted with an amazing sim. The vanilla version is very much enough for a new comer to the sim world, with decent default aircraft and graphics. For those that want even more realism, there is a wide array of free add-ons available online. These include scenery packs, aeroplanes, plug-ins (highly recommended) real life ATC (Under VATSIM) and the holy grail of X-plane visuals.....Ortho tiles( Photo realistic depictions of the terrain). All these elements combined create an experience unlike any other in the market right now. On the payware side of things, you can make the sim really shine. There are many great developers out there making everything from planes to weather enhancers. If your pockets allow I would definitely recommend you have a look at a few.  The Sim has great external hardware support for all your flight peripherals ( joysticks, yokes, rudders, throttles etc) and even controller support if that's more your speed. The community is amazing and is ready to help with any queries you may be having as your fly along. Overall this is a solid sim and is going to stay so for quite some time.

If you do decide to buy X-plane 11 BUY THESE PLANES FIRST : Flight Factor 757, Zibo 737 (freeware), Aerobask Phenom 300, ini builds A300, Toliss A321, Toliss A319, and the Flight Factor A320 ultimate. Update as of April 20, 2021: Now that I'm flying the Cessna 172 more in real life, I've come to appreciate the flight dynamics of the XP11 172. It is much more accurate in terms of performance (climb, glide, pitch attitude for a given airspeed) than MSFS2020. The latter still makes XP11 look like it was drawn with sidewalk chalk, but for usable practice in the 172, XP11 is the clear winner. I'm using the Facebook Quest 2, and though I'm still not a fan of Facebook, I just can't deny the quality of the product; and it gives a more stable experience than the Quest 1. XP11 is also much smoother in VR than MSFS2020 but that could be due to graphics settings. I just don't have the time to work it all out right now. For now it's XP11 for practice and MSFS2020 for sight seeing.

Update as of Dec 27th, 2020: With the release of XP11.50 with Vulkan as well as Oculus Link FINALLY coming out of beta this is now a good experience in the Oculus Quest 1 + Link. With a very solid gaming PC ($2500 total investment about a year ago) I can get 45FPS with just above average settings in XP. One really important piece is to make sure SteamVR has the correct resolution. What it call 100% is way too high for the Oculus Quest. It's not uncommon to need a reboot to get maximum FPS. I've seen a 3x improvement after rebooting the computer and headset. As of right now, this is MASSIVELY better than MSFS2020 in VR.

ORIGINAL REVIEW: This review is specific to using X-Plane 11 with Oculus Quest + Link in mid-2020 (which is not supported by either company). Until Oculus improves compressing/decompressing large frames over Link, X-Plane 11 is a non-starter. Even with everything dialed down to the minimum setting, the number of application dropped frames continuously increases at a quick pace. My guess is that Quest isn't able to decompress the frames fast enough so X-Plane just has to drop the frames as the pipeline gets bogged down. Prepar3d has the same problem. FlyInside sim seemed to be much better and MS-FSX is actually livable, but with much poorer graphics. Condor 2, strictly for sail planes, is very smooth, but also with pretty poor graphics. The one place X-Plane clearly outshines the competitors, even with Quest + Link, is in flight dynamics. The better flight model is the closest to real GA airplanes of any sim I've found. The behavior of the glider is extremely close to the real thing.

Aside from the Quest+Link problem, it's clear that VR is still a second class citizen in X-Plane. Using the controllers in the cockpit is unimaginably frustrating. Teleporting is so readily available that many times I've accidentally bumped the thumbstick and suddenly found  myself standing on the ground, watching my plane fly off in the distance. Trying to turn most of the knobs in the cockpit is extremely difficult. The trick is to pause the sim, put your face right in front of the knob and patiently, slowly twist back and forth until you finally land on the frequency or setting you need. Even more frustrating since MS-FSX doesn't have that problem. Another option (oddly the best one for me) is to pause the sim (or turn on the autopilot) lift the headset, click on the radio, then adjust it in 2D on the monitor. You will also need to fix the VR cockpit settings file for each airplane to put your head in a reasonable place in the cockpit. There are no avatars in X-Plane, so why is it so hard to position the head?

A note to all would be VR flight simmers: It seems that for any kind of reasonable experience in any VR flight sim, you need a joystick/yoke with as many buttons to map as possible. I've tried to use on the controllers in VR and it's only good for short, scenic flights. Holding a heading or vertical speed while doing something else in the cockpit doesn't work well at all.

runs great and performs for a flight sim. It looks absolutely stunning in VR on the Oculus Rift S. Lots of free addons to download from the community website, and LOTS of payware you can buy from Laminar Research themselves, and the community. This goes for planes, mods, and scenery addons. However i dont really reccomend buying anything unless you will really stick with it. Addons get expensive, especially the planes. Most of the ones made by the community start at 30-40 dollars and only go up in price drastically. That is not to say that they aren't excellently made however, just something to watch out for. A free plane I would recommend for beginners is the Zibo 737-800X. Its completely free and has the quality of most payware aircraft you would buy for 40 dollars and up. 

Enough about the content though. Its a bit of a learning curve, like most simulators. They have training lessons for flying a Cessna 172 Skyhawk. Basic things like controls and how to read the gauges. Highly reccomend playing through them and paying attention if you are new to flying. However for the other planes its gonna be a little research to figure out how to g et them up and going, especially the airliners like the boeing 737, 747 etc. For me, learning about how they work is half the fun. Actually getting the plane started from a cold and dark state and taking off successfully is the other half. Trust me, its extremely satisfying. Definitely an acquired taste, however.

In comparison to other flight sims i have played, its a big upgrade from Microsoft Flight Simulator X. and Honestly? i still enjoy it better than the new Microsoft Flight Sim 2020. I own it on the microsoft store, and at its best its more like eye candy to me. The graphics are real fancy but it doesn't run all that well, and the controls are extremely wonky. I have tried calibrating my yoke and controls devices several times through windows, and the game cannot have a smooth moving axis with it. Its terrible. In X-Plane 11, the controls are absolutely excellent, the best i have experienced in any flight sim. It has an in game calibration menu, unlike MSFS 2020. The UI is just way more intuitive in X-Plane.

Overall a 9/10 for the whole experience. I choose this game over MSFS 2020 any day. This game really shines with access to free community addons and your own intuition to learn. :)

This is the quintessential flight simulator for simmers and real pilots. Under normal circumstances, that would be enough said. This is not one of those times.

I played Microsoft's offerings since FS98. As a child, those titles inspired me to take on the challenge for real as a young adult. This led directly to a career in aviation in the US Armed Forces, where I applied that passion for nearly 10 years. It's fair to say that I owe a great deal of my life's passion to the Microsoft titles.

THAT BEING SAID...

As I matured as a gamer and as a real world pilot, I have come to appreciate X-Plane for what it is; a tool for the connoisseur. It feels better, plays smoother, puts polish where it counts. Its more well rounded, even if it lacks some of the in-your-face spit shine of its competitor. A quick verification of this fact can be done simply be popping onto YouTube and seeing how many of the real-world pilot "lets plays" use X-Plane as the basis of their content. It always works as intended, and generally feels the "realest" to those acquainted with the nuances of civil aviation methodologies and procedures. While I can't help but take a moment here or there to jump back into MSFS and luxuriate in its latest and greatest, there always seems to be a gut feeling of something missing for me. 

That feeling is gone 25 minutes after starting cold and dark in a B738 on a ramp, FINALLY having made it to the apron and ready for departure. Every switch and knob correctly set (by me). The ND lit up with all my constraints and flight path. EICAS says everything I want it to, autopilot set and ready to engage TOGA.

Then I take off and totally bork the SID, not because the sim is flawed and I'm having to RP a workaround for missing systems, but because after 15 years of flying IRL and 20 in sims, I'm still the worlds okayest pilot.

Thank you Laminar Research for your fantastic title and for consistently reminding me that I suck.

Often lose the ability to control the plane with a mouse, being unable to open up the steering box again. I know this game isn't meant to be played with a mouse so this is probably low priority but, still.

However, it's a lip sync service as the piece of garbage can't break 600 knots diving into the ground from 70k ft. But, it does go to 70k ft at 400 knots or so on a slow climb. Can probably speed this up with some more knowledge but.... no thanks. If this thing can't break 600 knots in level flight wtf is the point? Hey devs you know this plane does mach 3+ w/o trying, right? FIX IT FIX IT FIX IT FIX IT FIX IT FIX IT FIX IT FIX IT FIX IT FIX IT FIX IT FIX IT FIX IT FIX IT FIX IT FIX IT!!!!

Game also threw me for an engine failure on a landing which was really awesome to gain emergency experience. I think this was intentional and not a bug. Otherwise, another bug.

So, it's not all negative but, enough of it is for a bad review since there isn't neutral review and I wouldn't recommend a game with more bugs then a stray dog has fleas. Plus the utterly shameful representation of the greatest machine to ever fly.
