The Boeing 737 series is a long running series of civilian airliners, built in the narrow-body twin jet configuration. The 737 is the flagship product of the Boeing company, after the 787, 777, 767, 757 and 747 models, designed to compete against Airbus’s A320neo. As a civilian airliner it strives to be the safest and most efficient model yet. In 2018 and 2019, two 737 MAXs, a fourth generation aircraft, crashed in two different flights, severing the company’s stark reputation and grounding more than 300 aircraft around the world. The underlying problem primarily at its core was the MCAS (Maneuvering Characteristics Augmentation System) system, which was provided as a safety feature on the flights of Lion Air 610 and Ethiopian Airline 302. The MCAS system used a fragile system which put the passengers of all 737 MAX flights at risk, by tricking the system into thinking the plane was diving or stalling, which altered the yoke input leading to a wrestle of control between the pilots and the aircraft.

The 737 series was conceived in 1964, when Boeing was looking to replace its ageing 727s currently in service. The lineup began as the 737-100, which utilised JT8D low-bypass ratio turbofans, which began service with Lufthansa in 1968. Known as the “Original” series, this included the 737-100 and 737-200. The second generation “Classic” consisted of the 737-300, 400 and 500, launched in 1979 with increased length and capacity. The third generation “NG” (New Generation) gave birth to the 737-600, 700, 800 and 900 series with the fourth and most recent generation of 737s, the “MAX” series was developed to compete against Airbus’s A320neo series. With the ability to hold 138 to 204 passengers, it comes equipped with high-bypass ratio turbofans, CFM International LEAP engines which provide 160kN of thrust with 16% increased efficiency over older models, as well as an engine nacelle with chevrons built in to reduce noise. The first 737 MAX fuselage was finished in mid 2015, with flight testing beginning in early 2016. The first order was delivered to a subsidiary of Lion Air in May 2017. Going for $121.6 million each aircraft, the 737 MAX ferried 6.5 million people in 41,000 flights for 1118,000 hours in its first year of service. On October 29th, 2018, a Lion Air’s 737 MAX 8 crashed into the Java sea, and a year later on March 10th, 2019, an Ethiopian Airlines 737 MAX crashed near the town of Bishoftu in Ethiopia.

Lion Air’s Flight 610 took off at 6:20am on 29 October 2018 from Jakarta’s runway 25L, heading for Pangkal Pinang, scheduled to arrive at 7:20am. Heading west from the initial takeoff, it circled around until it leveled off and continued climbing in a northeasterly direction. Contact with the aircraft was lost at 6:33am, and air traffic control contacted authorities. After three ships and a helicopter were dispatched to the predicted crash zone, authorities reported that Flight 610 had crashed into the Java sea with 189 fatalities. Workers on a nearby offshore oil rig reported seeing the plane nosedive into the 35m deep waters at a steep angle. Boats dispatched from the oil rig later reported debris floating in the waters. A similar turn of events happened to Ethiopian Airlines Flight 302, when ATC lost contact with the aircraft 6 minutes after takeoff from Addis Ababa and found its wreckage close to the town of Bishoftu. The cause of both crashes was determined to be the MCAS (Maneuvering Characteristics Augmentation System) by investigating authorities. MCAS is a flight control law or software embedded in Boeing 737 MAXs, and deals with the automatic controls of the aircraft’s pitch. The system was included in the 737 to assist with the aerodynamics of the new leap engines, where it would need to pitch the aircraft up or down according to readings from the AoA (angle of attack) sensor. As an automated corrective measure for the safety of the aircraft, it could not be overridden by the pilots, so any faulty readings by the AoA sensor could result in the system forcing the aircraft in a nosedive, as was the case on both 737 MAX flights. Both sensors on both aircraft fed misinformation to the system resulting in the plane being visualised as pitching too high by the system. The motor unit in the tail of the aircraft as well as the yoke kept on pitching the aircraft’s trim down to account for the fake AoA resulting in a nosedive. Since the system was running off a single AoA sensor, the entire unit was susceptible to SPOF (Single Point Of Failure), where if one component fails, the entire system would too.

The requirement of MCAS came from the larger LEAP engine Boeing opted for the 737 MAX. The larger radius of the engines made it so that aircraft would pitch up very steeply if the AoA reached a certain amount. Instead of an aerodynamic option, Boeing selected to use the MCAS system, as it would not need to retrain pilots. Initial testing of the AoA sensor gathered that it could result in it not working, although it was not catastrophic and the pilots could respond to it. This was overlooked by the FAA (Federal Aviation Administration) when the system was deemed as approved for earlier models of the MCAS. As a result of the two crashes, aviation authorities around the globe have grounded all 737 MAX flights, costing Boeing $18.6 billion USD by March with further costs predicted due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with the FAA revoking airworthiness for each individual 737 MAX. Boeing suspended all production of the 737 MAXs, estimating that an ungrounding of aircraft could happen in mid 2020. 

Airbus, Boeing’s main competitor, was unwilling to put the blame on Boeing’s engineering, as the certification of products by aircraft manufacturers was considered tough. Around 200 aircraft leases have been canceled, with many undelivered aircraft now residing in Boeing Park, Seattle, Washington. As an engineering failure overlooked in the design and testing phase, the MCAS system could have been given a backup system or failsafe to give the flawed system some redundancy, in case a component fails. It could have also been given the aerodynamic refit, which was not chosen for costs, and this undermined the safety of the aircraft. Overall, the MCAS system was given full authority of the aircraft which made the pilots unable to control their aircraft in case of flawed sensor inputs. This resulted in two 737 MAX crashes claiming 347 lives, from the simple decision to overlook a design flaw.

X-Plane 11 is a good flight sim. It has really helped me to fall in love with the whole flight industry. It gives you the opportunity to fly a variety of aircraft you can only image being in control of. The graphics are fantastic, the settings and configurations are easy to navigate and the add-ons through X-Plane.org are so good and varied. I just love the professional flight experience what X-Plane 11 has to offer. I just love cold starting aircraft, figuring out how the instruments work and flying anywhere around the world in GA, business jets and helicopters. I’m still relatively new so I haven’t figured out how to fly commercial jets yet but that’s the great thing with X-Plane 11, there’s always something new, challenging and exciting to learn. The only negative is CRASH, CRASH, CRASH, CRASH!!!....You will be forever fixing crash problems,  tweeking, updating, looking on forums to help resolve problems, and fixing random problems. Also, the load times take forever, even after buying a 1TB SSD just for this sim alone. It runs a tiny bit faster but still waiting and wasting several minutes of my life each time before the sim loads up. All in all this sim is a love hate relationship.

XPlane 11 != Microsoft Flight Simulator. In fact XPlane 11 > Microsoft Flight Simulator.

I have played XPlane for a long time (as well as the Microsoft Flight Simulator franchise) and recently migrated from XPlane 9 to XPlane 11.

This is a great simulator typical of XPlane. The game has good graphics for the era it was released in.

As always one of the major strengths of XPlane is the flight modelling which one notices right away versus Microsoft Flight Simulator.

XPlane aircraft are more realistic in look, feel, operation, and workflow versus those in Microsoft Flight Simulator.

There are some areas I would love to see expanded in the next rendition of XPlane (not criticisms rather requests for enhancements): more expressive and functional ATC, more realistic/vibrant color palette, more land marks, more stock aircraft, and better mapping and flight planning capabilities.

It is not the graphical masterpiece that Microsoft Flight Simulator is (that is about all Microsoft Flight Simulator does well currently), after all it is from a different generation of graphics cards and capabilities, but still look phenomenal.

I have experienced one bug, in full screen mode the simulator hangs indefinitely on loads. I have not had this happen in windowed mode.

Buy XPlane even if you have Microsoft Flight Simulator, buy XPlane even if you do not have Microsoft Flight Simulator...

I bought this because I was sick of MSFS - Asobo acknowledging an egregious error with their flight model (the Flaps Debacle) and refusing to fix it (suggesting players manually mod their own planes) was the last straw.

With X-Plane, the physics are not only functional but they're even somewhat accurate. Aircraft systems are functional, even with the stock models. That includes avionics - the stock G1000 works better than any patch mod for MSFS available. The sim doesn't take 4 hours to load up, and frame rates are high. You don't have to worry about devs that have never seen an airplane before breaking some random mechanic in the latest scenery update because the game has been out forever. It's a game focused on the airplane and operating the airplane. 

Summary:
Graphics - scenery is trash. Aircraft are decent and not unpleasant to be inside during a flight.
Physics - high-quality. When I was in college there were some researchers that used X-Plane 11 to develop autopilots for novel flight concept demonstrator UAS's. Ground physics are bad though.
Controller support - excellent. The game recognized my X-52 stick/throttle and rudder pedals right away and calibration/remap was easy. Plenty of button bindings available, but I haven't found a bind for Parking Brake yet which is kind of annoying. I just tap the brakes to release if the cockpit object doesn't work or is hidden.
Simulation - very good. Icing is exaggerated greatly, landing gear model isn't bad but isn't good. Flight model is great. Aircraft systems work well. Avionics work correctly but NAV databases aren't kept current by the stock game (not a huge deal).
Overall - is it a better flight simulator than MSFS? Yes, MSFS isn't a flight sim and this is very much a flight sim. Is it a better game than MSFS? yep. Better value? Absolutely. It's not graphically stunning like MSFS and you don't get a headlamp for a dark cockpit, but in every other way X-Plane wins hands-down.
EDIT - You actually get a way better flashlight in X-Plane.

It should be a positive review since it is a great simulator but Laminar are relying too much on 3rd party paid addons (or free but very time consuming) for me to give this product a positive review. I will review X-Plane 11 alongside Microsoft Simulator 2020 so you can make a sound choice at the end. I own both product and I am not biased in any way.

After $500 investing into X-Plane 11 now I would give it a positive review but the stock version simply isn't there. You must absolutely buy third-party planes (or download the 737-800 Zibo and only fly this plane since it's free and competitive with the most expansive addons).

I guess what I am trying to say is the amount of money invested that will be obsolete when X-Plane 12 launch is simply not allowing me to post a good review. But in term of pure physics and systems simulation and what can be achieved with the  SDK it currently beats Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020. The open airports edits to push changes by the community when X-Plane launch an update is a very nice addition that at least makes all default major airports pretty realistic with correct number of gates, ground marking for them, correct taxiway indications. If you install Airport Environment HD it is even better with the sort of parking lines (with by-airplane stop indications) and beautiful taxiway signs and better runways textures (navigational aids, taxiway signs, aprons, runways all redone) but again, it is a addon. Free but Laminar could have done an equally good job.

So to resume, Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020, out of the box, beats X-Plane 11, less need to be invested in addons but the physics is not as good, no airliners can fly properly unless you download the free FlyByWire Airbus A320neo addons that basically replace the original neo withan almost study level plane. The live weather, airacs, traffics, amazingly detailed topography, cities and the magic is that the game use data streaming to give you astonishing graphics while keeping the game size relatively small so they can expand with each updates without passing the 300 GB mark at update 1.

 Downsides of MSFS2020 are the upsides of X-Plane 11. MSFS Need for a public airports database for people to do edits the currently extremely not accurately depicted airports that can be reviewed and pushed in updates like X-Plane. Better physics and systems sim, better airports ground markings. Right now all the default airport all have only a yellow line for taxiway so no taxiway markings part from the yellow line, only two markings and it's for the ramps such as the stop line for glideslope and the other a little bit further as the last stop before getting clearance to enter the runway and perform takeoff.  For the moment the MSFS2020 SDK is not completed and it is a major reason why there are no 3rd-party quality planes. By 2022 the Asobo's simulator published by Microsoft should have a decent payware and freeware ecosystem, much like X-Plane 11.

If you want a simulator that is beautiful out-of-the box and bet on the future (X-Plane 11 has stagnated). get Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020.
Graphics are of course, okay, but, the flight dynamics are spot on.

A fantastic basis for a study-level aviation sim, but with a single big caveat:

To really get the most enjoyment out of this game, you're going to need to spend time, money, or both. If you spend the time hunting down freeware addons, plugins, etc., you can have a great experience without spending a cent. Planes like the Zibo 737-800, graphics meshes, cloud plugins, so much to consider and places like /r/xplane are your friend.

If you have deep pockets, the world is yours and the sky is literally the limit. Excellent payware planes that offer challenging study-level accuracy like the FlyJSim 727, detailed pay terrain, weather engines, and the list goes on. MSFS may be better out of the box for sheer visual beauty, but XP11 is still king of the kingdom when it comes to power, wealth of third-party support, and flexibility.

And if you're considering choosing one of the two, on a very simplified level look at it this way: MSFS20 is your iPhone, and XP11 is your Android. One is really slick, simplified, and easy to dive into out of the box at the expense of third party support (for now) and accuracy. The other has a massive list of free and paid extra content, most of which is fundamentally high quality, and if you don't mind investing the time tweaking and tinkering, can offer a much deeper and more rewarding experience.

[h1] TL;DR [/h1]
[b]If you're trying to find out which sim is better than the other, MSFS or X-Plane the answer is neither. Both sims are fundamentally different.[/b]


There are lot of differences between the X-Plane series and Microsoft Flight simulator. I have been using both since X-Plane 9 and MSFS-X, and generally speaking the differences that follow remain the same across all versions of both simulators. Personally I feel that one is not better than the other, rather what are you trying to get out of it? 

There are pros and cons to both of them. X-Plane features full cockpit functionality to all of the aircraft in the vanilla game, as well as a lot of realistic features that MSFS doesn't even come close to. It's much less casual and unforgiving, and pressing the wrong button or over stressing the aircraft can have catastrophic consequences, if that's what you're looking for. Microsoft flight simulator even on the maximum realism settings is still pretty forgiving as far as the flight models for the aircraft are concerned. MSFS 2020 put more of their priorities into optimizing a game that's basically eye candy, so a lot of other features were skimped out.

Unfortunately X-Plane doesn't have an updated FMC database of all the NAV way points and airports, MSFS 2020 does. In order to get updated NAV aids for X-Plane you need to install Payware. (I'm sure there's free options but I've found that those are usually restricted to one region, or very hard to find from a reliable source in general.) Similarly to MSFS, there is no multi-crew feature, however X-Plane on its own with no plugins has NO MULTIPLAYER whatsoever. However both sims do support Add-on economy/tycoon software that adds a lot of replay-ability. If you have the money for it, I would recommend just getting both.
Even though XPlane is dying because of msfs, I still use Xplane for testing things such as crash physics and failures!
Great game, good for aspiring pilots like me too!

This is an excellent flight simulator. As it stands in January 2021, this sim remains more polished than its counterparts. The mod community for this sim is second to none and that is a credit to Laminar Research for making modding so accessible.
Just make sure your fps is not costantly below 20fps or you will fly slowly

Pros:
- Really easy to mod
- Amazing cockpit detail
- Amazing amount of airports to choose from
- Pretty good graphics in cities
- Relatively bug-free apart from the odd glitch here and there
- Amazing ATC

Cons:
- Less than fantastic audio.  Ex: Wheels hitting the runway sound like they were taken right out of tank simulator
- Trees and houses have no collision whatsoever
- The in-game maps purely suck
- JESUS CHRIST THE DLC'S ARE EXPENSIVE
- Lack Of Multiplayer Support

Overall, I would recommend this game if you want a step up from MFS X but don't want to spend all the money to get MFS 2020.  If you have the money, I would still get MFS 2020.

This has been my go to flight simulator for years. I do own the other big ones, however, this one is still the best and most realistic in terms of flight model compared to flying in real life; in my experience. I have presently over 600 hours clocked in this sim. Many hours before that in X-Plane 10 and thousands of hours flying in general.

Fairly recently we have seen a new big sim enter the market. It’s much much prettier than X-Plane and it does look very promising already. However, it’s not an X-Plane killer by any means. They both have strengths and weaknesses and the audiences may not be the same. X-Plane is not about eye candy even though you can make it fairly pretty using add-ons, but the real strength of X-Plane is its realistic flight model.

When it comes to flight simming it really doesn’t have to be one or the other. Personally, I use three for different purposes. Luckily, we have seen quite a few strong study level sims coming to X-Plane. So you’re not stuck with whatever sim PMDG and/or A2A produce aircraft for. There are alternative players for the X-Plane market that are absolutely on par when talking about system depth and simulation.

As said, X-Plane is not the prettiest out of the box for sure but there is an enormous catalogue of add-ons and a huge portion of them are free add-ons made by the community.

Also, the creator of X-Plane has very exciting plans for the future development of this sim, so it shall remain strong and attractive for serious simmers. The things you may dislike about it or stuff that only bothers you somewhat are also already on the minds of the developers and the creator and are already things they want to change, optimise, and just make better.

I could go on but I’ll end it here by saying that I can wholeheartedly recommend X-plane to anyone; experienced pilots and newcomers alike.

Hi hello, welcome to my review of XP11.

I wanted to make this review to tell you guys about this amazing flight simulator, Let me start off by saying that Graphics and the scenery of the world are not the best as MSFS has taken that crown BUT and there's a big T H I C C  B U T, X-Plane has a fantastic simulation to physics of the aircraft and this is what does it for me, don't get me wrong I genuinely enjoy flying in MSFS with all its navigation bugs and issues it has but X-Plane takes the crown in Flight physics and this is really important to me, just the fact I can set my autopilot and expect it to do what it's being told to just does it for me, MSFS makes it easy for people to set everything up but it's not truly Cold and Dark, This is what X-Plane does really well. you get in the aircraft do your checks follow procedures and all works as expected. 

don't get me started on the amazing Zibo 737 that upgrades the default 737, I highly recommend anyone who buys XP11 to try Zibo 737 even if you are an Airbus fanboy like me you will enjoy flying the Zibo 737. 

You can make X-Plane 11 Look amazing by using reshade and downloading many great graphical addons that can be found for free on the X-Plane forum for FREE! yes FREE, the X-Plane community is amazing!

Listen I will be honest here, only buy this Flight Simulator if you really are someone who likes Study level aircraft and if you are someone who has the time and can go through the effort to make it look eye candy and if you are looking for a flight simulator that has good physics. 

if not then stick to MSFS as that's easier to deal with and you will enjoy your self while flying around the world :) 

X-Plane 11 will stay on my hard drive even if I have and use MSFS.

I'm happy again with X-Plane 11. I've rated it negative before because i have had massive problems with using my Windows Mixed Reality Controllers in VR-mode of X-Plane 11. Every Time i have started the sim an error message was shown ("Error reading joystick configuration (.joy) file" and the controllers did not work. Sometimes X-Plane 11 crashed after confirming this error message.

Thsnks to an user in X-Plane.org forum i was able to fix (or better to avoid) this error by loading X-Plane 11 directly from "Windows Desktop" in the "Cliffhouse" (WMR VR start environment) by choosing "Play X-Plane in VR" instead of launching it from "Steam Home".

This seems to be the same, but doing so is avoiding the error message and the controllers are working fine.

And i can finally fly again after nearly one whole sad year of "non flying".

In the meantime i've hoped that switching to FS2020 is an option, but they have only VR light (no support of VR controllers, you have to use keyboard, mouse and joystick, realy really embarrassing), 

But no matter, now, X-Plane 11 is my baby again and i will use it with joy.  FS2020 with it's crappy vr can go to hell :-)

Maybe Laminar Research read this sometimes and put some efford in fixing this error, so users can start the game like it should be. And maybe my review helps somebody who have the same problems like me.

Thanks for reading ;o)

I've started out with the very first version of X-Plane when it came out up to V11. This version with VR on the Oculus is almost impossible to describe. The best way is to just think that YOU are sitting in a real cockpit of a variety of aircraft. Your eyes and brain is tricked into thinking all is REAL!!! I just got the Oculus this week and now after trying X-Plane I will NEVER got back to playing any flight sim in 2D, it stinks! Tonight I tried out the fighter jet and was just so blown away. Fortunately, I am not scared of heights nor do get motion sickness. Someone that has these two things, forget about doing VR it will make you sick as can be! But if you are up to it, X-Plane is the one to get. The graphics are smooth on my computer, I can set almost to the highest of all settings, the world looks so real, I wish to thank the developers of this program and all of the past versions. Its no telling how many hours I've spent on it. I am NOT a pilot, but when I was in the Air Force, I was in a Tactical Air Control Party (TACP), we are the ones who conduct airstrikes. I think I have at least 4,000 hours of flight time. As a passenger our pilots taught us how to fly so just in case something happens to them, we would be able to safely return to base without crashing! Now with the Oculus and X-Plane I get to relive my flying days although I am fully retired after 44 years of service! This is beyond exciting! On a scale of 1 to 10, I give a 10, totally big thumbs up! I highly recommend this flight sim for 2D or VR, its great for both, but VR is the way to go!

I got this prior to the COVID lock down while it was on sale and purchased the Saitek Pro yoke and throttle bundle separately. As far as training equipment goes for students learning to be pilots it's quite a good investment. The controls can feel a bit wonky sometimes and the simulation itself can only go so far to simulate the real deal, but overall its a realistic experience. It really shines if you are practicing instrument flying, emergency scenarios that you'd best not try in real life, and pattern work to get used to certain procedures. It also has maps of just about every airport around the world so if you are planning a trip it can help to try it a couple of times in the sim before flying there for real. I should also point out that you will need a moderately powerful graphics card to run the sim on higher settings. It is still decent on the lower settings but it can make certain airports and areas harder so aim to be able to run it on the higher settings to get the most out of it. Overall a great purchase.

I am not impressed at all. Out of the box you get only a hand full of aircraft to fly with. The AI aircraft doesn't seem to really go anywere and just swarm around you. When I reload a saved flight, I start with all my engines and batteries off, mid flight - X Plane doesn't seem to save the state of aircraft properly. I had random crashes.. Sound doesn't work after these crashes and requires a re-install..

All in all I'm surprised that people compare this to MFS. This feels like an open-ended product that gives you barely enough. Sure the physics and simulation itself seems good, but this is a simulator that heavily relies on 3rd party plugins to function properly. If you get this game, you'll probably enjoy it, but prepare yourself to google a lot and use plenty of 3rd party plugins and aircraft. For a paid game, you just don't get enough.

I'm going back to MFS. Sure, MS is known for giving issues after updates, but at least they get the basics right. Buying X-Plane, I was expecting a product like MFS in terms of value for money. I mean they are compared like they are almost the same thing. In my opinion, MFS is years ahead.

TLDR:
- If you want a simulator that will work out of the box and include more than you need, go for MFS.
- If you want a simulator that offers enough to get started, you don't mind using plenty of plugins and perhaps want to create your own, go for X Plane.

"It's a good flight simulator.
Has some pros and cons." - Me at 164hrs

Revisiting this review after an additional 220hrs, and 60-something hours on MSFS2020 (about ~30hrs actual, not including download etc.)

What I noticed immediately on firing up X-Plane after an extended amount of time away following the release of MSFS2020, is the crispness of the displays, the resolution and definition of the landscape.

There's also something about the flight characteristics of the aircraft.  I can't put my finger on it, but flight feels a little more satisfying than the newer sim.

What about the landscape? Well, there's no getting away from it. X Plane's scenery can appear bland, with sometimes repetitive textures. But at times it shines, with beautiful mountain vista's fading into the distance. I also feel a degree of, dare I say it, nostalgia  for the way the landscape is generated. Digital elevation maps combined with land class data and open street map information are blended together to recreate the globe. Is it perfect? No. But it is an amazing technological feat. And it is stored locally on your own PC. Is that important? Only if your online scenery servers become unavailable...which I experienced a few days ago with the other sim. Coming back after flying around the VFR marvel of MSFS2020 is like coming back to a low-poly world, but that's not necessarily a bad thing.

X Plane 11 is a fine simulator, but it is not going to be everyone's cup of tea. I feel like I've spent as much time tweaking it for performance and improvements as I have spent flying it. There's a strong community dedicated to creating plugins, add-ons, aircraft, and environments. I've made a few airports myself and uploaded them to the X Plane Scenery Gateway. If they're accepted they will likely be included in future releases. It's easy to get involved.

I have had a great time with X Plane 11, and it's still got life left in it.

Pros: More realistic than FSX, nice to have between Cessna training sessions. Absolutely gorgeous graphics and you can even replicate infamous incidents.

Cons: Not even close to the level of community add-ons as FSX and the add-ons this sim does have are almost all payware.

Having played for decades with the different versions of Microsoft Flight Simulator I became interested in the new version of Microsoft FS2020. But I soon found out that MS FS2020 would not get a high enough framerate on my current computer (I7-4790 16GB and GTX-760). So I  tried X-Plane 11 as next best. After playing 65 hours with X-plane 11 I can state that I have no regrets what so ever. Yes, the autogenerated buildings could be better. Yes, the weather engine of MS FS2020 looks better. But I had 65 hours of real simulationtime, no severe bugs, no unreal looking oversaturated-colors like MS FS2020 has and no missing airports which should have been included (like Eindhoven in MS FS2020). With the addition of Ortho4XP scenery and ORBX Terraflora I can even state that many times the world in X-plane 11 looks even better than the one in MS FS2020. But even without Ortho4XP the scenery is convincing. I even make pictures during the flight and post it on a photography site and get good comments. What I also like is the fact that the Cessna 172 looks a bit dirty round the windows and even has scratches in the glass. So I probably will stick with X-Plane 11 until MS FS2020 is fully matured or when X-Plane 12 is introduced. At this moment I recommend X-Plane 11, which is a bargain when it is on Sale.

Microsoft Flight Simulator is better looking, performers better, requires less fiddling, has lots more default aircraft and tons more flashy features. I own every plane in its marketplace, have over 150 logged hours in it, and am genuinely impressed by it every time I open it.

I still wound up reinstalling X-Plane, and I enjoy flying in it more. Right now, the aircraft available, although pricey, are better. There's nothing even close to the quality that Aerobask provides in MSFS. Flying in X-Plane feels challenging, exciting, and much better. The planes have weight. The process of starting up and managing the planes in flight is more fiddly, and requires you to really understand the planes and their systems.

Maybe one day MSFS will be there. It's not now. While I love to explore the MSFS map, I cannot deny that flying in X-Plane is the most satisfying (even for VFR) and it won't be leaving my hard drive any time soon.

I know it's weird to review this by simply comparing it to something else, but MSFS is a giant in a space that's largely been niche software for av nerds. It's just that good.

Finding a good, modern flight simulator on Linux these days doesn’t leave you with too many options. You could always stick with the classics like FlightGear or the recently released Aerofly FS 2 Flight Simulator, but what if you want the ultimate flight sim experience?

This is where Laminar Research comes in with their X-Plane 11 flight simulator a modern take on flight sims built for more current hardware. The original version of X-Plane 8.20 for Linux came out in 2005. Since then, the X-Plane series has become the gold standard for flight simulators not only on the Linux desktop but also on Mac and Windows.

What makes X-Plane 11 so unique?

Unlike it's biggest competitor FS2020 (which is only available for Windows), X-Plane is a true flight simulator and not a pick up your game pad and land with 280 knots type of game. It's unmatched in terms of realism, aircraft detail, flight model, customizability and controls. While FS2020 does indeed have a vast selection of available aircraft along with impressive eye-candy scenery (only when you are connected to the MS server); the flight models and instrument responses to control inputs (compared to X-Plane) seem arcade-like at best.

I have approx. 430 flying hours (private aviation) and roughly 1218 hours in X-Plane since version 8.20. Comparing my real world experience to FSX, FS2020, FlightGear, Aerofly FS 2 Flight Simulator and X-Plane 11, I have to say that X-Plane is by far the most realistic and complex flight sim on the market; it will have even the most seasoned flight stick-jockeys in awe of its precision.

Let me elaborate why:
Most flight simulators have based their flight models on a combination of empirical data and computational arrays of data (also known as lookup tables). This can save a lot of time (and therefore money), but it doesn’t get at the individual feel of flying an aircraft.

What sets X-Plane apart from other flight simulators is its use of blade element theory, which actually forms the basis for those data arrays I mentioned earlier. This method involves the breaking down of a propeller blade into smaller parts. From there, the effects of the forces enacted upon the sections of the blade are determined. Once this has been done, the forces are merged along the entire length of the blade and one rotor revolution. By the end of this process, the forces and moments produced by the whole propeller and/or rotor have been obtained.

These forces include but are not limited to:

•Thrust
•Lift
•Force
•Torque/radius
•Drag
•Blade tip speed
•Induced speed
•Angle of attack
•And much more..

X-Plane devs take this process used for propellers and apply it to the entire aircraft. This more intensive form of data gathering creates a truer flight simulator experience. It helps devs & designers create a more “real world” experience than other forms of data gathering used in flight simulators like FlightGear, FS2020, Aerofly FS 2 Flight Simulator and so on.

In addition, X-Plane 11 includes a Plane Maker application to make your own airplanes and helicopters, Airfoil Maker to make airfoils for custom aircraft. This is designed from the ground-up to be an experience you craft for yourself, and others. Also new to X-Plane 11 is Flight School, so now you can go through the basics and complexities of flight to get acquainted with the physics and handling of a single engine airplane or helicopter. With patience and practice, you will be able to figure it out, and it will be well worth it!

Also novice and veteran pilots use X-Plane for training, there are plenty of videos on the internet where you can watch them train and share their experiences.

The fidelity and immersion of this simulator is impressive.  I have flown a variety of simulators over 30 years, and X-Plane 11 is easily one of the most realistic-feeling and visually immersive.  

It is not, however, especially well documented.  Provided aircraft manuals are basic, and teaching myself to fly aircraft I have flown for years in other simulators is frustrated by inadequate checklists and incomplete instructions.  Even "starting with engines running and electrical systems up" is insufficient.  It took dozens of hours of trial and error, and searching community advice to work out startup procedures for the King Air 90 which did not exhaust the battery or overload the generators / inverter.  Cabin pressurisation instructions completely neglected to mention turning on bleed-air, for example, or the merits of monitoring cabin temperatures.

I like an active community of supportive enthusiasts, some of whom fly these aircraft professionally, but when a simulator is this detailed and modelled so well, some extra time and effort might be spent on providing equally detailed materials or at least downloadable libraries of checklists for default aircraft.  I came close to giving up on this simulator before I chanced to find videos and casual references in forums which helped me connect the dots.  I expect to keep doing so as I fly and learn to fly new aircraft for this simulator.

Amazing work, all, truly.  I'd just love for the learning process to be a little less hit and miss.

My original review back a few weeks after picking up X-plane read as follows:

"Quite simply the flight dynamics make this a worthy upgrade to FSX or P3D. Add in some great scenery in the way of the free Ortho addon and you've got a great sim!"

HOWEVER, after many months of battling, I have to change my mind entirely.

While I have something like 1000 hours in-game, I'd guess that a good 30% of that was spent in troubleshooting, re-installing, re-configuring, and re-loading after crashes. 

I have spent endless hours trying to get X-plane to run smoothly and predictably with or without plugins, with or without addon scenery, and with or without external programs. I have reached my end and now loading this dated and VERY poorly optimized sim becomes instantly frustrating. 

I have been trying, primarily, to deal with out-of-memory errors wherein memory use spikes and causes a HARD system lock up. I just can't do it anymore and have given up entirely, moving onto MSFS as it is ultra stable and smooth-running for me. 

I know I'm not alone in these issues but we're in the minority. For what it's worth, I've had these same issues on two different desktops and two different laptops, all of which exceed the 'requirements' of the game. I also know a lot of people have X-plane working smoothly and predictably but I just never got there.

Oh yes, Xplane 11 is everything I've ever wanted in VR Aircraft simulation. You don't need an expensive cockpit, or controllers, just your touch controllers will do. The graphics are dated, but the game plays well in VR and the cockpits look amazing. If you have scenery files for your desired flight area, it'll make it that much more immersive. 

Be aware though this is a mid to high level gaming experience. Having knowledge of aircraft and air traffic flow is very much needed. This game will not hand hold a novice pilot. 

It def has a steep learning curve so be ready to do research and learn how to control your aircraft. These things are modeled in "easy mode" for users, simplifying the controls for a novice pilot. If you're looking for a fully realistic plane, you'll need to buy ones from 3rd party developers. The only down side to this game is if you want the best experience, with the most realistic simulation be ready to fork over money for those plugins. Some are worth it, others are just garbage. 

So far this is the only VR simulation software I've found that doesn't require expensive controllers. I already have the touch controllers so this makes using the virtual cockpit controls perfect. You can interact with every button and knob in the cockpit that is available. Sensitivity is pretty high as well so you'll have to adjust. Once I got the hang of the controls the game was very easy to use.

With all that being said I've spent the first 14 hours of my game play trying to tweak the settings well enough to be able to have decent visuals in VR. The code for the game is highly unoptimized for VR play. I have a beast of a system and can play the game fine on max graphics on flat screen but attempting to do that in VR is impossible. I get 6 FPS on max in VR while flat screen I can lock 185fps which is the max my monitor can do. I'm hoping but not optimistic about VR getting some love later on. Maybe X-Plane 12 if it ever comes out will do it much better.

I want to get a PPL license. Though PPL requires 40hrs minimum, average pilots need up to 80-120 hrs of flight training in a plane (costs $150 + gas) and availability of instructor to get to the check ride stage.
Instead of learning & gaining competency of flight maneuvers while spending $$ on an actual plane, I wanted to learn it in a simulator. 
XP11 is the perfect simulator for learning to fly on a Cessna 172.
I use XP11, Gliem XP11 flight training software, Honeycomb Yoke, CH Pedals, custom built throttle and mixture control push rods and Saitek X52 for extra buttons. This is setup to work with Oculus Rift CV1 & Quest 2 with link for simulation in VR.
This makes XP11 the cheapest option to learn to fly & build competency before actually spending money for flight training.
XP11 in VR has its quirks, but do you really want to rent a plane for 40 to 80 extra hours at $150 per hr to learn how to fly?

Even with MS Flight Sim 2020 out now (and I've tried it) I still think X-plane is the better, more realistic flight sim and with some mods (I have HD trees & terrain) even the graphics can be very nice.  X-plane has the better physics, with details like landing gear suspension noticeably compressing upon landing and better detection of hard landings, whereas in MSFS planes kind of artificially bob up and down in the air and on hard landings they bounce like toys.  MSFS does have better eye candy from above, no doubt about it, but it is a more casual game.  Up close the MSFS graphics are a different story though.  I've seen some really crappy, blurry streets and houses.  Those look much better in X-plane.  I think X-plane is the closest you can get to real flying on your PC.

Mixed review after 632 hrs of play.
Updated  

half my time on X-play is spent trying to get things to work!
I hate it! 

Forget buying that new plane thats looks great! Why!  Because they are so poorly documented! Devs rely on the public to figure it out!

3rd party planes often use different mechanisms to control plane than default x-plane planes, the result of this is:

1 cant map hardware controls
2 if you save a situation ( like a snapshot of the plane control settings etc) to practice landings, when the plane loads the engines arent running and abruptly crashes! This is because the way that 3rd party planes control the plane.

Unless you fly the real plane, you will struggle looking for info!

Hardware setting keep changing from plane to plane and everytime you start XP up! 

After uninstalling Navigraph SIMLINK, X-Plane closes like it should.

Pros
-The graphics are great, 
-the selection of payware and freeware planes and mods are great, the Zibo mod is great!
-flight simulation seems reasonable, although Ive never flown, heavy metal.

Cons

Hardware support, my CH Pro Pedals very of very limited functionality, I have spent hours trying to get them to work properly searching forums, contacting CH support. Hardware to work properly must be set through X-Plane, which is more problematic than you can imagine. Controlling nosewheel steering, vs rudder. CH claim its plug and play...but it doesnt in X-Plane, does in DCS.
 
Bugs -Aircraft I use are buggy FF B777 et al requires java which is not listed as a requirement, but is required.
Ive had alot of data corruption (often) with my installation and have to verify file integrity before I use it. No other software has this issue, and my disk cant find any disk errors. 

My hardware allows for 60 fps, with 16gb ram, and 100 gb of free space, Ryzen 1600,  so while not a high end box, its above bare minimum spec.

My usb got briefly disconnected while flying while attempting to plug something into the hub, many of my custom settings were lost, took more than an hour to get joystick back. When initially came back on default setting were applied that were in conflict. So much time wasting figuring out silly things.

Couldnt step thru my FMS flight plan because the map wasnt oriented with North at the top. Not documented, search the forum, so time consuming.

Many issues can be solved, but waste enormous amounts of time searching!
Be prepared to spend time searching for solutions why things dont behave, but the X-Plane forum has been helpful.

All software has its bugs, the aircraft bugs are not X-Planes, issues, but associated with the product and that detract from positve experience.

Many of the issues I have had, dont stop me from flying in X-Plane, but they break the immersion.

People with other hardware and payware aircraft may have different experience than me. I must admit I spend more time trying to get my payware to work properly than flying the planes in the vanilla version of X-Plane 11. Some of the default X-Plane 11 planes are quite good, but suffer from less functionality and eye candy than payware.


Good luck

MSFS2020 is a good game.

This is a good simulator. Mind the difference.

The Good:

Have you ever wanted to try to land a Boeing 737 on an Aircraft Carrier? If so, this is the game for you! You can practice landings, learn about the basics of control and physics using a variety of general aviation and airliner aircraft that are included by default. There are also a few really, REALLY good free downloads like the Robin DR401, the Yak 18, and the Zlin 142 in case you get bored with the Cessna 172. It also includes jet aircraft, such as the SR-71 Blackbird (which goes very, very, VERY fast).

There is also a lot of payware aircraft available. I purchased the Beechcraft Model 76 Duchess from JustFlight, and it is extremely accurate. Steam gauges, complex engines, and a long checklist with systems that all work properly.

The Bad:

I am using the Thrustmaster Flight Control pack for a control setup. The game integrates relatively well with the controls, though I have encountered a few bugs where my airplane just falls from the sky until I reset the application because of my flight controls.

This is a simulator, and it's not meant to be a "fun" game if you are not interested in aviation. You can literally set the auto-pilot on your 737 and go AFK for 2 hours and then come back for the approach and landing. I enjoy General Aviation more than the airliners.

The graphics are kind of bad. This is unfortunate, because it requires hunting around for free content, texture packs, and other modifications if you want to look really nice. Contrast this to the aircraft that are included, which are good enough to stand on their own without requiring free content.

Installing new content requires downloading the content and then manually copying it into the proper file structure. It's a bit annoying and requires some commitment from the user. In one case I had to fiddle with some files and copy/paste between folders to get a Livery to work properly. The Livery in question was the Norwegian Airlines livery for the default 737. It required copying some normal maps from the Quantas Livery into the Norwegian Livery folder to remove an annoying American Airlines logo on the default 737 livery normal map.

Conclusion:

A great simulator for aviation. Though a bit dated, the systems are more accurate than those in Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020. Microsoft Flight Simulator also has fewer payware aircraft, more aircraft with Garmin G1000 suites vs more steam gauges available in X-Plane 11. I have both games and I play MSFS 2020 for the eye candy and I play X-Plane to practice flying the Duchess.
Awesome!
A great global flight simulator.

The handling is much more realistic than FSX and thus less forgiving. SO So actually have to pay attention as you learn to fly. The Scenery tends to be better but I haven't spent much time on MSFS 2020 yet.

X-Plane is a wonderful simulator. The Zibo 737 is hands down the best freeware in any simulator. If you are considering getting XP11 over FS2020, I recommend XP11 if you are needing a study level sim. If you just want to fly around with good graphics, FS2020 is for you.

Edit: Something that I forgot to mention in the original review is that without some payware scenery, (ORBX, etc.) this sim is not very good for VFR. If you want good out of the box VFR flying, download FS2020.

I am private pilot with IFR certification.  I have microsoft FS and Xplane.  I use Xplane most of the time, because general aviation IFR simulation is excellent in most planes.  My preferred xplane aircraft are Cessna 172 G1000, King Air, and TMB900.  In my setup using Lenovo non-gaming laptop, with external Radeon 5700 GPU, i7 2.8 GHz processor, with 8GB memory, and external display, there is a tradeoff for frame rate and aircraft performance.  The TBM850 and TBM900 run at rate about 17 FPM, while the King Air runs about 25 FPM. The Baron and 172 run about 28 FPM.

This is my first review.
I have a private pilot certificate and bought a Vive Pro, new computer, and x-plane 11 to help train for an instrument rating.
First, even if your computer is VR ready, this game will bring it to it's knees.  It's extremely resource intensive.  It takes almost 5 minutes to boot up from cold, and sometimes I have to restart the computer before attempting to play.  Yes, you can turn down the resolution and it will improve the frame rate and it will load faster, but at that point the graphics become far too primitive in my opinion.
As to the actual gameplay, all aircraft are FAR TOO FORGIVING on the landings.  Not very realistic at all.  Try that in a real 172 and you'll be buying airplane parts.  
The interiors look good.  Too good - I've never been in a NEW plane, it was interesting!
As far as the intended purpose for me, it was fine.  I can fly all I want and not pay 140 per hour plus safety pilot so I can get hood time.  I can adjust the weather and go to places I'm not familiar with.
I believe there is an online community with ATC, but I don't know how to make this work.  There is plenty of users and active forum so the answers are out there.
Well worth $60, but I'd pay 10 times that for something BETTER.

If forced to vote yes or no, I have to vote yes for X-Plane. It is one of two major PC flight simulators that have dominated the civil flight sim market for so many years. However, I have never liked some aspects of it very much and have therefore spent very little time flying X-Plane over the years. In fact, I have only owned two versions: 8 and 11.

To be fair, I am primarily a combat flight simmer and right now DCS World is the simulator I fly for several hours almost every night. But FSX/Prepar3d has been the better civil sim for me because of the 3rd party aircraft and systems addons: I can fly F-4 Phantoms whose flight and systems modeling are almost equal to DCS World, especially with VRS TacPack installed. Whereas the default F-4 Phantom in X-Plane has a laughable flight model and I have never bothered to try any X-Plane payware aircraft.

Other than the area of military aircraft, X-Plane can rival or beat FSX/P3d with free addons and/or payware. It is a matter of personal preference and experience balancing the detail and realism versus system performance. In either flight sim series, you can turn up the graphics so high that even the most expensive gaming PCs will slow to a crawl. For VR, X-Plane has an edge in performance, especially with the new Vulkan support.

If you are like me, then you love PC flight simulation, have adequate funds, and don't worry about which sim is better, you just buy them all and fly them as you see fit. Which brings me full circle: how could I not vote "yes" for one of the biggest and best flight simulators available even if I don't prefer it over my other sims and don't fly it very often.

Like Skyrim, this is a solid foundation that's unfortunately a bit outdated and clumsy and needs the help of third-party tools so that it can shine. Get the 124thATCv2 plugin to replace the sim's half-baked air traffic controller AI with a better one, or you can use XSquawkBox to interface with VATSIM and get simulated air traffic control from live human beings. And Ortho4XP is a powerful but complicated program that can replace the simulator's generated terrain with real satellite photos from Google Maps or Bing Maps.

X-Plane is amazing in its realism; it's just a shame that it needs so much attention to improve the experience.

The best VR capable flight sim. puts other flight sims to shame. if you have a nice VR rig get X-Plane 11 even if you are not that good at flying. you will test your hardware and maybe even learn how to fly a plane.  Sitting in the cockpit and looking around while in the air leaves the new MS flight sim 2020 on the ground as Microsoft failed to see the potential in VR that X-Plane figured out years ago.  X-Plane never stopped developing and this amazing product is an achievement in design and functionality. Works with standard ruder peddles and other flight sim controls in VR however you only really need the peddles as X-Pane figured out a great VR latching method for manipulating the flight surfaces.

Even compared to FS2020, which was released just a couple weeks ago, X-Plane 11 has a multi-year history of customization, capability, and performance. After trying FS2020 on a really powerful computer I still feel like X-Plane 11 is the ultimate in maximizing one's sim experience. Yes, FS2020 is gorgeous, and yes I'm sure it'll bring many people into the hobby, but there's nothing stopping X-Plane from continuing to improve its graphics in response. X-Plane is simply the most configurable and power user friendly flight sim there is.
AWESOME GAME.  ONCE YOU GET YOUR SETTINGS RIGHT AND DOWNLOADED ALL THE FREE ELEMENTS THAT MAKE THIS GAME GREAT YOU HAVE A DECENT SIM.  LESS HUNGRY THAN MSFS2020.

Splendid flight models when compared to previous sim experiences and looks great out of the box. The X-Plane community also offers lots of opportunities for customization with both freeware and payware.

This is a great simulator. If you are looking for something to grow into and are willing to put in the time to learn how to fly, I would highly recommend X-Plane 11. Just be warned that this is not intended as a game despite how Steam displays it. This is a professional quality flight simulator, if you are looking for a flight simulator game I'd recommend Extreme Landings Pro which is available on the Microsoft Store or Mac App Store or Microsoft Flight Simulator on with all assists on.

Well. The time has come to say goodbye to Laminar. It's simply inferior to the latest simulator from Microsoft and I can no longer recommend it. On top of that, there is a lot of stuff here that's just a bit off at makes me want to ask "why?!?". 

1) The menu system - is a... it's not awesome. It's some kind of a custom controls scheme that's just hard to master. 
2) Bring your own "everything". In order to make this sim look good, you need to download your own world mesh, process photo-textures from Bing on your own and download planes on your own... The default stuff is just... bad.
3) It's a resource hog - once you do get the textures and everything it need insane amount of RAM just to display your initial surroundings. 
4) It supposedly has superior to FSX physics simulation of plane surfaces (i.e. it uses simulated surfaces instead of tabular data). But then real pilots always say that planes don't really handle like they do in X-Plane so... I guess it's a bit off.

...just get the new Flight Simulator from Microsoft and forget this one and FSX.

For many, many years, X-Plane has been the reigning king of civilian flight sims. Microsoft's venerable Flight Simulator X required massive help from 3rd-party developers and genius hackers in order to get it to work properly, and for the past 5-6 years, after MS gave up on flight sims, X-Plane went on to surpass it in almost every way. Sure, Prepar3D has done an amazing job keeping the bare bones of FSX alive, but the general public will never embrace the cost of their model. X-Plane is the cream of the crop...for one more week as of this posting.

On August 18, 2020 Microsoft's newest flight sim will be released and it looks unbelievably amazing. If it's all that and more, X-Plane 11 will appear to be on it's last legs. But, it's not dead yet. It will be within a couple of years, but it's got some life left in it, particularly if MS blows the launch of it's new juggernaut.

I am fully on board Microsoft's train of flight-sim greatness, but will absolutely not be deleting X-Plane 11. I've simply invested too much money and time into building that world. Laminar may soon be scrambling to keep up with the new king of sims, but they have nothing to be ashamed of. X-Plane 11 is a masterpiece by any standard.

TL-DR:  Wait for MSFS-2020

I've had a love/hate relationship with this game since I first played it.  The physics and controls were WAY different than FSX (not a surprise, of course).  Matter of fact, I actually refunded X-P about a day after I first downloaded it, then reconsidered and was glad I did.

Overall it's been fun and a decent product that has provided many hours of enjoyment.  However, I've had a lot of issues with it.  Installing some DLC, such as planes or airports, is pretty simple, but due to the order in which the DLC is loaded when X-P starts, you may want a special utility that assists in putting the load into the correct order.  Downloading and using scenery can be another issue altogether - that's not simple at all.  And X-P's load times are a real problem (although admittedly I obviously have no idea what FS's load times will be.)  Sometimes I'll start X-P and go get something to drink, check my email, see if it's raining outside, then head back to the PC to find that it just finished loading - and I have a decent near-high end system.  And then there's the endless pursuit of that elusive high FPS.  Sometimes my FPS has been good, and my flights fine.  Sometimes (especially in VR) my flights have been unbearable due to the low FPS.  I have tried several of endless combinations of graphics settings and NVidia settings and finally get it right, only to find that with the next beta release, I was back to square one.

X-P's scenery is average at best, which pretty much forces you to download 3rd party products.  I'll be the first to say I'm not sure if I'll see the detail you see in the FS trailers, but even if it's close, it'll be light-years ahead of X-P.  Admittedly, I have no idea if FS and its DLC and load times will be easier/better.  But I knew one thing through all of this -- if there had been a better product than X-P available over the last two years, I would have bought it and played it instead.  So we'll see.  If FS is all it's been hyped to be, then it's so long X-P.  If not, then I guess I'll be back.

Edit - I wanted to add one other point about X-P, and unfortunately it is not a good one.  The ATC in this game is absolutely awful.  One big complaint is that the ATC will advise descent to, say, 9K feet.  Uh, what about that mountain that has now appeared in front of me?  You want me to also change my heading too, right?  Nope.  I wait for the hole to appear in the mountain, but I haven't seen it yet.  The second problem is that for some reason, ATC will tell you to alter your course or descend, then a few SECONDS later, tell you to resume your own navigation.  This happens on EVERY flight, so I end up ignoring ATC and landing blind.  These and other ATC complaints are well-documented on the X-P forums, and the response from the X-P junkies is to download a 3rd party product and all will be well with the world.  Well I shouldn't have to download 3rd party products to FIX what Larimar should have already fixed years ago.

A great Desktop Flight Simulator with a high degree of realism out of the box - I actually purchased this as a 'practice' sim ready for the release of Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020 (as I hadn't flown on Desktop Sims for a few years), but I'm left pleasantly surprised at the realism offered as-standard, with a great support and creative community giving plenty of cool add-ons, often free of charge! 

My respect goes out to all the content creators - special mention to Zibo and their B737, which for a freeware add-on is simply phenomenal. I can also recommend Toliss' A319/321, who also show great detail and realism. 

For reference, I run a Ryzen 7 3800X, 32GB 3200 MHz RAM, and an RTX 2070 Super - frames are easily over 60fps at QHD resolution, with the Zibo and Toliss aircraft sitting at around 40-50, so for any payware/detailed add-ons, I might recommend a fairly powerful rig, but for playable frames at a lower resolution, nothing too fancy is required. I'm also running pre-Vulkan Xplane, so expect to see fps improvements when Vulkan becomes available soon. 

Overall, highly recommended for those looking for a detailed, configurable flight simulator with great physics, visuals and immersion! It may soon be overshadowed somewhat by MS FS2020, however the community around this sim is brilliant and I don't expect it to be obsolete any time soon.

The game is buggy. Every time I fly the Cessna 172, whose identifier is N172SP, there is always ANOTHER airplane with the same identifier (AI) coming out, coincidentally, from my same airport. The worst part is that the air traffic controller gives indications to me which the other airplane responds, or sometimes gives indications to the other airplane, which I am asked by the UI to read back. It's incredibly frustrating, and something you would never see in Flight Simulator X happening.
Another bug is that when using VR, the game will sometimes randomly crash. I can't pinpoint the root cause. VR was the main reason why I bought this game.
I have also noticed that the taxi glowing line sometimes won't show up, or sometimes will flicker. I have tried to find a fix on the internet, but haven't found anything that works.
I find the lack of Graphics configuration options disappointing. I had to download plugins to allow me to control that. It's nice that plugins exist, but I have been wasting time doing things that should be available in the factory version.
I like the integration with the Saitek/Logitech yoke and pedals. The buttons are automatically assigned to the most adequate function, which is something FSX does not do.
I also have to accept that the realism is a bit better here than in FSX, but then again, FSX is from 2006, so a long time has passed to allow XP11 to do things better.
I think the cons outweight the pros, unfortunately. I'll keep playing this game until FS2020 comes out, and I won't be recommending this game to people I know.

After 2 years I'm forced to update my review to a negative one. But the cherry on top was trying to reach their support, and I was told in a Facebook message (since there's literally no other way to contact them) that they don't have a contact e-mail address. They just sent me a link to their useless generic FAQ that mentioned nothing about WMR.

*****July 2020 update*****

Really surprised to find people still commenting on my original review from 2017, so I thought it is time to post an update and to answer some of the more recent questions posted in the comments.

Since my original review was written, the experimental flight model has started to bring some much needed improvements to the flight dynamics.  In terms of graphic performance, Vulkan has the ability to vastly improve the overall performance once the bugs are ironed out. 

The LES SF340A and the X-Rotors AW139 are the only mods that keep me returning to X-Plane.  I analyse flight data for a living and the X-Rotors AW139 is as close as it gets on a desktop sim right now.  

It seems my flying background is of interest to some.  So for context, I've a private pilots licence and I've been flying for the last 20 years.  I've flown a number of different aircraft, C150, C152, C172, PA28 Warrior, Europa, Jabiru J400 and X-Air.  I've also been fortunate, over the last 30 years, to have some time in full flight simulators such as the B757, B737-200, BAC1-11, Eurocopter AS332L2, EC225 and H175.  My current aircraft is an X-Air.  

On a more lighthearted aspect, my kids absolutely love X-Plane and for that reason alone I'm changing this from a thumbs down to a thumbs up.  They use X-Plane far more than I do, which partly explains why the use time continues to rise.

I've left my original review below, as is.

******************Original 2017 Review******************************

I write this as someone who is a qualified pilot and am fortunate to have my own real aircraft.  I've also owned and used previous versions of X-Plane since 2004.

I bit the bullet and purchased X-Plane 11 as getting back into flight sims after getting an oculus rift.  First impressions is that X-Plane continues to be resource intensive - needs one heck of a pc to get decent frame rate (I7 6700, 32GB, GTX 980 Ti and it struggles to maintain 30fps unless graphic options are reduced. 

In terms of flight model - still as quirky as ever.  Torque effect is too extreme on the C172 during take-off for example.  On entering a straight and level stall (C172)- it starts ok but then the aircraft loses a significant amount of height during recovery.  Real aircraft - height loss should be around 50 to 100ft if standard recovery actions taken.  Side slipping does not appear to be modelled - somehow managed to maintain and even gain height on the C172 whilst carrying out this manoeuvre.  Other weird effects is the rapid pitch change when going supersonic in the F4 and SR71.  Granted there will be some change, its seems over-exagerated.

On to helicopters - disappointed to see the 'rotation' issue still apparent during start-up (as per previous X-Plane versions).   Was hoping to try the DMO S92 since it was updated for XP11, but that does not work properly in versions 11.1 and 11.2 (main pfd/mfd screens are blank).  Also the DMO S92 rotates very rapidly during engine start - completely unrealistic.

Sounds -very poor.

Scenery - actually the best part of X-Plane, in terms of standard of scenery straight out of the box.  Aberdeen (EGPD) - my home airport,  is pretty well represented - easy to visually navigate the local area.  

VR - recently downloaded the 11.2 beta and have had constant app crashes when using the Oculus rift.  When it does work, it looks quite good.  As with other simulators - instruments are not crisp, but to be fair they are better than other sims.  Being able to use the touch controllers to interact with the aircraft, without buying yet more 3rd party software, is good.  

In fact its a shame as with VR support X-Plane has the foundations of a fantastic sim.  For me the biggest let down is the flight model - its still too quirky, and the default sounds.  Whilst the graphics have progressed over the years, the same cannot be said for the flight model or sounds.  The final surprise is the cost of add-ons - 3rd party X-Plane aircraft seem to have a premium attached to them.

My first impressions of X Plane 11 were quite favourable. Unlike FSX (either heritage or SE) it runs on modern hardware and Windows 10 without any hassle. Out of the box, the default graphics look much better and crisper than any of the MSFS versions and the supplied aircraft are also nicely put together, particularly the sounds - unlike MS' default jet spool which sounds like it was sampled from a vacuum cleaner.

However my enthusiasm was short lived. Most of the key commands are unassigned, leaving the user to choose the input - usually at a critical time in flight. The list of tutorials is very short and specifically there is nothing to transition you into the jet liners once you get used to the hedge clippers. There's no flight planner so you either choose an airport and take off to fly randomly, or rely on third party software or sites to compile a flight plan which can be imported to the GPS or FMC system on your chosen aircraft. However Laminar appear not to have chosen to update the location database and the FMC generates dire warnings about your nav data being out of date. Hey guys, I'm buying this brand new.

Once airborne, if you save and resume a flight later, you may find if you chose the cold and dark start option, your engines are shut down in mid air. Even without that, you will likely find the autopilot and autothrottle has switched off leaving you to cycle through the disengage sequence before it works again. Crash detection is also virtually non existent. A couple of times I crashed by accident, not only was there no damage r a game over message, but the aircraft just continued merrily along the ground passing through buildings and trees at 140 knots with no collision detection whatsoever. Utter rubbish!

Amateur, sloppy and if I had to be honest it's more of an arcade plane game than a simulator. I would say it is to flight simming what Trainz is to train simming against MSTS or the Dovetail TS, but that would be insulting to Trainz. I can't help notice that post summer sale, this game (sorry it's not a sim) has gone back up to the full price of £55... What?! No way it's worth that, in fact i don't even consider it worth the £36 I actually paid for it. Unfortunately the 2 hour window to refund has long come and gone, so guess I'm stuck with this lemon in my Steam collection. In all honesty I cannot recommend it. If you want to flight sim, persevere with keeping FSX going, tell Lockheed the white lie to get the academic licence for Prepar3D or just hang on for FS2020.

1st Impressions Video with Commentary // Oculus Rift S // RTX 2070 Super:

My Initial Impressions:
I started VR 3 years ago and always wanted a decent VR flying sim game, now I'm sporting an RTX 2070 Super, I final found one with X-Plane 11.
The immersion factor of flying in this game with VR is AMAZING!
The game took me about 2 hours to figure out how to set up the controls for the Rift S controllers, in my video above I show you how to get up and running in 10 mins!
Great flight sim, great plugins and great gfx when using add ons. Defualt gfx not so bad it self. Game can be ran at max settings using three ulrawide using a 2080 ti
The simulator is realistic and enjoyable. Although you do have to spend extra amount of money for extra aircraft on the xplane website which is quite annoying

I recently just purchased this game in the steam summer sale and i haven't stopped playing it since, I have done 10 flights in 3 days now in the Zibo 737-800 and I have loved every moment of them, I followed a video of the best free things to have in Xplane 11 and I am so glad I did as now my game looks absolutely stunning both day and night. I strongly recommend this game to people that have a passion for simming, however be prepared to take some time to get everything setup as the sensitivity and controls require some tweaking to get the best outcome. If i could rate this game out of 10 i would probably give it 11 as its just absolutely stunning considering there are so many freeware addons that can enhance the game so much. You will need a decent PC to run this game, I am currently using a i7-7700k and a 1070 FTW to run this game and i get around 40-50 FPS with my addons so before purchasing just make sure you can run it as it has quite a steep price tag. The game standard comes at £54.99 which is not bad considering how good it is, but in the sale I managed to pick it up for around £31.99 so if it is on sale then I highly recommend picking it up however if it isn't then maybe hold off until it is as £54.99 is quite a lot of money. Overall this game is a very big upgrade from the previous XPlane 10 (which I also own), the game it self is just so much more refined than XPlane 10 and Laminar Research have really done a great job with this sim. I am sure ill have 1000 hours in no time ;) 

Hopefully this review helped you out deciding whether to buy this game.

It is a nice game but it has some pros and cons.

Pros -
Nice Graphics (Definitely better than FSX.)
Great Flight Physics.
The developers are putting out different updates to the airports and the environment which evolves the world according to the real word data.
Base planes are realistic and are simulated almost fully.

Cons -

And also the in game ATC sucks because you need to file an IFR route you can't use to fly VFR. In my opinion FSX has a way better ATC than X Plane.

To be honest I would rate this game 7.5 out of 10.

Ignore the negative reviews.  If you're a flight simmer or interested in flight simulation, you'll like this flight simulator.  Sure you could hold out for Microsoft's new 2020 simulator, or you could play a great sim today.  I'm a fan of FSX and I've sunk a lot of money in to that simulator, but I wasn't getting what I was looking for from the environmental realism.  X-plane 11 give you a 64-bit application that leverages the latest hardware, has plenty of add-ons, both payware and MANY free (quality) add-ons, this is worth your investment.  Beyond the quality flight simulation, it brings more realism to the environment that you just can't achieve in FSX.  However, it's not perfect.  My biggest complaint is ground services.  Admittedly, it's a flight simulator and not a ground services simulator, because FSX and the GSX addon are superior in the ground services category.  I'm a jetliner simmer so I want as much realism as possible from the jetliners.  The aircraft are not at the level of PMDG simulations, but the Zibo 737-800 is very close and offers additional immersion realism than I was achieving in FSX.  I put off buying x-plane for a while.  Now, I wish I had bought it sooner.  I'm only 53 hours in and I'm loving this simulator and the enhanced world realism I've achieved.  It's time.  Enjoy!

X-Plane 11 is the most comprehensive and complete flight simulator out there now, and looking into both, I would highly recommend it over Lockheed's Prepar3d.

One of the many pluses of X-Plane 11 is it's stunning visuals (this needs a very powerful PC to run smoothly, but Vulcan API Optimisation is coming this year which will make the simulator run loads better on standard machines). Even the default game is very good looking and with pure freeware you can make the game look stunning. However this covers one of the disappointing aspects of X-Plane, which is the default bitmaps like clouds and skycolours, which can at times, take away from the overall immersion sometimes. If this really annoys you the first payware addon I would recommend buying is UltraWeatherXP, which adds better clouds, skycolours, water depiction and sky effects. This one addon takes care of the sky as a whole and all for the fairly modest price of £30 (this might seem a lot but it is one of the cheapest addons of this nature and in my opinion, the best).  The best tool for enhancing X-Plane's default ground textures is with Forkboy's Ortho4xp, which introduces powerful software to generate real satellite imagery for anywhere in the world and can be downloaded for free. This can make a Freeware airport, paired with Ortho4xp look very authentic for no money, even better when it's paired with payware airports and UltraWeatherXP.

To match the freeware scenery quality in a free aircraft you can get the Zibo Mod 737-800, which is a modified default aircraft (which are by the way pretty good). The detail on this free addon is on par with the PMDG 737 (an £80 addon) and is being updated all the time, not only to iron out bugs, but also to add new features. These freeware plugins in itself make the simulator worth a buy for anyone out there looking for a very real simulation of the boeing 737-700,-800 or -900.

But perhaps the sector where X-Plane 11 beats Prepar3d decisively is the flight model, which is a mile ahead of anything offered by Lockheed or Microsoft. This is especially noteable in light aircraft like the cessna 172, the default c172 is done very well and it's  flight characteristics can really be felt through the controls and according to real world pilots, portrays realistic airflow over surfaces. It achieves this by running a completely independent airfoil maker programme which simulates airflow over wing and control surfaces, giving the most accurate flight model simulation in the consumer industry.

The only thing in this simulator that I am disappointed with is the ATC, it is unintuitive and really doesn't do the game justice, there is however Vatsim servers for this sim if you are interested in ATC with real people controlling.

Also it is worth mentioning that the New Microsoft Flight Simulator is coming out this year, so if you are short on money or just want to spend more on the new MS Flight Simulator when it comes out, it might be worth holding back on purchasing X Plane.

One thing I can't stress enough is that this is not a game, for any people out there just looking to have some fun on flight sim multiplayer, buy FSX, it's cheaper and better suited for your needs. This is a simulator and as always in these types of programmes, the learning curve is very steep for a new player. And again for somebody just starting out, who is unsure weather they really want to get into flight simulation. I once again recommend FSX and a cheap HOTAS (Hands On Throttle And Stick) setup for the same price as X-Plane 11 on its own. However if you already know you will invest hundreds of hours into this genre, or perhaps have in an old programme like FSX, this simulator is definitely for you, and with more and more addons coming out for X-Plane as it becomes more of a mainstream product, I can't recommend this simulator enough.
