Not a flight sim expert. I also don't have any fantasies of being an actual pilot myself. So I am not looking to train to be a pilot. 

I have been playing FSXSE since 2017. I have 80+ hours in that game. I see a lot of people talking about how X plane 11 is better. It looks better than FSX but I wouldn't say it's a big difference. The planes look nice. Some of the graphical effects look nice. 

The problem for me is the game just felt so bare bones. There isn't much there. It's nice that they have flight school with tutorials in it cause you will need them. It's not as simple as FSX can be. 

But there really isn't much there. There is only a few planes, though the few I used looked good. There aren't even any missions you can do. In FSX they have a whole bunch of missions or whatever you want to call them. So when you get bored with the free flight you can go do something with some objectives and a reason for playing the game. Free flight is fun but only for a while. It gets boring in FSX as well. I can only fly around and look at the game world for so long. 

With FSX you get more planes to fly and if you look around you can find some really nice freeware planes that are even better than some payware planes. Like the F-14 you can get for free. The amount of planes in this game is limited. Though it does give you an F-4 Phantom with the game. I had to buy one for FSX. 

It's also a bit too realistic for me. Like I said above I am not looking to become a pilot.

FSXSE is cheaper, has more planes, it has the missions you can do. You can get some really nice free planes for it. Sure it doesn't look quite as good as Xplane 11 but FSX was released in 2006. 

Xplane 11 isn't a bad flight sim. It's just a bit lacking. It's also not really the sim for me. 

But because I find it lacking I am going to give it a thumbs down.

Pros:

- You can fly anywhere in the world unlike some other simulators where you get portions of the world
- Super realistic in terms of physics

- Works well with VR headset (Oculus Rift S)

Cons:

- It can get expensive once you get add ons
- Lack of default plane selections
- Wish the weather apperence was a bit more realistic, I ended up paying $35 for better looking clouds lol
- The ATC is way too complicated unlike FSX
- No built in flight planning (You would need a 3rd party software)

Overall

If you're a pilot irl or wanting to fly irl then this is the perfect simulator for you but if you're like me that just wants to play casually and fly around freely then it might take some time to learn and get used to. I fully recommend getting a joystick or yoke if you don't have one already.

If you're planning to buy a yoke I recommend getting the Honeycomb as it is well made and sturdy unlike the cheap plastic looking Logitech yoke

For making a flight plan I recommend using Little Navmap as it's very straight foward, easy to use, and can be tracked where you are on the map ingame

Being a former fighter pilot, with an obsession for details and realism, this flight sim is something that I can recommend to anyone really serious about FLYING. The weather and the flight models are highly immersive. The ATC for VFR flights is on the weak side, but using VATSIM, it is no factor for my use. If you know how to program, you can easily access the data generated by the sim, to power your own applications (map, gps, etc). I only flew Microsoft Flight Sim X besides this one, and it is just not playing in the same league, although way older. For those who are real professional pilots, waiting for FS 2020 to release: considering that the marketing around it is mostly focused on visuals (which look absolutely fantastic), and not really on what makes or break a realistic flight simulator, I'd say go for X-Plane meanwhile! It can only be a great experience! If you are a casual FS user, I'd recommend sticking to Microsoft products, as they have always been less realistic, but more accessible (and still great to practice procedures).

PROS: 
- X-Plane 11 is an excellent software full of API and documentation
- Passionate community of developers who provide plugins, scenery and airplanes for the game. Most of them frequently update their plugins.
- Lots of commercial developers who improve every aspect of the game but obviously at a cost
- Many YouTubers like flightdeck2sim are more than happy to support others like my self to learn how to fly the more realistic community made airplanes.
- Integrated with third party payware Navigraph which help you to actually have updated airracs and flight graphs but obviously at a cost.
- You can buy lots of DLC directly from the steam store of X-Plane 11. So you don't need to follow any complicated installation instructions some plugins/mods require.

CONS:
- Developers seem demotivated when receiving negative feedback about features of the game or new update; look at the developers blog, they always take a passive aggressive tone with those leaving comments.
- Also when the developers are aware a feature in the game is so obviously bad, they seek feedback from the users and say "Don't just say it simply sucks". In my opinion they should be contracting out industry experts to tell them how ATC could work in the game.
- The ATC sucks
- AI planes fly with no logic, randomly popping up around you during flight and also consumes loads of FPS.
- The scenery is auto generated and really just flat, boring, unrealistic.
- There is a popular community made software to generate realistic scenery for the game but the output from the software requires a lot of time and HDD space.
- The community developers have patched everything missing in this game requiring a great deal of patience to deal with installing everything require; for example, you might download your favourite airport but the developer used scenery libraries from several other sources thus requiring you to download all of those.
- The real time world weather inside the game is horrible, so unrealistic and not matching real world weather, let alone the dynamics of weathers on this earth.
- You need to purchase a third party subscription to have up to date airracs making navigation in the world realistic.
- No multiplayer support by the developers. You need to use community multiplayer plugins/networks.
- To be honest, I just can't get my head around the 3 or 4 seperate plugins required to go on these multiplayer networks
- Then the actual flying experience on those networks can be laughable, graphics of other users are rediculous. For example, usually you cant see the gears of the other planes... and some users treat the game like GTA5.

So the game doesn't really match the product description. It's sold as some realistic flight sim but you need to spend 200 hours to jump all the hurdles to make it passable and if you have a deep wallet you can buy the weather, airplanes, scenery which actually make the game become a truly realistic flight sim.

All around this is probably the best flight sim available. A bit of an initial learning curve to manage if you’re unfamiliar with aviation, but there is still flexibility between simple to fly aircraft that get you going quickly versus more complex aircraft that require deeper systems knowledge.  Peripherals are easy to configure if you have them. My only knock would be that plugins/scenery (which are nearly a requirement for the best experience) can be a bit tedious to set up, as they require editing in the file system instead of an in-game interface. Once you understand how these add-ons fit in the game files, the process is straightforward, and generally it is only a one time install. There is also a thriving forum community for help with troubleshooting or discovering new add-ons. Lastly, it goes without saying for a flight sim that performance correlates highly with hardware, and X-Plane is no exception to this rule.

I was originally somewhat astonished to give this game a positive review.     I have purchased earlier versions of X-plane over the years, and not experienced much luck with them.   I'm still not sure why.   Somehow, my gaming hardware just didn't work well with the earlier versions.

But then I found, quite some time ago, that X-plane 11 ran well enough on my gaming laptop to please at least me.  And I ran it on that gaming laptop for a time.

But recently I purchased a strong gaming desktop and an HTC Vive to enable virtual reality.   And from that point forward this game began to astonish.

It took a few tries to get the hang of using VR with X-Plane 11.  Indeed, initially I was a little frustrated.  But I'm glad I stuck with it.   Learning that I could still use the mouse cursor to control the switches, while I used a joystick to control, began to make everything easier.  The virtual reality experience began to be amazing, and with the Vive headset on if felt remarkably  like I was actually inside and flying the plane.

A few minutes ago I landed a float plane in (virtual) Alaska.  I recognized the area from the air (I've been to the area I flew over), and marveled at how real everything seemed to me.

There is now a growing number of decent programs for VR, but X-plane does, at least for me, "take the cake."  I've never been happier with a piece of software in my life.  The difficulties that I initially experienced were the result only of my own temporary inexperience with the software, and they all were solved with continued practice and thought. 

Your own experience might be different from mine -- after all, everybody has different equipment and amounts of patience, and my own experience got markedly better when I changed rigs.  But X-Plane 11 will remain on my computer until there is an X-Plane 12.  I award this software 5 out of 5 perfect landings.

UPDATE 040919:  Just landed my little Cessna at the airstrip in Gibraltar.  Got out of the plane and climbed up the rock of Gibraltar and sat at the top of it, looking down at the town below.  The graphics aren't perfect, but they are certainly sufficient.  With this game and virtual reality, and a bit of practice figuring out how to make it all work (have patience), this game becomes a window on the world.   I won't live long enough to actually travel the entire world.  But in virtual reality, I can go just about anywhere I would want to go, and it feels remarkably lifelike.  Google Earth street view, it's not.   But, on the other hand, I can fly in and land with the Cessna, and get a pretty good sense of the geography.   It's worth far more than the price of admission, and it's both educational and interesting.   Technology is going far beyond what I would have envisioned as a child, long ago.

UPDATE 092919.  Reading some other reviews today, I noted that a few did not like the VR experience.  I find that genuinely surprising.   I hope enough patience is being used to figure out how to make this work, before coming to a negative conclusion.  I enabled the mouse cursor to work while in VR, and I use the mouse to flip switches, and a joystick to control the planes control surfaces.   I also use a Vive controller to "move around" outside of the plane.

I was initially frustrated trying to sit myself well in the virtual cockpit.   But I eventually figured it out: I click the small button (with three lines upon it) above the round control disc on the Vive Controller, then select views and then cockpit view.   I end up sitting in the cockpit, well positioned.

To get out of the plane and move around, I use the controller too -- in the normal way one moves around in many virtual reality titles.  

Today I took off from La Guardia (using the simulator, of course) and flew around New York.  The scenery has apparently been greatly improved.  Landing in Central Park allowed me to then "walk around" the city.   Again, of course, with the simulator, since one cannot land in Central Park, I assume, without making many, many policemen and other officials quite unhappy.   :)

This program seems to get better and better, from an already good start.

UPDATE 6/6/20.  Staying at home.   Don't much care for television.  Can only play so much chess and read so many books.  What to do?  A few days ago I started an attempt to fly around the world in a (virtual) Cessna 172, using Xplane-11 and a Vive VR set up.  Yeah, it's Walter Mitty on steroids.  But how many people still know who Walter Mitty is?

Landed at night in a small field in Kansas.   Eastward bound.  I'll deal with the Atlantic when I come to it.  

This is still a wonderful purchase.

Having flown and trained on the Cessna 152 in reality, I can say that the VR capabilities of the X-Plane 11 have gone beyond my expectations.

1) When in the virtual cockpit it feels as though in the real one. You can look in all directions and see the appearance of difference in distance when you look out the windows etc. It is amazing, it is as though VR has been designed for the ultimate flight simulation training.

2) In the virtual cockpit ideally you can utilise the VR controller to be used as your hand to press switches and knobs and to trim the pitch etc. This is essential to train muscle memory and training in X-Plane VR muscle memory will give you the ability to keep current when one cannot fly in real for longer periods for whatever reason.

3) Using the VR controller is not the best way to control the yoke, as you do not have any feedback of resistance. A joystick without resistance feedback is better as it does offer some resistance. A special yoke that has full on resistance feedback were you have to trim the aircraft to relieve the tension is highly recommended for more realistic training.

4) The movement of the aircraft as perceived with the eyes is nearly identical to the real machine. This really knocked me off the seat, as in my perception it felt the aircraft moved nearly exactly the same as the real machine, despite I flew on the less powerful 152, whereas X-Plane 11 has the 172 version. In my experience the two versions of the Cessna are nearly identical in the actual movement, the 172 has that extra power, it seems as though you can be more aggressive with it.

To conclude, giving that you have a realistic yoke and a relatively high resolution VR headset (I use the Samsung Odyssey and it is sufficient with an overall good quality. I would say that is the minimum for a headset) and pedals would be handy, you can use the X-Plane 11 as a form of training to fly a Cessna when you cannot fly in real. For that purpose it is AMAZING! If you have not flown a real aircraft for a sufficient number of hours to start getting the gist behind flying an aircraft with the different procedures and the overall feeling, then it might be more difficult for you to use this simulation to what it has been designed for, but still it will prepare you to some extent for the real thing. For those who already have some ability to fly aircraft this is your baby to keep on progressing in flight training. The only difference I would say is the fact that you do not feel the actual aircraft move through the air with all the G-forces and forces that are part of it. Other than that it is the best flight simulation VR training tool I have come about and I have been using flight simulation since I was a 7 year old kid, starting with the very primitive flight simulator for my Amstrad CPC-464, moving unto various military aircraft simulations (F-16 Falcon; F/A-18 Hornet; A6 Intruder & F4 Phantom) and Airbus 320 for my Amiga 500, then when eventually I got into the PC realm I started off with Microsoft Flight Simulator 2002, 2004 & X. Out of the Microsoft Flight Simulators I found 2004 the best of them all. There is something about MSFS 2004, the graphics and physics and the realism of the clouds and also MSFS 2004 has some of the most realistic expansions, such as the Boeing 727 Professional & Airbus 340 Professional. Basically these expansions are 100% replicas of the real machines with all the buttons and knobs 100% functional in the 3D cockpit and the controls and physics of the airliners are as closely imitated to the real machines. It has even been tested by real airliner pilots and engineers. Anyone interested to become an airliner pilot, I recommend you buy yourself a second hand copy (CEX sells them) of Microsoft Flight Simulator 2004 and buy yourself some of the Professional Expansions (CEX has them on sale sometimes also).

Eventually on my journey in flight simulations, I have discovered the existence of X-Plane and my first version that I bought was X-Plane 10 which is really good. X-Plane was certainly superior in realism to MS Flight Sim, except for the professional expansions for MSFS 2002/2004. I used to use both simulators interchangeably as they would both offer something to learn from. Nonetheless, since I started to train to fly the real thing, I noticed how flying in the flight simulation was much more difficult, because I was unable to feel the aircraft and until I got this new version of X-Plane 11 I was unable to use the flight simulators as I used to in the past as it didn't feel the same anymore. Now, with X-Plane 11 VR capability and the actual realism of controls and all the points I have mentioned above, it is a truly valuable tool for real pilots in training. Thank you for such an amazing simulator and anyone that would not recommend this simulator, simply never really trained on the real aircraft, it's just a fact. If you are interested more in the fanciest graphics or scenery and many aircraft to choose from and not the realism, then maybe this is not the simulator for you. From me this simulator is 10/10.

Make sure you have a powerful enough computer. I have a i5-8600k, Asus ROG Strix GTX 1070, 16GB RAM (3200MHz) and a gaming motherboard. It is a pretty powerful set up, though I would say this is more of your average these days, but it does the job.

I've decided to change my review on this sim.  After more time spent with it, I felt it was unfair to give it a thumbs down.  The true purpose of this sim is to give you as accurate a flight sim model as possible.  I think they have done a very good job of that.  The software is very powerful and you are able to replicate many things that will make the experience very enjoyable.  

My complaints though are still as follows:

I have a 2080ti, Intel 9700k, 32GB DDR4 and an SSD.  I run the game in 2k with eye candy turned on and the frames can be  really bad around cities even with the brand new Vulkan patch.   Flying over Toronto in 2k with higher graphic settings and I'm at 31 fps in Vulkan and even less when sitting on the runway.  The same when flying over London or other cities.  In fairness, I enjoy heli's so I fly below 2500 feet.  If you are flying up at 20,000 or higher or over sparse landscape I jump up into the 80's but it's not why I purchased two paid helicopter modules.

I'm also very disappointed in the way the scenery is generated.  Again, if you are at 20 or 30,000 feet everything looks fine but get down near the ground and wow.  The roads all look like they were laid out by a dev on a bad acid trip.  The roads have no order to them.  they're just  generated in a willy- nilly fashion or go absolutely nowhere.  Railway lines can just end like cliffs even in areas of paid content and you will see roads on 45 degree angles like a Nascar track or just nonsense elevations.  You need to pay hundreds of dollars to get this game resembling what an area really looks like and the satellite data you can download looks really bad down low in a helicopter and takes up TONS of space on your HD.

I downloaded the free Orbx southern England scenery and it certainly helps but you will still find really strange roads and railways.  The trees are still cardboard cutouts and water is just painted on the landscape with no actual waves or moving boats.  

I don't know how bad things look in other civilian simulators as this was my first but this is not up to the level of military sims like Digital Combat Simulations.   I know this is a civilian simulator as opposed to military but running so poorly with mediocre at best scenery makes is dissappointing.  As I said, you can download improved scenery both for free and paid but it will take up hundreds of gigs on your hard drive to improve anything to a slightly better level.  

I can fly anything from an F18 to a Huey in DCS with graphics at max in 2k with proper looking scenery, animated water that I can fly right down between moving waves in huricane winds and moving boats that pitch etc. etc. etc. all at 100 frames per second.  They  even have fully animated ground crew on the aircraft carriers.   There is just no comparison as far as immersion goes.

Great sim, enjoying it. Limited flight hours in XP11, nevertheless my two cents below.

[h1]Some positive points[/h1]
  - Product seems to be built up from scratch with complete passion. Something that is, unfortunately, severely lacking in the overall software market (I guess outside of that as well).
  - (Almost) [b]fully-clickable 6DOF cockpits[/b] much like in DCS World, [i]including TrackIR support[/i] (protocol-wise, opentrack works wonders).
  - Performance [i]was[/i] a problem before Vulkan (11.50+, currently beta), I couldn't get above 20 FPS with medium settings but now I can run the sim at the full 50+ FPS with everything on max.
  - Sounds. [b]The sounds seem to be [i]spot[/i] on.[/b] Haven't gotten any aircraft other than the ones present in the base of XP11, but the 737 sounds 100% like the real thing (likely actual recordings).
  - [b]In the settings, controllers have full descriptions and visual indications[/b] of where each button/axis is on the actual controller, which makes it easy to (re-)assign buttons/axes.
  - [b]Multi-monitor support[/b], beautifully represented in the settings. Meaning you can, for example, have one monitor setup for situational awareness (map + params) and another for the actual sim.

[h1]Some meh/interesting points (YMMV)[/h1]
  - UI navigation after having loaded up the sim is unconventional and slightly confusing, but one gets used to this after a while. It all still makes sense, it really is just unconventional.
  - Carrier-landing support for the 737. At least, when it comes to comms. Landing itself was partially successful (my own words), touched down nicely but [i]slightly[/i] (no sarcasm) overshot the runway.
  - Ground vehicles make interesting maneuvers every now and again (immersion-breaking, slightly).

[h1]Some negative points[/h1]
  - [b]Unable to link one throttle axis to multiple throttle axes.[/b] This is a PITA, a true PITA, if you're flying anything with more than two engines. A plugin is available (X-Multi-Throttle) that does the job, but it is cumbersome in my experience since it requires some reconfiguration every time you switch between >2 and <=2 engine aircraft. IMHO this should be part of the base of XP11, since one would absolutely expect customers to run into the issue of having to control a 4-engine aircraft using a 2-axis throttle.
  - [b]Damage is not modeled visually[/b] (at least not on the 737, on 11.41). Which means that if you rip your flaps off because you're not overspeeding at all because you'd never do such a thing ever, it'll affect your flight model but visual inspection will reveal that nothing actually seems to have happened (because you'd never overspeed) and that your flaps are still perfectly functional (visually they remain [i]completely[/i] unchanged). Now, I know this is a flight simulator and not a "crash simulator", but I still hold my opinion that this comes off a little cheap as this should be a relatively easy to implement feature, as it doesn't need to be perfect. [i]If I rip my flaps off, I don't want to see my flaps anymore. I think that's fair, and realistic.[/i]
  - [b]Collision is not modeled with static objects.[/b] If you so desire you are fully capable of taking off [i]through[/i] a residential area, houses included. Buildings are but visual obstructions, and sometimes you/AI entities get spawned on gates where there is already a static aircraft parked (once again moving perfectly through it). [i]If I fly into a building, I want to crash and burn. If I fly into a forest because I overloaded my plane to double the maximum weight and overshot the runway, I want to crash and burn. I don't want to spawn on a place occupied by a static aircraft. I think that's fair, and realistic.[/i]
  - [b]No first-party/retailer addon store, only third party stores.[/b] I'd feel a whole lot more comfortable purchasing from either Steam or an official store. Mostly since one would need to create yet another account and that most stores are geographically targeted and as such have limited payment methods, as is the case with the ones I'm familiar with. Because of this I'm limited (due to my own principles) to purchasing from Steam only, and the addons I'd like to purchase are not available.

Nevertheless, this is an amazing product with a level of detail that I truly wish we would see more often.

From a real pilot this game is very disappointing. The graphics are 2010/2012 at best. If you would like a well designed airfield you will need to pay extra for that ($30-$50) for one airport. The physics are bad. I try to brake the aircraft with the flight pedals but the moment I tap the pedal is screeches and pulls the aircraft way left or right as if I used maximum braking. The comms are a SLIGHT improvement since you can file a flight plan (without SIDs and STARs so half asses it), switch to clearance/ ground/ dep/ center in a logical way. However when you get to your field of attend landing atc will vector you in circles until you run out of gas. They are unable to effectively vector you into an approach like an ILS. It's pretty much required to cancel IFR and proceed VFR to land. There is no multiplayer, no shared cockpit unless you download third party hardware. The planes are VERY limited, maybe 10 aircraft? However you can download mods to add more but they are user made so the quality is typically a shell of an aircraft. You would think a flight sim with todays technology could do a bit better. 
What I would have liked to see as a bare minimum for a game of this age is a robust ATC system, aircraft physics, and proper looking weather.
Second tier items would have been graphics, multiplayer, larger selection of aircraft.

After using this sim for 400 hours, I wanted to give a clear insight to anyone who wants to use this sim and have questions about it.

First of all, this is a SIMULATOR, not an arcade game where you press a key and you're up in the air. Unless you are an aviation enthusiast, stay away from this because you will not like it. 

Let's also do a quick Pro/Con thing to see what you should expect from X-Plane 11.

Pros:
-Great flight modelling.
-Currently, the best looking simulator you can get out of the box.
-Amazing addon support and a vast amount of freeware and payware addons
-VR support

Cons:
-Low performance (this is currently being solved with the new 11.50 Vulkan update. So if you are reading this in the future, it's probably already solved)
-There is a built-in ATC, but it's not that good at its job. 
-Billboard(2D) clouds, even though that can be easily fixed with payware addons.

I probably missed something good/bad about the simulator but the ones I wrote should answer some questions you have in mind. 

Now back to "should you buy this simulator?". Do you like planes? Do you want to spend many hours learning systems and reading/watching tutorials or manuals? Are you planning to be a pilot or just want to live the life of one? 

If you answered at least 1 or 2 of those questions with "yes" then you should consider this simulator. It won't disappoint you. But if you haven't, then simply close this page; this simulator isn't for you. 

TL;DR: This is a simulator, not an arcade game. Buy it if you know/want to learn to fly a plane properly.

As a longtime flight sim enthusiast with both Microsoft and X-Plane, I can definitely say that X-Plane 11 has been on top of its game since launch. It is realism and accessibility at its finest. The only real question you have to ask yourself is how invested will you become? 
We are talking about more mods, add-on aircraft (pay and freeware), extra downloadable utilities (again, pay and free) and tools, weather upgrades... the list is exhausting. And just like modding anything to squeeze out that extra inch of realism or to master that next business jet, problems can and will arise. The more you mod and tinker the more likely it is you will eventually break something within the game. 

With all that said, the community for X-Plane 11 is endless. Help is always around the corner. Again, I do not know what each and every potential user is looking to get out of this flight sim so it's hard to fully describe the experience as it will be custom tailored towards the individual. If you are looking to fly this right out of the box then I would throw an easy 75% rating at X-Plane. There's just so much you can add to this sim to make it that much more immersive and realistic that x-plane out the box versus x-plane with mods and additions isn't quite the same experience.
 
Quick and easy advise; if you aren't in X-plane 11 fully or tend to jump from game to game, sim to sim then move on as X-Plane 11 is definitely an investment in time, education (if you aren't a real world pilot or have little flying experience), and possibly cold cash. Now, let us see what Microsoft brings to the table with their flight sim hopefully due out this year.

Fantastic game with plenty of freeware planes and scenery to expand the game. General aviation aircraft, fighter jets, Airliners, business jets, helicopters, it's all available free online. There is something for everyone that enjoys aviation. There is a learning curve and it took me a lot of youtube videos to figure out things like using the nav radio for ILS and creating a flight plan in the FMS for long haul flights but I'm glad. Running ILS approaches in bad weather, offshore oil rig heli landings (or on a moving frigate), aircraft carriers and thousands and thousands of airports, there's so many aviation challenges you can make for yourself. I played on a simple joystick with twist yaw and had a blast but with a throttle, yoke, and rudder pedals it becomes even more immersive and precise. I'm happy with the standard scenery, although some cities are lacking such as Dallas but flying over Manhattan or Washington DC at night looks superb and the street traffic looks great.

If you are a fan of aviation and willing to put in a little time to learn the systems of the aircraft (with youtube it really isn't hard), I highly recommend you check this game out. If you're more casual and looking for a more arcade experience where you hop in a plane and takeoff and don't worry about things like bird strikes, engine failures, or wind shear, weight and balance, fuel usage, then this game probably isn't for you. 

One last thing. There is multiplayer. VATSIM has ATC controllers and real traffic if you're looking for an even more immersive flying session. There are rules however, it's not like GTA5 (again, this is a simulator, GTA5 is arcade). You'll need to be able to follow taxi instructions, gain landing/take-off clearance, and communicate like a real pilot but this game is great for learning real world procedures. The best sim on the market. With FS2020 on the way, I think it's important to mention on X-Plane, I can still fly around the world and do whatever even if I didn't have access to the internet. How many games can you say that about today?

X-Plane 11 is a good sim IF you have DLC or mods. The base game is very bare, and the airports and scenery are frankly outdated. While there is global, most airports are bare-bones and lack some key details. In places with unique runways such as Lukla, it lacks the sloped runway and other key details that make it special. The runways all have one thing in common; they are low res, and are very rough. 
While there is a fairly large selection of base-game aircraft, most have lacking audio and low resolution textures. If you have a look at the game's 747-400, you will find that the aircraft has horrible textures, non-fmod sounds, landing gear clipping through the floor when retracted, and unrealistic handling. 
The 737-800 on the other hand is a beautiful aircraft. It has nice textures, fmod sound, and more-or-less accurate handling. 
Most of the GA aircraft are nice, but there is a small selection of them.

If you are in the market for a flight sim, wait for Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020. You'll be waiting for a few months, but you'll get so much more than X-Plane, for a similar price. FS2020 offers multiplayer, many more very detailed aircraft, and globally accurate scenery with 3D trees!

The bad reviews are most likely from people who thought you just hit a throttle and takeoff.
A recommendation is that you use a yoke or sidestick, rudder pedals and a throttle quadrant.
Add all global scenery packs and if you can add autopilot instruments to your cockpit setup.
If you can't afford this, use a sidestick with a small throttle attached.
And a starter flight on a 737-800 would be KJFK to KBOS (John F Kennedy Intl to Boston Intl)

X-plane 11 is an extremely awesome simulator although just like anything else it has it's ups and downs. To start off X-plane 11 includes awesome realism settings that just haven't been achieved by another previous simulator in the industry in my opinion. The graphics (for those that have the appropriate hardware - graphic card) are very realistic but a very good CPU and GPU are needed to accomplish this. Comparing this to other simulators I've used in the past FS2004, FSX, Prepar3D, XP10, I wish that X-plane developers made it more stable for most users and not have a specific type of GPU to have it function to its full capabilities. Making a comparison with it's competitor Microsoft Flight Simulator X, which is a lot more stable and even more widely used because of its stability which I wish X-plane 11 had brought would've made it much more popular. Again, this is my opinion using the experience I've had since flying in the FS2004 since it came out in 04'.

This game is amazing in VR. I have flown from places like Newark to Detriot, and Newark to Miami or Orlando. At medium settings, I would say that the game is ok, but I wish it was a little more optimized for lower end systems. I am running currently on a Ryzen 7 2700 and a RX 570 4GB, in all of the other games I play I can turn the setting all the way up, but here, the maximum I can do is around medium settings for everything. All around, this game is good.

As of May2020 this is the most realistic flight simulator you can buy... So much that it counts towards some of your required hours in real world flight training. The stock xplane11 install while including the world and most airports and a few planes does feel very bare - Firstly get (free!) the module known as Zibos 737. Tons of people fly this because it is probably better than any payware aircraft. Next watch a recent upload date video that highlights "Top10 must-have xplane modules" or something similar. There's many good free plugins that add features, such as gate pushback mod, choice of vatsim intergrations etc, scenery packs, and other planes.... My HUGE advice here (learnt the hard way) is to read/watch reviews of any products you wish to buy - there's often no refund for these digital addons, and some aircraft are made really badly (a certain payware 747, shan't name it! eg) while others are totally different ball game (another payware 747 for example).
Many people will want to jump in the cockpit and get flying ASAP which is understandable, but to get the most out of this simulator, you will need to put aside a few hours to get your controls setup just how you like, tinker with the graphics to get the best quality/frame rate for your system and taste, find which scenery packs you might like, airports, weather/cloud modifications, lighting/colour enhancements and so forth, and these few boring hours spent researching and tinkering will pay massive dividends in the end.
Must have free modules to get started:
* zibo 737  (professional grade / study level 737 - every switch....)
* X-RAAS (runway awareness advisory - ("approaching runway 0-5-Left" etc)
* BetterPushback (preplan your gatepush backs from top-down planner, and watch the tow truck do it)
* X-MultiThrottle (Allows your 2 throttle HOTAS to control 3-8 engines, using some clever logic)

This game is also fully VR supporting, personally I find the switch from HOTAS (hands on throttle and stick) back to the VR controllers (your "hands" in game to press the switches or spin the dials) too much of a hassle and immersion breaking, so never use it for any "proper" airliner flying.. HOWEVER if I go VFR for fun, I will forget tuning ILS's, leave the FMC behind, and go HOTAS only, which in VR is the best way.

Anyone who likes flying and wants a realistic flight models - this is it. turbulence, crosswind landings, wings icing up, massively multiplayer over online VATSIM network - it's all there. RATE 9.5/10

[h1]English[/h1]
[b]recenzja po polsku poniżej[/b]

I've bought it as my first serious contact with flight simulators and one of my first contacts with knowledge on flight operations in general. I enjoy it and don't regret spent money (about 45 euros).

[b]Advantages:[/b]

- It has a very good reputation on graphics and quality of simulation (many sources list it as the best flight simulator on the market for now) — I'm unable to deny any of that.
- I didn't encounter any kind of problem with stability, performance and bugs in the flying simulation itself (i7-4720HQ 4 cores, 8GB RAM, GeForce GTX950M).
- The airliner I've been playing with so far (737-800) has most of functions in cockpit operational and really used during flying.
- Possibility of flying all around the world.
- Broad functionality (in passenger operations) — ATC, tower, ground control, essential ground service, navigation points all around the world, STARs, SIDs, functional navigation system in an airplane. Small bot-controlled air traffic.
- Ability to watch and save replays from flights.
- Advanced support of game controllers and possibility of broad configuration of keyboard buttons functions.

[b]Disadvantages:[/b]

- Serious problems with navigation during taxiing  — maps dont include taxiway marks so it's needed to follow yellow arrows displayed on the ground which are being drawn by bad working algorithm that doesn't know what's going on and sometimes guides through grass or fences (in addition of looking terrible). Beside that sometimes control doesn't detect that the plane made it to a destination point and doesn't provide takeoff clearance. The pathfinding on airports sometimes forces our plane to crash into other aircraft.
- From whatever reason an access to a map is limited to several dozen km from our position. It's impossible to prepare desired flightplan on an departure airport.
- Saving and loading simulation states doesn't work properly — some aspects (for example ATC flightplans, but I think more than that) doesn't save at all.
- There are bugs in simulation of some cockpit instruments, for example FMS (simulator spew an error and and the device stopped working, other time the simulation crashed in similar situation).
- Only three passenger airliners included (there are much more other aircraft, that's a remark only for people intrested mainly in big civil aviation) — I don't know what is the quality of free addon aircraft.
- Very strange system of toggling between flight controls by mouse and pressing buttons in cockpit. It is incredibly easy to accidently crash the plane when trying to switch something on or off, especially in situation that demand quick reaction or doing many things at once. It's very frustrating (having in mind save/load problems) and it's impossible to calibrate as wanted or turn to a diffrent toggling mode.
- Included instructions (at least some of them) are written laconicly and are insufficient to properly control onboard devices especially for someone who is learning to do it. It's gonna be needed to look for additional information and use "trial and error" method.

[h1]polski[/h1]
Kupiłem jako pierwszy poważny kontakt z symulatorami lotu oraz jeden z pierwszych poważnych kontaktów z wiedzą o operacjach lotniczych w ogóle. Jestem zadowolony i nie żałuję wydanych pieniędzy (dałem nieco ponad 200zł).

[b]Zalety:[/b]

- Ma bardzo dobrą reputację pod względem grafiki i jakości symulacji (wiele źródeł uważa X-Plane za najlepszy symulator pod tym względem w tej chwili na rynku) — faktycznie nie potrafię się do tych rzeczy przyczepić.
- Nie natrafiłem dotąd na problemy ze stabilnością, wydajnością ani błędami w samej symulacji lotu (i7-4720HQ 4 rdzenie, 8GB RAM, GeForce GTX950M).
- Statek powietrzny którym jak dotąd się bawiłem (737-800) ma zdecydowaną większość funkcji w kokpicie sprawnych i faktycznie używanych.
- Możliwość latania po całym świecie.
- Szeroka funkcjonalność (jeśli chodzi o operacje pasażerskie) — kontrola lotów, wieża, kontrola naziemna, podstawowa obsługa samolotu na lotniskach, punkty nawigacyjne na całym świecie, STARy, SIDy, funkcjonalny system nawigacyjny w samolocie. Drobny ruch lotniczy prowadzony przez boty.
- Możliwość oglądania i zapisywania powtórek z lotu.
- Zaawansowana obsługa kontrolerów gier i konfiguracji funkcji przycisków na klawiaturze.

[b]Wady:[/b]

- Poważne problemy z nawigacją po lotniskach (przy kołowaniu) — na mapach brak zaznaczonych punktów więc instrukcje kołowania należy wykonywać po strzałkach wyświetlanych na drogach kołowania które są rysowane przez źle działający algorytm — same nie wiedzą do końca o co chodzi i każą czasem jeździć po trawie (a oprócz tego wyglądają okropnie i psują immersję). Oprócz tego czasem nie zaliczają dojazdu do celu co skutkuje brakiem możliwości otrzymania pozwolenia na start. Czasem każą zderzać się z innymi samolotami na lotnisku.
- Z jakiegoś powodu mapę można przeglądać tylko w zasięgu kilkudziesięciu kilometrów wokół nas — nie da się przygotować zamierzanego planu lotu na lotnisku początkowym.
- Niepoprawnie działa zapis stanu symulacji — pewne aspekty (np. plan lotu u ATC, ale odnoszę wrażenie że parę innych rzeczy też) nie zapisują się.
- Występują błędy w symulacji działania pewnych rzeczy w kokpicie, np. FMS (symulator zgłosił że wystąpił błąd i komputer ten przestał działać, coś innego raz doprowadziło do crashu symulacji).
- Tylko trzy duże samoloty pasażerskie w zestawie (jest kilkanaście innych samolotów, to uwaga dla osób które są zainteresowane głównie "Airlinerami") — nie wiem jakiej jakości są darmowe dodatki społeczności.
- Dość dziwny system przełączania się między sterowaniem samolotem za pomocą myszy a naciskaniem przycisków w kokpicie — bardzo łatwo jest przez przypadek rozwalić samolot próbując użyć przełącznika w kokpicie, szczególnie w sytuacji wymagającej szybkiej reakcji lub zrobienia wielu rzeczy na raz. Jest to niesamowicie frustrujące (szczególnie że zapis i wczytywanie działa tak sobie) i nie da się tego w żaden sposób dokonfigurować dostosowując do swoich potrzeb.
- Instrukcje (przynajmniej niektóre) są napisane lakonicznie i nie wystarczą do poprawnej obsługi niektórych funkcji w kokpicie, szczególnie jeśli dopiero uczy się działania tych sprzętów. Będzie konieczne szukanie dodatkowych informacji w internecie i posługiwania się metodą "prób i błędów".

As an instrument pilot, I love practicing instrument approaches in VR.  I run the program with a Valve Index with high settings and don't have any issues.  I utilize the saitek pro flight yoke, with double throttles and pedals.  It's great to actually fly IMC (instrument meteorological conditions) and fail an engine or fail the pitot-static system.  Since in real world, when you simulate an engine or instrument failure, you brief it so much with your safety pilot or instructor, you loose the sense of surprise (you see them reaching for the throttle or reach to cover an instrument).  In sim, I can set up emergencies to happen randomly to help me hone identifying the emergency too.  

That being said, it is also a fun simulator to just game around in.  Even if you don't have any flight experience, it can still be enjoyable.  (I got my start in aviation with flight simulators when I was a teenager and its a fun way to scratch the aviation itch and much less expensive.)  

--Ryzen 7 3800x, 64GB DDR4, RTX 2080ti, 1TB 3D NAND NVMe PCIe M.2 SSD, Valve Index

Let me preface this review with the fact that I am not a pilot, and I don't know a lot about being a pilot, but i'm trying to learn, which is why the realism of the game caught my attention.  If you're like me, and you've been playing FSX for your whole life, this game is a considerable step up from that.  The graphics are insane, the scenery is profound, and you end up learning a lot about flying.  I had to learn how to program my own flight plan and how to fly with the autopilot using the FMC.  I learned how to start the aircraft from a cold start as well.  

However, in the first 7 hours that I owned this game, I spent most of them googling issues and trying to solve them.  I spent an hour trying to figure out why the APU wouldn't start, I spent an hour trying to figure out how to bind the yaw and the nosewheel tiller to the same control on my joystick (I gave up on this).

My summation of the above is that the game is fantastic but very advanced. Novices beware.

However, now let's get to the elephants in the room: the bugs and the gameplay.  For $60 I expected a very polished and extensive game.  In these respects, the game left me disappointed.  For example, in FSX there are missions in which you conquer different scenarios, all featuring pre-recorded ATC and sometimes even a storyline.  In X-Plane 11, it's basically like flying in free-flight all the time.  Every single other review mentions the poor vanilla ATC quality so I will give that a rest, but if you're curious, check out another review, they'll talk about it.

Secondly, I am frustrated with the bugs in this game.  There were bugs with installing plugins, and the FMC functions after pausing to click out to the desktop or start menu on my computer.  The big problem was after 6 hours of time played, none of the planes would respond to my joystick's Pitch and Roll axis.  The yaw, throttle, and all the buttons worked perfectly, but the pitch and roll didn't work.  I tried everything from resetting the controller, re-installing the controller, restarting the game, restarting my computer, but still I couldn't even taxi off the ramp because the controls didn't work.  That was the last straw for me with this game.  When Googling the problems extends beyond me learning how to fly and into me learning why the game isn't working, that's where I start losing interest in playing.  Especially because I'm new to this hyper-realistic simulator and sometimes it's hard to tell if it's a bug or if I made a mistake in the cockpit.

Feel free to comment all the plugins that I can download below, but the fact of the matter is I paid $60 for this game, I want it to work without add-ons and plugins.

I have had X Plane 11 for a few months now and its so much fun and a real challenge, you can decide freeflight of course and start from many locations at each Airport. Out of the box it seems a bit lacking,  however the  X plane.org forums and shop provides you with tools for an immersive and realistic experience and you can get far on even a limited budget. The X Plane community produces some extremely impressive freeware addons and commercial vendors provide reasonable and detailed addons such as your favorite airplanes, airports and lots more. I highly recommend this Flight Sim, it does have a learning curve but the rewards are extensive and continuing the more you use it.

In its 11th iteration this simulation offers a complete package to everyone who is into serious flight simulation that also allows diverse customization, a community that comes up with a wide variety of mods and addons. Yet this is a study sim beyond the usual Cessna flying that comes with the tutorial thus it is mainly made for people that are sold for aviation. If you decide to own this simulation you should also expect to invest in higher priced peripherals, and if you want to use VR you can but make sure your rig is beefy enough (high end CPU and GPU plus 32+GB of RAM are a must then.

Update 8 months later in April 2020.

DO NOT BUY THE GAME!!! The amount of bugs you will encounter in VR is not worth the money. By time you get things set up to work, you end up jumping in to a game that looks like it cost you 15.00. Graphics suck, optimization sucks, bugs suck. You are better off waiting for Microsoft flight sim 2020 to come out or play DCS world. Wish I could have my money back, but because I can't, I play it to see if it got better and not even a little bit.
